~ e-m e-t, to compensate one for a thing (= ~ e-t við e-n);
Styrr vá mörg víg, en bœtti engi (viz. víg), S. slew many men, but paid for none;
~ mann fé (dat.), to pay weregild for one slain (Hrafnkell bœtti engan mann fé);
~ sál sína, to devote one’s efforts to the saving of one’s soul;
~ um e-t, to improve a thing;
ekki bœtist um, matters grow worse;
~ yfir e-t, to make good again, redress;
guð bœtti honum af þessi sótt, God healed him of his disease; with gen. of the disease;
~ e-m sinnar vanheilsu, to restore one to health;
refl., e-m bœtist, one gets better, is restored to health; with gen. of the disease (bœttist Búa augnaverkjarins).
(pl. -endr), m. one who has to pay weregild.
pp. (cf. bœta) atoned for; er mér ekki sonr minn at bœttari, þótt Bolli sé drepinn, my son’s death is none the more atoned for though B. is slain; ok er eigi at ~a, þótt, things are no better though.
n. shoulder of a dragon, flipper of a whale.
(að), v. to dabble (splash) with the oars (þú skalt ~ í árum).
(að), v. to thrive (hann nam at vaxa ok vel ~).
(að), v. impers. to dawn; eptir um morguninn er trautt var dagat, at early dawn; en dagar uppi, the day dawns upon one (of dwarfs and giants).
fara með ~, to work for daily wages, be a day labourer.
m. ‘daybowl’ (a vessal containing sufficient wine for a whole day).
f. day drinking (beginning after the dagverðr).
n., in the phrase, fara ~ (dat.) ok náttfari, to travel day and night.
a. n., in the phrase, e-m verð ~, the day is not long enough for one.
a. day-long, lasting all day (daglangt erfiði);
daglangt, as adv. all through the day.
n. pl. the time about 9 o’clock a. m.
m. ‘son of the day’, poet. man.
(gen. dags, dat. degi; pl. dagar), m.
at kveldi skal dag leyfa, at eventide shall the day be praised;
dagr kemr upp í austri, sezt í vestri, the day rises in the east, sets in the west;
at kveldi dags, síð dags, late in the day;
á (or um) daginn, during the day;
hindra dags, the day after, tomorrow;
dag frá degi, hvern dag frá öðrum, from day to day;
dag eptir dag, day after day;
nótt ok dag, night and day;
dögunum optar, more times than there are days, over and over again;
á deyjanda degi, on one’s death-day;
á dögum e-s, um daga e-s, in the days of, during or in the reign of;
eptir minn dag, when I am dead (gaf honum alla sína eign eptir sinn dag);
mátti hann eigi lengr gefa en um sína dagi, than for his lifetime;
ráða (taka) e-n af dögum, to put to death.
2) leita raðs, to be an observer of days or times (menn skulu eigi leita ráðs at sýslu sínni).
a. plain (true) as day; þú segir sanna (= hit sanna), the obvious truth.
f. the first streak of daylight, daybreak.
pp. n., er ~ var, when the day was at an end, at nightfall.
n. the celebration of a day.
(gen. helgar), f. hallowedness of a day.
f. day’s mowing (= three quarters of an acre of grassland).
n., at magni œrnu, in full daylight.
m. a day’s difference (svá at mun sér á).
a. n. fixed as to the day (eigi höfum vér fundit stœtt, nær signaðr Thomas var kjörinn til erkibiskups).
f. help to win the day.
f. the drinking, after dagverðr, = dagdrykkja.
n. the time of the day-meal.
(verðar, verði, pl. verðir), m. ‘day-meal’ (the chief meal, taken at the time of dagmál), = dögurðr.
a. not knowing what day it is, = daga villr.
vaxa -vöxtum, to grow visibly day by day.
(að), v. impers. to become dented (~ði ekki né sprakk).
(gen. dals, dat. dal or dali, pl. dalar or dalir), m. dale, valley (djúpir dalir).

3) ballad (þeir gørðu um hann dansa marga).
dönsk tunga, the Danish (or old Scandinavian) language.
(acc. dapran), a. downcast, sad; of things, dreary (~ dagr, daprar nætr, döpr heimkynni).

a. dismal, sad; daprlig ásjóna, a sad look; daprlig kona, a dismallooking woman; daprligir draumar, dismal dreams.
vefr darraðar, web of spears, woof of war.
(að), v. refl. to become weary and exhausted.
pp. weary and exhausted (from cold or bodily exertions).
(að), v. to throb; ~ði hjarta hans við, his heart sank.

a. turning a deaf ear to (við e-t).

kasta daus ok ás, to throw deuce-ace.

f. ‘death-fetch’; an apparition boding one’s death.
f. hell, opp. to ‘jörð lifandi manna’, ‘udáinsakr’, paradise.

n. = banaorð; segja ~ e-s, to relate one’s death.

n. deadly strain (of the muscles or tendons, of a horse).

pr. p. death-bringing, deadly (dauðfœranda gras, eitr).

2) the state of being mortal, mortality.
1) deadly, fatal (~ harmr, dauðlig synd, dauðligt eitr);
(gen. dauðs), m. = dauði (drepa, brenna, e-n til dauðs).
verða, vera, ~, to become dead, die;
falla niðr ~, to drop down dead;
ganga ~, to reappear (of ghosts), = ganga aptr;
a. dying, at the point of death.
n. pl., in the phrase, liggja á ~m, to be dying (cf. ‘líkstrá’, nástrá).

(-ða, -ðr), v. to make soft, to weaken.
f. servantmaid, dairymaid (~ eðr önnur hjún).
sú á, er deilir með jötna sonum grund ok með goðum, that river which parts the giants and the gods;
alit þat land, er vatnsföll ~ til sjófar, of which the rivers form the boundaries down to the sea;
vildi H. bæði kjósa ok ~, H. would both choose and deal (viz. divide the catch in shares and choose for himself the share he liked best);

with dat. (hversu má keisarinn ~ sér í tvá staði);

4) to busy or occupy oneself with, deal with (engi maðr á önnur mál at ~ í kirkju, nema biðja fyrir sér);

5) ~ við e-n, to quarrel with one (~ við heimska hali);

n. pl. distinctive features; kunna, vita öll (engi) ~ á e-u, to know all (nothing) about a thing; sá þó öll ~ á. honum, all his features were visible.

a. likely to lead to a quarrel.
f. the sharpening, of a scythe by hammering (cf. lédenging).

f. the sharpening, of a scythe by hammering (cf. lédenging).

1) to make deaf (daufr); impers., hann deyfi, he became deaf;
2) to make blunt (~ egg, sverð, vápn);

(dey; dó, dóum; dáinn), v. to die (deyr fé, ~ frændr); hann dó af eitri, ór sárum, he died of poison, from wounds; á ~nda degi, on one’s dying day, on one’s deathbed of a limb (dó fótleggrinn allr); of inanimate things, dáinn arfr, an inheritance left to the heir.

1) big, stout, opp. to grannr; ~ sem naut, big as an ox; ~ fótr, a big leg; hon gekk ~ með tveim, she was big with twins;

1) to compose in Latin (~ ok skrifa bréf á Látínu);
3) to invent, devise, think out (hann gerir á sömu leið sem fjandinn fyrir honum ~r).

(-ða, -t), v. to make bold; esp. ~ sik or ~st, to dare; ~st til es or at e-u, to have courage for a thing; bœndr dirfðust mjök við Birkibeina, became bold, impudent; ~st at gera et, to dare to do a thing.
a. bold, daring (~ í orrustum); ~ ok dularfullr, impudent and arrogant.
(dat. djöfli, pl. djöflar), m. devil; freq. as a term of abuse (taki þér djöful þenna).

2) heavy, severe (djúp laun ok ill); neut., djúpt, as adv., deep, deeply; leggjast djúpt, to dive deep.
a. benumbed, dead, of limbs (~ er mér fótr minn).

1) the iron rim under the keel of a boat or a sled; fig., leggja ~ undir ofmetnað e-s, to encourage one’s spirit;
2) an additional line to a stanza.
~ heim viðinn, to drag the logs home;
absol., drógu þeir skjótt eptir, they soon pulled up to them;

~ fisk, to catch, pull up fish with a line;
~ kvernstein, to turn the millstone, to grind;
við ramman mun reip at ~, it will be pulling a rope against a strong man, i. e. it will be a difficult task;
2) to draw, inhale (~ úþefjan með nösum);
~ nasir af e-u, to smell a thing;
3) to procure, earn, gain (þegar hann hafði fé dregit sem hann vildi);
~ e-m e-t, to procure (or get) one a thing (eigi sögðust þeir vita, at hann drœgi Haraldi ríki);
4) to employ as a measure (~ kvarða við viðmál);
5) to prolong protract (dvalir þessar drógu tímann);
vil ek þessi svör ekki láta ~ fyrir mér lengi, I will not wait long for these answers;
hann dró um þat engan hlut, he made no subterfuge;
7) to delineate, draw a picture (var dregit á skjöldinn leo með gulli);
í þann tíma sem hann dregr klæðaföllin (the folds);
8) to trim or line garments (treyjan var dregin útan ok innan við rauða silki);
with dat., hjálmr hans var dreginn leiri (overlaid with clay), er áðr var (dreginn) gulli;
drógu þeir þeim svá nær (came so near to them), at;
~ föt, skóklædi af e-m, to pull off one’s clothes, shoes;

dró hann þá grunninu, he pulled them off the shallow;
~ e-t af e-u, to draw, derive from a source;
~ e-t af, to take off (Þ. hafði látit af ~ brúna);
~ e-t af við e-n, to keep back, withhold, from one;
man héðan af eigi af dregit við oss, henceforth we shall no be neglected, stinted;
Egill dró at sér skipit, E. pulled the ship close up to himself;
~ vél at e-m, to draw wiles around one;
~ spott, skaup, at e-u, to hold a thing up to ridicule;
~ at lið, föng, to collect troops, stores;
dró at honum sóttin, the illness drew closer to him, he grew worse;
impers., dró at mætti hans, dró at um matt hans, his strength declined (fell off);
til þess er dró at degi, till the day drew near;
þá er dregr at jólum, when Yule drew near;
dró at því (the time drew near). at hann væri banvænn;
tók þá at ~ fast at heyjum hans, his stock of hay was rapidly diminishing;
svá dregr at mér af elli, svengd, þorsta, I am so overcome by old age, hunger, thirst;
nú þykki mér sem fast dragi at þér, that thou art sinking fast;
~ hring á hönd sér, to put a ring on one’s hand;
~ á vetr, to rear through the winter (Hrafnkell dró á vetr kálf ok kið);
impers., dregr á tunglit, the moon is obscured (= dregr myrkr á tunglit);
dimmu þykkir ~ á ráðit Odds, it looks as if a cloud was drawing over Odds’ affairs;

~ eptir e-m, to gain on one (Þórarinn sótti ákaft róðrinn ok hans menn, ok drógu skjótt eptir þeim Steinólfi ok Kjallaki);

~ e-ð saman, to collect, gather (~ lið, her, skip saman);

dregr þá saman or dregr saman með þeim, the distance between them grows less;
~ e-t í sundr, to draw asunder, disjoin (vil ek eigi ~ í sundr sættir yðrar);
impers., dregr þá í sundr or dregr í sundr með þeim, the distance between them increases;
~ e-n til e-s, to move, prompt, induce;
engi ofkæti dregr mik til þessarar ferðar, it is not from wantonness that I undertake this journey;
slíkt dregr hann til vinsældar, this furthers his popularity;
ef hann drógi ekki til, if he was not concerned;

hann hét at ~ allt til sætta (to do everything in his power for reconciliation) með þeim Skota konungi;
impers., nema til verra dragi, unless matters turn out for the worse;
with dat., þat samband þeirra, er þeim dregr báðum til bana, which will prove fatal to both of them;
at hér mundi til mikillar úgiptu ~ um kaup þessi, that much mischief would arise from this bargain;

~ e-t undan e-m, to seek to deprive one of a thing (þeir hafa bundizt í því at ~ bœndr undan þér);

~ rót undan (tölu), to extract the root;

impers., hann (acc.) dró undan sem nauðuligast, he had a narrow escape;

impers., dró yðr (acc.) undir hrakningina, en oss (acc.) undan, you came in for hard uasge but we escaped;
~ upp skip, to drag a ship ashore;
~ upp segl, to hoist a sail (sails);

impers., þoku dregr upp, fog is coming on;
1) timber carried on horseback and trailing along the ground;
2) metric term, repetition, anadiplosis (when a stanza begins with the last word of the preceding one).
v. refl. to draw oneself, move;
~ aptr á leið, to remain behind;
~ á hendr e-m, to gather around one;

þegar honum dróst aldr, when her grew up;
herr, lið, dregst e-m, troops gather round one;
~ vel, illa, to do well, ill;
dróst þá liðit mjök af kulda, the host suffered much from cold;
þau drógust (they pulled against each other, fought) um einn gullhring;

m. trail or long line of laden horses.
m. a trailing kirtle or gown.
(að), v. to drag, trail oneself along (hann ~r síðan heim at búrinu);
(að), v. to be haughty, behave with arrogance (~ við em, í móti em); ~ af e-u, to pride oneself on; ~ yfir sér, to boast; ~ yfir em, to lord it over one, look down upon one.
m. a foot showing pride (hefja fót í mót em).
n. pl. proud speech, haughty language.
(-s, -ar), m. a detached pillar of rock.

a. n. a sort of metre.
n. pl. ‘house of ghosts’, burial mound (poet.).
(-s, -ar), m. the dead inhabitant of a cairn, ghost, spirit.
f. ‘dreamwoman’, one who appears in dreams.
m. a man who appears in dreams.

(-s, -ar), m. dream; eigi er mark at draumum, dreams are not worth noticing; segja em draum, to tell one’s dream to another; ráða draum, to read (interpret) a dream; ~ rætist, a dream proves true; vakna eigi við góðan draum, to awake from a bad dream; em er draums, one dreams, is in a trance.
m. a skilfull interpreter of dreams.
a. one who never dreams (cf. þat er eigi manns eðli, at hann dreymi aldri’).
n. assembly of dreams, poet. sleep.
n. soldiers decorated with ribbons = dreglat lið.
drepa e-u á ~, to scatter about; fig. to throw or cast aside, to let drop;
þeir drápu óllu á ~ um þessa fyrirætlun, gave it up altogether;
2) string or chain (valrinn komst hvergi, því at ~arnar héldu honum).

1) to scatter, disperse, with dat. (dreifðu þeir þá öllu liðinu); to strew (tak duft ok dreif á sárit); to sprinkle (~ vatni umhverfis stein); ~ en blóði, to bedabble one with blood; reflex., ~st, to be spread out;
f. scattering, diffusion; ~ blóðs, effusion of blood.
adv. scatteredly; fara ~, to march in loose order (of troops).
(-tta, -ttr), v., in the phrase, ~ en inni, to shut one up so as to force him to ease himself (drita) within doors.
n. a dragon’s head on a ship’s prow.
n. a banner bearing the sign of a dragon.
2) ship of war (bearing a dragon’s head as an ornament at the prow).
~ full, minni, horn, to drink a toast, cup, horn;
~ drykk, to drink a draught (þú skalt ~ af tvá drykki);
~ e-n af stokki, to drink one under the table;

1) one half of the astron. Day, twelve hours of the day or night (í degi dœgr tvau, í dœgri stundir tólf; tuttugu ok fjórar stundir skulu vera í tveimr dœgrum);
2) an astronomical day; twenty-four hours; sjau dœgra sigling, a sail of seven days (between Norway and Iceland).
n. the division of day and night.
n. the twilight at morning and evening.
m. dalesman, mostly in pl. compounds. (Laxdœlir, Fljótsdœlir, Vatnsdœlir, etc.).

1) to give judgement, pass sentence; ~ mál, to give judgement in a case; ~ dóm, to give a verdict or sentence; ~ sekt, útlegð, to pass sentence of a fine, out-lawry; ~ eindaga á fé, to fix a term for payment; ~ lög, to pass a lawful sentence; ~ e-n skógarmann, to proclaim one an outlaw; ~ e-m e-t, to adjudge a thing to one; ~ e-m dóm, to deal out a sentence to one; ~ e-n af e-u, to declare one to have forfeited (~ e-n af sinni sœmd); ~ um e-t, to judge of;
2) to talk, converse; ~ við e-n, to talk with one; drekka ok ~, to drink and talk; en er þeir áttu of þessa hluti at ~, when they were talking of those things.

1) proof, reason; draga þeir eigi sízt til dœmis þar um, at, in proof of this they specially adduce the fact, that;
2) incident, fact; þó hafa mörg dœmi orðit, í forneskju, yet many things have happened in elden times; hörð dœmi, hard fate; at eigi verði oss Adams ~, that the same shall not happen to us as to A.;
3) tale, story (Ari prestr fróði, er mörg dœmisparklig hefir saman sett);
4) poem, verses (þessi dœmi öll eru kveðin um þenna atburð);
6) example for imitation, model (eptir dœmum kristinna manna); taka ~ af e-m, to take an example by one;

7) example, instance, precedent (djarfari en dœmi munu til vera); umfram ~, ór dœmum, unexampled, unprecedented (kom þá svá mikill snjór, at þat var ór dœmum); meirr en til dœmis or til dœma at taka (draga), to take an example.
2) the name of the book Edda, written by Snorri Sturluson, c. 1220.
1) if, in case (aldri hefðir þú í borgina komit, ef ek hefða vitat); in poetry generally with subj.; vega þú gakk, ef vreiðr séir (sér), if thou be wroth;
2) = hvárt, if, whether (Egill spurði, ef hann vildi upp ór gröfinni);
3) as a relat. part., sá ef = sá er (rare).
n. doubt; ef er á e-u, it is doubtful; ekki er til efs, at, it cannot be doubted that; útan ef, without doubt.
(að), v. to doubt (engi efar þat); ~ um e-t, to doubt about a thing;
refl., ~st í e-u, to hesitate in, be in doubt; ~ um e-t = efa um e-t; with gen., ~ e-s, to change one’s mind in a matter.
m. doubtfulness; ~ sagnar, ambiguity of expression.
1) to strengthen structurally, to reinforce (~ veggi);

~ her (lið) á hendr e-m, to raise troops against one;
~ e-n, to support, aid (efldi Dofri hann síðan til ríkis í Noregi);

~ at brullaupi, to hold a wedding;
4) to be able (sem vér eflum ok orkum);
v. refl. to grow strong (hann fann, at mótstöðumenn hans efldust);

~ til ríkis, to win a kingdom (by force of arms);
poet., ~ við e-n, to marry into one’s family, = mægjast.
adv. undoubtedly, without doubt (~ má hann þat vita).
(-da, -dr), v. to perform, fulfil (~ orð sín, sætt, heit);
refl., ~st, to turn out in a certain way (efndist þat ok vel; þat efnist opt illa).
(að), v. to prepare, make arrangements for a thing (e. til vetrsetu, veizlu kaupstaðar).
f. scarcity, want, or shortness of means.
n. scarcity, want, or shortness of means.
m. scarcity, want, or shortness of means.
f. fulfilment of a promise (raun mun eptir fara um efndir).

1) stuff, material (svá skildu þeir, at allir hlutir væri smíðaðir af nökkuru efni); ek em görr af ústyrku efni, I am made of frail stuff; cf. biskups-, brúðar-, fægðar-, konu-, konungs-, mágs-, manns-, mungáts-, smíðar-efni;
2) matter of discourse, subject, theme (þryti mér fyrr stundin til frásagnar en efnit til umrœðu) eigi með sönnu e., with untrue statement, falsely; nú er úti mitt e., now my story is at an end;
3) matter, affair (segir konungr frá öllu þessu e.); fátt er betr látit en e. eru tíl, few things are reported better than they really are;
4) cause, reason; látast báðir af því e., both die from this cause; fyrir þat e. (for that reason) keypti hann landit

5) state, condition, affair; sagði, hver e. í vóru, he told how matters stood; ek veit eigi görla e. Gunnlaugs, how G.’s affairs stand; kominn í úvænt e., into a critical condition; óttalauss í öllu e., in every respect; er þessi hlutr kom til efnis, when this came aboitt; berr þat til efnis, at, it happens that;
6) pl., means; ok bjuggust um eptir þeim efnum, sem þeir höfðu til, according to their means; engi vóru e. annars, þar vóru engi e. önnur, there was no other chance or choice.
a. hopeful, promising (efniligir menn); ekki efniligt, not advisable.
bera efra skjöld, to gain the victory;
verða e-m ~, to be superior to;
a) high above ground (fara hit efra í trjám sem apynjur eða íkornar);

by land, opp. to the sea;

þetta var inn efra hlut sumars, towards the end of summer;
á efra aldri, advanced in years.
efsta vika langaföstu, the last week of Lent, Passion Week.
(gen. -jar, dat. -ju; pl. -jar), f. edge; eyða (verja) oddi ok eggju, by force of arms, with might and main.
pp. cut, wounded by an edge.

(að), v. to incite, egg one on to do a thing (e. e-n e-s or til e-s or á e-t); e. e-n fram, to urge one on;
refl., láta at ~st, to yield to another’s egging on; e. upp á e-n, to pick a quarrel with one, provoke one; recipr. to egg one another on (eggjuðust nú fast hvarirtveggju).
m. poet. play with sharp weapons, battle.
m. ‘edge-twig’, the steeled edge of a sword; svá at fal báða eggteina sverðsins, so that both edges of the sword were hidden.

m. the steeled edge of an axe (hann snerpir eggvölinn).
1) to use as a bait, with dat. (e. oxahöfði a öngul);

m. pl. the inhabitants of Agðir, a fylki in Norway.
ei ok ei, forever and ever;
1) to own, possess (Starkaðr átti hest góðan);
2) to have (~ börn, föður, móður, vin);
~ konu, to have her for wife;
hann átti Gró, he was married to G.;
hann gekk at ~ Þóru, he took Th. for his wife, he married Th.;
enga vil ek þessa ~, I will not marry any of these;
~ heima, to have a home, to live (þeir áttu heima austr í Mörk);
~ sér e-t = ~ e-t (Höskuldr átti sér dóttur, er Hallgerðr hét);
~ ván e-s, to have hope of a thing, to reckon upon;
~ hlut at or í e-u, to have a share in a thing, to be concerned in;
~ vald á e-u, to have within one’s power;
3) to be under obligation, be obliged, have to do a thing;
tólf menn, þeir er fylgð áttu með konungi, who were bound to attend the king’s person;
á ek þar fyrir at sjá, I am bound (I have) to see to that;
átti Hrútr för í Vestfjorðu, H. had to go to the V.;
4) to have a right (claim) to, be entitled to (~ högg ok höfn í skóginum);
~ mál í e-m, to have a charge against one;
~ rétt á sér, to have a (personal) claim to redress;
~ fund, þing, samkvámu, stefnu, to hold a meeting;
~ orrustu við e-n, to fight a battle with one;
~ högg við e-n, to exchange blows with one;
~ illt við e-n, to quarrel with;
~ tal (or mál) við e-n, to speak, converse with one;
6) as an auxiliary with pp. = hafa (þat er við áttum mælt);
7) to have to (skal Þ. eigi at því ~ at spotta);
~ hendr sínar it verja, to have to act in self-defence;
~ um vandræði at halda, to be in a strait;
8) ~ e-m e-t, to owe to one (mun æ, hvat þú átt þeim er veitir);
9) to be the person denoted by a thing;
þat muntu ætla, at ek mun ~ hinn bleika uxann, that the fawn-coloured ox means me;
~ e-t at e-m, to have something due from one, to expect from one (þat vil ek ~ at þér, at þú segir mér frá ferð þinni);
to deserve from one (ok á ek annat at þér);
þeir er mikit þóttust at sér ~, had much in their power;
~ e-t eptir, to have to do yet, to have left undone (þat áttu eptir, er erfiðast er, en þat er at deyja);
to leave behind one (andaðist ok átti eptir tvá sonu vaxna);
~ e-t saman, to own in common;
~ skap saman, to agree well, be of one mind;
eigi veit ek, hvárt við eigum heill saman, whether we shall live happy together;
~ um við e-n, to have to deal with (við brögðótta áttu nú um);
þar sem við vini mína er um at ~, where my friends are concerned;
~ e-t undir e-m, to have in another’s hands;

Njáll átti mikit fé undir Starkaði ok í Sandgili, N. had much money out at interest with St. and at Sandgil, er sá eigi vel staddr, er líf sitt á undir þinum trúnaði, whose life depends on thy good faith;
~ mikit (lítit) undir sér, to have much (little) in one’s power;
far þú við marga menn, svá at þú eigir allt undir þér, that the whole matter rests in thy own hands;
hann sá, at hann átti ekki undir sér, that he had no influence;
~ við e-n, to have to do with, fight with (brátt fundu þeir, at þeir áttu þar ekki við sinn maka);
ekki á ek þetta við þik, this is no business between thee and me;
~ gott (illt) við e-n, to be on good (bad) terms with one;

recipr., ~st við, to deal with one another; fight, quarrel;

kasta sinni eigu, leggja sína eigu, í e-t, to take possession of;

(gen. eikar and eikr, pl. eikr), f. oak, also a tree in general.

~ skal við ~ eiga, one shall fight against one;

2) as ord. numb. = inn fyrsti (Urð hétu eina, aðra Verðandi, Skuld ina þriðju);

in poetry and old prose a pronominal k is suffixed to the verb, emk = em ek, vask = vas ek; sák = sá ek; mundak = munda ek; even if preceded by ek: ek sék, ek sitk; a preceding g becomes by assimilation k, hykk = hygg ek; the pronominal k is inserted between the suffixed negative, -a or -at, and the verb, sáka = sá ek-a, I saw not; veitka = veit ek-a, I know not.
f. carting, carrying in a cart (sumir tóku til ekju).

nom. and acc. neut. sing. of engi, nothing, nought; also used as adv., not, = eigi.

(-s, -ar), m. fire; taka eld, drepa (upp) eld, to strike fire: kveikja (upp) eld, to light a fire; bregða (koma, skjóta) eldi í e-t, láta (leggja) eld í e-t, to set fire to, to set on fire; e. varð lauss ok lék skjótt, a fire broke out and spread rapidly; e. hraut af sverðum þeirra, sparks of fire flew from their swords.
pp. grown old, worn by age; kvazt e. vera mjök frá úfriði, said that he was too old for fighting.
a. habitually sitting by the fire (for warmth).
a. habitually sitting by the fire (for warmth).
f. flint to strike fire with.
m. pl. the dwellers on the banks of the Gotha (Gautelfr).
m. pl. the dwellers on the banks of the Gotha (Gautelfr).
f. pl. the arms of the Gotha, also used of the mouths of the Nile.
n. pl. the skerries at the mouth of the Gotha.
(gen. elfar, dat. and acc. elfi), f. river; esp. as prop. name in Saxelfr, the Elbe; Gautelfr or Elfr, the river Gotha (in Sweden); Raumelfr (in Norway).
m. centaur (a monster half man and half elk).
f. a rival wife (þær konur eru eljur er einn mann eigu).
1) else, otherwise (skaltu eigi annat þora en fara ella skal ek drepa þik); eða ella, or else; eða heit hvers manns níðingr ella, or else be called the ‘nithing’ of every man;
2) or, or else (annathvárt at koma honum á mitt vald, ella drepa hann sjálfr).

a. superl. eldest, oldest (~ brœðranna; hinn ellzti sonr).
(að), v. to wax, grow; sótt elnar á hendr e-m, e-m elnar sóttin, one’s illness becomes worse.
(að), v. to love (hann ~ði ekki annat goð meir en Frey);
refl., ~st at e-m, to grow fond of; recipr., to love one another (höfðu þau Jón ~zt frá barnœsku).
f. love (= ást); hafa elsku á e-m, to love one; leggja elsku á e-n or við e-n, to take a fancy for, to fall in love with one.
a. fondly attached to one (e. at e-m), of persons and animals.
f. a special kind of love.
2) beloved, dear (e. faðir!); ~ e-m, dear to one.
1) to knead (e. leir); ek skal yðra búð e. (belabour) með klungrum;
2) to chase, pursue; e. óxn með vendi, to drive cattle with a goad; e. sauði, to run after sheep;
refl., eltast eptir e-m, to pursue eagerly.
1) to attend, serve, wait upon, e. e-m (eiga gestum. at e.); e. fé, to attend to the cattle, to milk;
2) to administer the sacrament to one (e. e-m).
1) service, = þjónosta 1; veita e-m e., to serve one; bindast í e-s e., to enter one’s service; guðligt e., holy service; hefi ek mörg vandræði þolat í þinu e., in your service;
3) office (biskupligt e.); bjóða e-m af e., to depose one from office.
a. able to perform one’s duties.

~ heima mun ek sitja, but I will stay at home;
ek kann ráðum, Gunnhildar, ~ kappsemd Egils, I know the devices of G. and (on the other hand) Egil’s eagerness;
3) = ‘an’, than (óbrigðra vin fær maðr aldregi ~ mannvit mikit).
in Norse MSS. = ef, er (rel. pron. and temp. conj.);
sælar væri sálurnar, ~ þær vissi, if they knew;
mína dóttur, ~ (= er) allra meyja er fegrst, who is the fairest of all maidens;
3) when, = er, þá er (þeir vóru í hjá, ~ upp var lesit).
1) with subj. (a standing phrase in the law connecting the latter clause of a conditional premiss) if, and if, and in case that, and supposing that;
nú hefir maðr sveinbarn fram fœrt í œsku, ~ verði sá maðr veginn síðan, þá …, if a man has brought a boy up in his youth, and it so happens that he (the boy) be slain, then …;
2) even if, allhough, with subj. (seg mér, hvat til berr, at þú veizt fyrir úorðna hluti, ~ sér þú eigi spámaðr);
þá skal hann segja búum sínum til, ~ á, þingi, even in parliment;
4) if only with subj. (fyrir engan mun þori ek at vekja konunginn en segja má ek honum tíðindin, ef þú vill, ~ vekir þú hann);
5) and indeed, and of course, and also, and besides;
~ skulum vér þá leysa þik, and then of course we shall loose thee;
sýnist þat jafnan, at ek em fégjarn, ~ man svá enn, and so it will be also in this case;
eigi nenni ek at hafa þat saman, at veita Högna, ~ drepa bróður hans, I cannot bear to do both, help H. and yet kill his brother;
~ tak þú nú øxi þína, and now take thy axe.
1) to end, coming to an end (í því sama klaustri endi hann sína æfi);
impers., ~r þar sögu frá honum, the tale of him ends there;
3) to mark the end of, to bound (af suðri endir hana [i. e. Asia] úthafit);
4) refl., ~st, to end, come to an end (reiði mannsins endist á einu augabragði);
to last, hold out (berjast meðan dagrinn endist);
meðan mér ~st föng til, as long as my provisions last;
ef honum endist aldr til, if he lives so long;
meðan mér ~st lífdagar, meðan ek endumst, as long as I live;
to turn out, to end (well or ill), to do (enda mun þat fám bóndum vel ~st at synja mér mægðar).
m. the last day, day of death (vita sinn endadag).
endamörk ríkis þíns, the end of thy reign.
a. thin at the end, tapering; gera eigi endamjótt við e-n, not to leave one in the lurch, treat one well to the end.
n. = eindœmi 2, something unexampled or unheard of (þat er undr ok ~);
m. a monster, an extraordinary person.
1) the end (extremity) of an object (þar var skáli mikill ok dyrr á báðum endum);

2) conclusion, end, issue (hvern enda eiga mundi málit); gera enda á e-u, koma enda á e-t, to bring to an end; vera á enda, to be at an end; S. var vistum með föður sínum til enda, S. stayed with his father to the end; eigi er fyrir enda um gert með þeim, their difference is not settled between them upphaf ok endir, beginning and end; hér skal nú ok endir á verða, here it shall come to an end; sá varð endir á, at, the end of it was, that; til alls endis, to the very end.
a. along the whole extent of, from one end to the other (ríða um endilangt herað); ok lagðist þar ~, at full length; um endilangt, at endilöngu, lengthways.
n. pl. = endalok; til ~a heims, to the end of the world.
n. = eindœmi 2, something unexampled or unheard of (þat er undr ok ~);
m. esp. in nom., = endi (upphaf ok ~ míns máls).
1) in times of yore, formerly, = endr fyrir löngu;
2) again (svá kom Óðins son endr at hamri);
3) endr á sinnum, endr ok stundum, from time to time, now and then.
adv. at other times, else (bæði þá á endramer).
(að), v. to get well again, recover.
(-tta, -ttr), v. to repair, restore (þat þarf at ~, er áðr hefir farizt).

(see gjalda), v. to pay back, to repay.
(að), v. to call to life again.
(að), v. to return to life, to revive.
(see minna), v. refl. to remember, call to mind, with gen.
(að), v. to renew, repeat; impers. (~ði sóttina í annat sinn).
(see skapa), v. to create anew, recreate.
(see taka), v. to resume, take up again (~ til e-s).
(-ða, -ðr), v. to make secure again, reconcile.
1) (gen. -jar, pl. -jar), f. meadow, meadow-land (hann villtist í enginni); pl. outlying grass-fields.

1) no, none, no one; hafa ekki e-s, to have nothing of it; lose it altogether (er búit við, at þú hafir þá ekki dýrsins); old dat. einugi = engu (fátt er svá illt, at einugi dugi);
2) any, after a negative (aldri fyrr fekk hann þvílíkan sigr í engri herferð); after comparative (þessir dvergar kunnu betr smíða af járni en engir aðrir).
n. meadow, meadow-land (tún ok eng; akr ok engi).

(en, et), the oldest form of the def. art., = inn, hinn.

1) with verbs of motion, after (ríða, róa, fara, ganga, senda e-m);
2) denoting the aim and object of many verbs;
leita, spyrja, frétta, ~ e-u, to search, ask, inquire after;
líta ~ e-u, to look afler, attend to;
vaka ~ e-m, to sit up waiting for one;
segja ~ e-m, to report behind one’s back;
3) following the course of a track, road, etc., along;
~ endilongu, from one end to the other;
4) after, according to, in accordance with (~ sið þeirra ok lögum);
hann leiddist ~ fortölum hennar, he was led by her persuasion;
gekk allt ~ því sem H. hafði sagt, according as H. had said;
fátt manna ~ því sem hann var vanr, few men in comparison to what he was want to have;
6) with verbs denoting imitation, indulgence, longing after;
fundust ~ þeim írskar bœkr, which they had left behind;
1) of time, after, in succession to (vár kom ~ vetr);
hvern dag ~ annan, one day after the other;
ár ~ ár, dag ~ dag, year by year, day by day;
taka e-t í arf ~ e-n, to inherit from one;
hann tók konungdóm ~ föður sinn, after his father;
vita þá skömm ~ sik, to leave such a bad report;
skaði mikill er ~ menn slíka, there is a great loss in such men;
annat sumar ~, the second summer after;
~ um várit, later during the spring;
~ koma úsvinnum ráð, the fool is wise when too late;
bíða sitja ~, to wait, stay behind;
vera, standa ~, to remain behind, be left;
skammt get ek ~ þinnar æfi, I guess that little is left of thy life;
3) before the rel. part., ~ er = ~ þat er, after (ef maðr, andast á þingi ~ er menn eru á braut farnir);
fig., vera ~ e-s, to be inferior to one.

f. (a female) underling (ek mun eigi vera ~ hennar).

a. remaining behind; verða ~, to remain behind.
1) aftermost, hindmost, opp. to fremri ~ fótr the hind leg; hit eptra austrrúm, the hindmost pumping place;

I) (older form es), rel. part. in old poems and in law phrases ‘es’ is suffixed to a demonstrative or interrogative word, pron. or adv., as s: sás, sús, þats, þeims, þærs; þars, þás, þegars, síðans, hveims, hvars, &c., = sá es, sú es, þar es, þá es, &c.
I. used as a rel. pron., indecl., who, which, that;
1) Mörðr hét maðr, er (nom.) kallaðr var gígja;
grös fögr, er (acc.) hón hafði í hendi;
aðra hluti þá, er (gen.) menn vildu visir verða;
þann einn son, er (dat.) hann ann lítit;
2) with a prep. placed at the end of the sentence;
land, er hann kom frá, the land he came from;
jötunn, er ór steini var höfuðit á (viz. honum), whose head was of stone;
ór þeim ættum, er mér þóttu fuglarnir fljúga (viz. ór), from the quarter that I thought the birds flew from;
þeir hafa nú látit líf sitt, er mér þykkir eigi vert at lifa (viz. eptir), whom I think it is not worth while to outlive;
4) a personal or demonstr. pron. may be added to the rel. part., er þú, er þik; er hann, er hón, er hana, er hans, er hennar, er þeim, er þeiri, er þeira, etc.;
œrr ertu, Loki, er þú (who) yðra telr ljóta leiðstafi;
sá maðr, er hann vill, that man who wishes;
nema ein Goðrún, er hón æva grét, who never wept;
ekkja heitir sú, er búandi hennar (whose husband) varð sóttdauðr;
þann konung, er undir honum eru skatt-konungar, that king under whom are tributary kings;
5) in the fourteenth century added to the int. pron., hverr;
þat herbergi, í hverju er hann (in which = er hann í því) hefir sitt ráð ok ræðr;
II. as a conj. and adv.
1) local, er, þar er, there where;
hann sá á eldinum fölskann, er netit hafði brunnit, where the net had been burnt;
Ó. gekk þar til, er H. lá, to the spot where H. lay;
2) of time, er, þá er, when;
þegar er, as soon as (þegar er lýsti, stóð konungr upp);
næst er vér kómum, next when we came;
þá lét í hamrinum, sem er reið gengr, as when it thunders;
ok fannst þat á öllu, er hón þóttist vargefin, that she thought she was thrown away;
ek em þess sæll, er okkart félag sleit, I am happy that;
skyldi fara fyrst leyniliga, en þó kom þar, er allir vissu, but it came to this, that every one knew of it.
n. pl. the result (issue) of one’s errand.
eiga ~ við e-n, hafa ~ til e-s, to have business with one;
2) the result of one’s errand or mission (þótti mönnum hans ~ lítit orðit);
ef ~t eyðist, if the errand turns to nought;
hefik erfiði ok ~, I have had toil but also gained my quest;
3) ganga erenda (eyrna, ørna) sinna, to go to ease oneself;
tala langt ~ ok snjallt, to make a long and eloquent speech.
a. without effect, vain; fara at erendislausu, to go on a fool’s errand.
adv. in vain, to no purpose (fara ~).
1) to honour with a funeral feast (síðan lét Egill ~ sonu sina eptir fornum sið);
2) to inherit (erfir hón allt þat eptir börn sín).
n. funeral feast (gøra e. e-s, e. eptir e-n; drekka e. e-s, eptir e-n).

(pl. -jar), m. heir, child (þau áttu engan erfingja).
(gen. -nytja), m. heir, child (ek á ungan erfinytja).
f. holding, a funeral, feast (þá eyddist ~in).
2) ~ e-m, to cause one trouble; ~ sér í e-u, to trouble oneself with;
4) impers, ~ði sóttarfar hans, his illness grew more severe.
a. difficult to do (varð þeim þat erfiðdrœgt).
n. trouble, toil, labor; höfum ~ ok ekki erendi, we have the toil, but no result.
adv. with pain and toil; e-t horfir ~, it looks hard; búa ~ við e-n, to treat one harshly; varð mér þar ~st um, there I met with the greatest difficulties.
a. toilsome, difficult, adverse (margir hlutir erfiðligir).

a. difficult, hard, troublesome; oss verðr erfitt at þjóna Norðmönnum, it will be hard for us; Guðrún var erfið á gripakaupum, G. was troublesome (extravagant) in buying finery; hvíldist Helgi, því at honum var orðit erfitt, for he was exhausted; þó at honum væri málit erfitt, though he spoke with difficulty.
n. the skin of the glutton.
taka ~, to take possession of an inheritance;
taka, eignast e-t at ~, to get or come into possession of by inheritance.
m. the section of law treating of inheritance.
m. an úmagi, having an inherited right to receive support.
f. law or ordinance relating to inheritance.
3) unmanliness, unwarrior-like behavior with a strong connotation of effeminacy and passive homosexuality.
(ð), v. refl. to lose courage, grow faint-hearted (svá ergist hverr sem hann eldist).

adv. abroad, in a foreign land.

old form for er, rel. part., and 3rd pers. sing. from vera.
1) to eat (~ kjöt, mat sinn, dagverð);
fig., ~ orð sín, to eat one’s own words;
sorg etr hjarta, sorrow eats away the heart;
refl., Gyðingar átust innan, er þeir heyrðu þetta, the Jews fretted inwardly on hearing this.
standa öllum fótum í etu, to live at rack and manger;
1) to incite, egg (goad) on to fight, with dat.; ~ hestum, to make horses fight; with acc., ~ e-n til þolinmœði, to exhort one to patience;

2) ~ hamingju, afli, við e-n, to match one’s luck, strength, with anolher’s; ~ kappi við e-n, to contend in rivalry, vie with one; ~ ráðum, hvárt …, to consider, if …; ~ saman manndrápum, to incite two parties to manslaughter;
3) ~ við e-t, to contend against; ~ við aflsmun (liðsmun), to fight against odds;
4) to put forth; hann etr fram skallanum, he exposes his bare skull (to the blows);
5) to cause to be eaten; ~ heyvi, heyjum, to feed cattle upon hay;
6) refl., etjast við e-n, to contend with one; ef menn etjast vitnum á, if men contend (plead) with witnesses.
neut. sing. from engi and adv. = ekki.
m. crib, manger (U. fal hann í etustalli), = eta 1.
ey manni þat veit, no man knows.
(gen. eyjar, dat. ey and eyju; pl. eyjar), f. an island.

adv. poet. not at all (~ hefi ek fé);

(pl. eyru), n. ear (eyrum hlýðir gestr, en augum skoðar); setja hnefa við e. e-m, to give one a box on the ear; leiða e-n af eyrum, to get rid of one; koma e-m til eyrna, to come to one’s ears, of news; hafa nef í e. e-m, to put the nose in one’s ear, to whisper to one, of a tell-tale.

1) ounce of silver, the eighth part of a mark (átta aurar í mörk); hringr, er stendr sex aura, a ring weighing or worth six aurar; verðr þá at hálfri mörk vaðmála e., then the ~ is equal to half a mark in wadmal; e. brendr = e. brends silfrs, an ounce of pure silver;
2) ounce (svá var haglit stórt, at hvert haglkornit vá eyri);

3) money in general, property; ljósir aurar verða at löngum trega, bright silver brings long, woe; ilir af aurum, a miser; gefin til aura (= til fjár), wedded for money; hann vissi ekki aura sinna tal, he knew not the tale (extent) of his riches; lausir aurar, opp. to ‘fastr ~’, movables, chattels (lönd ok lausir aurar); fríðr ~ (= frítt fé, kvikfé), cattle;
4) money, currency; Flosi spurði í hverjum aurum hann vildi fyrir hafa, asked in what money he wished to be paid.
f. a fine of an eyrir.
n. a bargain to the amount of an eyrir.

(acc. -skáan), a. galloping over the gravel banks.
a. compar. more eastern; hit eystra, the eastern way.
a. pertaining to the Orkneys, from the Orkneys.
(for ‘ey vættar’), adv. not, not at all.
1) to make empty (auðr), clear of, deprive of its contents (~ allan fjörðinn bæði at mönnum ok fé); ~ bygð (bœi ok borgir, heröð), to desolate, lay waste;
2) to desert, depart from (féllu sumir, en sumir eyddu hálfrýmin); ~ veizluna, to break up the feast; ~ þing, to dissolve the meeting;
3) to do away with, destroy, with dat. (eyddi eldr konum ok börnum);
5) to render void in law, annul, with acc. or dat. (~ vígsmál or vígsmálum);
6) refl., eyðast, to come to nought; eyddist erfisgørðin fyrir honum, he let the funeral feast drop.
n. waste or ruinous state; leggja í ~, to lay waste; vera (liggja) í ~, to be deserted or ruined.
n. a sea whose coasts are desolate.
2) sad, cheerless (mér sýnist siðr þeirra veikligr ok ~).
m. the rivet in a clasp knife.
1) nature; manns ~, mannligt ~, human nature; arnar ~, the eagle’s nature; þat er í móti náttúrligu ~, it is against the order of nature;
2) origin, extraction (hann var valskr at ætt ok ~);
1) or; fyrr eða siðar, sooner or later; annathvárt … eða, either … or; hvárt … eða, whether (if) … or; hvart er … eða, whether … or;
2) in comparison of two unlike things, and (mikinn mun eigum vér at gera þin eða annarra heimamanna);
3) after a comparative, and perhaps (ek em eigi verri riddari en S. konungr, eða nökkuru betri);
4) introducing a question, but (ek beiti Auðgisl, — eða ertu H. vandræðaskáld?);

1) shower of rain, snow or hail;

nom. pl. to þú, ye, = þér.

(fögr, fagrt; comp. fegri), a. fair, fine, beautiful; f. sýnum, álitum, fair to see; fagrt veðr, fair (fine) weather; f. söngr, beautiful (sweet) song; fagrt kvæði, a fine poem; talaði fagrt, en hugði flátt, spoke fair, but thought else.

(feld; félt, féldura; faldinn), v. to array with a woman’s hood (f. e-n or e-m e-u, or með or við e-u); f. sik motri, með or við motri, to hood oneself with a motr; Brandr var faldinn, Brand had on a woman’s headgear; hjálmi faldinn, wearing a helmet.

1) fall; f. er fararheill a fall bodes a lucky journy; koma e-m til falls, to cause one to fall; föll berast á e-n, one begins to reel or stagger;

7) downfall, ruin, decay; f. engla, the fall of angels; gózin eru at falli komin, the estates are dilapidated;

refl., láta ~st (= sik ~), to let oneself fall (þá lét Loki ~ í kné Skaða);
2) to drop down dead, be killed, fall (in battle);

a. for sale, to be sold; eiga (hafa, láta) falt, to have a thing for sale; mér eru e-t fait, I am willing to part with; þeir er mér eru falastir til þungs hlutar, whom I would most willingly let suffer.

with the road in acc. (~ fjöll ok dala);

5) of time, hversu er f. orðit, how late is it, what time is it? f. orðit dags, late in the day.

adv. only in the phrase, svá f. er, so far; esp., svá f. er, not until, not before, only when; seg þú svá f. frá því, er þessi dagr er allr, wait till this day is past before you speak of that; svá f. ef, in case that.

(frýs; fraus, frusum; frosinn; also freri or frøri, frerinn or frørinn), v. to freeze, esp. impers., fraus um hann klæðin (acc.), the clothes froze on his body; fraus inni skip (acc.) Erlings, Erling’s ships were frozen in; veðr var kalt ok ~nda, cold and frosty; frýss haf allt optliga á vetrum, the whole sea often freezes in winter.
~ var veðrs, it was frosty weather;
in pl., ~ mikil ok kuldar, much frost and cold;

m. one making a first visit.
f. the foremost rhyming syllable in a line.
skamt ~ ánni, a short distance from the river;

gera sik auðkendan ~ öðrum mönnum, to make oneself conspicuous;

a. knowing, learned, well-informed (hón var fróð at mörgu); fróðar bœkr, instructive books.

(gen. frú, pl. frúr), f. mistress, lady (= freyja).

a. superl. the first, foremost; hinn fyrra hlut vetrar, in the early part of the winter; hit fyrra sumar, the summer before last; yðrir fyrri frændr, your ancestors; verða fyrri til e-s, at e-u, to be the first to do a thing; eigi fellr tré við hit fyrsta högg, a tree does not fall at the first blow.
1) to grasp with the hands, get hold of;
hón hefir fengit einn stein, she has taken a stone;
sá fær er frjár, he that woos wins;
fá fljóðs ást to win a woman’s love;
hann bað konunnar ok fekk heitit hennar, he asked the woman in marriage and got the promise of her hand;
fá sitt eyrindi, to accomplish one’s errand;
fá haærra hlut, to get the better of it;
fá góðar viðtökur, to get a good reception;
fá skilning á e-u, to get knowledge of;
fá úvit, to fall senseless, to faint;
fá bana, to come by one’s death;
hann fekk sér gott kvánfang, he got a good wife;
6) to give, deliver to one, put into one’s hands;
fá mér (give me) leppa tvá ór hári þinu;
fáit nú konungi festu (give the king bail) þá er honum líki;
fá e-m sök, to charge one;
var sá sveinn fenginn í hendr okkr, delivered into our hands;
fá e-m e-t at geyma, to give a thing into one’s charge (= fá e-m e-t til geymslu);
7) with pp. following, to be able to;
fá e-n veiddan, to be able to catch one;
hon fœr með engu móti vakit þá, she could by no means awaken them;
þeir munu mik aldri fá sótt, they will never be able to overcome me;
fengu þeir honum ekki nát, they could not catch him: skaltu hvergi fá undan hokat, thou shall have no chance of sneaking away;
hann fekk þó eigi víss orðit, he could not make out for certain;
8) with gen., to get, take, gain, win;
þeir fengu fjár mikils, they took a rich booty;
vel er þess fengit, it is well earned, well done;
hann var eigi skáld, ok hann hafði ei þeirrar listar fengit, he had not received that gift: fá verðar, to take a meal;
hann tekk sér sveitar (he raised a band) ok gørðist illvirki;
fá konu, to get a wife, marry (hon var átján vetra, er þorsteinn fekk hennar);
9) to conceive, of sheep and cattle (fá burðar, lambs);
þat fekk mikils hinum hertekna manni, it touched the captive deeply, þá fær þorbirni svá. mjök (Th. was so much moved), at hann grætr;
11) impers., one can get or find;
vápn svá góð, at eigi fær önnur slík, that the like are not to be got;
at varla fái vitrara mann, that a wiser man is hardly to be found;
also, one may or can (do something);
þat skip fær vel varit eldi, that ship can well be guarded against fire;
fá af sér (with infin.) to bring oneself to;
þeir fengu af verra, they got the worse of it;
fá at veizlu, brúkaupi, blóti, to get provisions for a feast (hann fekk at blóti miklu);
sá dagr er at jólum skal fá, the day when preparations are to be made for Yule (cf. atfangadagr);
fá á e-u, to get hold of, grasp with the hand;
faðir Móða fekk á þremi, the father of M. caught hold of the brim;
fá e-n, to touch, affect one, move (opt fá á horskan lostfagrir, litir);
láta e-t á sik fá, to be (deeply) affected by, take it to heart;
drykkr fær á e-n, the drink intoxicates one (er drykkr fekk á Hákon jarl);
fá í e-t, to take hold of, grasp with the hand (= fá á e-u);
forðuðu fingrum, fengu í snœri, they took hold of the strings;
fá e-t or e-s til, to get, procure (var kirkja gör ok kennimanna til fengit);

1) to hurl, with dat. (h. e-m til helvítis);

1) to drive away, chase off (h. e-n af máli);

1) to push, thrust, with dat. (hann hratt hestinum í vök eina); var þá hrundit hátnum, the ship’s boat was put out; h. hurð (upp), to push the door open; h. e-m í myrkvastofu, to cast into prison; h. á braut, to drive away; h. skipi fram or út, to launch a ship; impers., hratt stundum fyrir, en stundum frá, the clouds were drifting on and off (the moon);
2) to cast (throw) off (h. harmi, ótta); h. máli, to make a case void, clear oneself of it; h. e-u af e-m, to free one from, rid one of a thing.
(að), v. to furnish with a ring.
(-da, -dr), v. to encircle, surround; h. e-u um e-n, to encircle with (cf. kringja um, urnkringja).

1) ring, circle; slá hring um e-n, to make a ring around one; í hring, in a circle; hann fór í hring um skipit, he swam in a circle round the ship; með hringum, all around, altogether (brendu upp bœinn Með hringum);
2) ring (on the finger or arm, at the end of a chest, in a door, at the end of the hilt); link (in a chain).
pp. ‘ring-mounted’; málmr ~, a sword with rings.
(-Sta, -str), v. to shake (h. höfuðit); h. e-t af sér, to shake it off; marir hristust, the horses shook their manes; þeim hristust tennr í höfði, the teeth chattered in their head.
(hrjái, hrjáða, hrjáðr), v. to vex, harass (a person).
(hrýss, hraus, hrosit), v., only in the phrase, hrýss mér hugr við, I shudder with horror (ávalt hrýss mér hugr við, er ek sé þik).

1) to fall, fly, be flung (øxin hraut ór hendi honum); hraut upp hurðin, the door was flung open; eldr hraut ór hlunnunum, fire sprang from the rollers; ~ spœnirnir upp í móti honum, the chips flew up into his face; h. í sundr, to be snapped asunder (í sundur hrutu baugar);
2) to snore (hann svaf ok hraut sterkliga).
2) to strip, disable, esp. a ship in a sea-fight (hann hrauð öll víkingaskipin);
3) impers., hrýðr e-u, it clears away; mun hroðit myrkvanum, the fog will have cleared away; hrauð upp ór honum miklu vatni, he brought up much water;
4) refl., hrauðsk ór skikkju, she threw off her mantle.

a. infirm, decrepit, staggering (h. í göngu).

f. affliction, grief, sorrow (mikil ~ ok hörmung).
(d), v. refl. to become old and infirm; hrymdr, infirm from age (h. bæði at sýn ok elli).

f. a kind of metre (having lines with four stresses).

a. moist, raw, of hides (nautshúð hráblaut).
1) raw, of meat or food (hrár fiskr, hrátt kjöt);
a. afraid (við e-t, of), frightened (at); vera h. um, at, to fear, be afraid, that.
(-ða, -t), v., h. um e-t, to bear with, tolerate; má ekki um þat h. lengr, it is no longer tolerable.
(-ta, -tr), v. to spit; h. e-u út, to spit out.
(að), v. to beat the loom with a weaver’s rod (hræll).
m. the light from decomposing matter.
n. the light from decomposing matter.

m. carrion-smell; stench of dead bodies.
refl., ~st e-t or við e-t, to be afraid of, to fear, dread.
~ við, to take hold, to grip (kasta akkerum, ok ~ þau við, um síðir);
impers., hríft við, it takes effect, it turns out well;
2) to scratch (hann lét ~ sér með kömbum).
2) the black soot on a kettle (ketil~).
1) to squeal (of swine); h. við, to neigh to a horse (of a mare in heat);

1) storm, esp. snowstorm; h. mikla gerði at þeim, laust á fyrir þeim h. mikilli, they were caught by a violent snow-storm;
2) attack, onset, in a battle (hörð, snörp h.);

3) a while; nökkura h., for a while; langa (litla) h., a long (little) while; þessar hríðir allar, all this while; um h., for a while (hann dvaldist þar um h.); um hríðir sakir = um ~; í hríðinni, immediately, at once (hann fór í hríðinni upp til Hofs); hríðum, frequently (stundum í Hvammi, en hríðum at Stað);
4) space, distance (var þó h. löng í millum).
a. indecl. killed by a snow-storm.
n. shed (under which ships are built or kept).
(gen. hrannar, pl. hrannir), f. wave; dat. pl., ~um, in heaps (drepr hann hirðmenn konungs niðr ~um).
m. ‘the swift one’, poet. name of fire.
1) to fall back, recoil, be repelled;
~ fyrir e-m, to give way before one (gekk konungr svá hart fram, at allt hrökk fyrir honum);

~ við, to stand at bay, make a stand (verðr Sigvaldi nú við at ~);
2) to curl, of hair (hann hafði gult hár, ok hrökk mjök);
1) ~ e-u um e-t, to lash (switch) with a thing;

to move from one’s place, to budge, stir (ek ætla héðan hvergi at ~st).
a. free from disturbance, quiet, peaceable (sjaldan mun hrœðulaust vera í þessu heraði).
1) to excogitate, think out (hugat hefi ek mér ráð);

f. care, concern (konungr bar hér mikla ~ fyrir).
2) h. e-m vel (lítt), well (ill) disposed towards one;
3) e-m er mest um e-t hugat, one has most at heart (Hafliði kvað þat sýnt, at henni var mest um hann hugat).
n. foreboding, anticipation, fancy (þat er nær mínu ~i, at).
pp. n., hafa e-t ~, to intend.
a. steadfast, fixed in one’s mind; e-m er e-t hugfast, one is bent on.

a. n., e-m verðr fátt, one loses heart.
n. change of mind; telja e-m ~, to persuade one to change his mind.
a., e-m er hughœgt, one feels at ease.
m. mind (= hugr); illum huga, with evil mind, ill, badly; hafa e-t í huga, to have in one’s mind, to think of; leiða e-t huga, to consider.
m. the wise raven of Odin.
(see leggja), v. to lay to mind, to reflect on.
pp. n., mér er eigi ~ at, I have no mind to.
(-dda, -ddr), v. to pay attention to, consider.
m. darling; (hann var ljúfi allra manna).
a. n., e-m er ~ = e-m er hughœgt.
(að), v. to please; e-m ~r e-t, one is pleased, satisfied with a thing; impers., mér ~r vel (illa) við e-n, I am pleased (displeased) with one;
í hug eða verki, in mind or act;
vera í hug e-m, to be in one’s mind;
koma e-m í hug, to come into one’s mind, occur to one;
ganga (líða, hverfa) e-m ór hug, to pass out of one’s memory, to be forgotten;
snúa hug sínum eptir (at, frá) e-u, to turn one’s mind after (to, from);
mæla um hug sér, to feign, dissemble;
orka tveggja huga um e-t, to be of two minds about a thing;
orkast hugar á e-t, to resolve;
ef þér lér nökkut tveggja huga um þetta, if thou be of two minds about the matter;
reynast hugi við, to make close acquaintance;
hugir þeirra fóru saman, they loved each other;
leggja hug á e-t, to lay to heart, take interest in;
leggja lítinn hug á e-t, to mind little, neglect;
leggja hug á konu, to fall in love with a woman;
mér leikr ~ á e-u, I long (wish) for a thing;
e-m rennr ~ til e-s, to have affection for one;
mér er engi ~ á at selja hann, I have no mind to sell him;
svá segir mér ~ um, I forebode;
hann kvað sér illa hug sagt hafa (he had evil forebodings) um hennar gjaforð;
mér býðr ~ um e-t, I anticipate (eptir gekk mér þat, er mér bauð ~ um);
mér býðr e-t í hug, it enters my mind, I think;
gøra sér í hug, to imagine;
~ ræðr hálfum sigri, a stout heart is half the battle;
herða huginn (hug sinn), to take heart, exert oneself.
f. clinch on a sword’s hilt.

(að), v. to think, think upon; ~t hefi ek kostinn, I have thought over the terms; ~ eptir um e-t, to consider; h. e-t fyrir sér, to ponder over, reflect upon; h. um e-t, to think about; h. sik um e-t, to take counsel with oneself about a thing, consider.
1) thought, thinking; bera h. fyrir e-u, to ponder over;
2) opinion (hér em ek í annari h.).
f. time for consideration or reflection.
m. time for consideration or reflection.
a. indecl. thoughtful, meditative, absent-minded (hann fór jafnan sem h. væri).
2) vera hugstœtt til e-s, to be opposed to one.
f. heartfelt affection; unna ~um, to love with all one’s heart.
f. interest, affection; leggja hugðu til e-s, to take interest in, feel affection for one (konungr leggr enga hugðu til hests síns); mæla, rœða af hugðu, to speak from one’s heart.
n. a matter which one has at heart.
a. endeared to one, after one’s heart (~ allri alþýðu).
m. mind, disposition, judgement (hefir þetta farit eptir hugþokka mínum).
a. n., e-m er ~, one is depressed.
1) cover, veil (mikil þoka ok h. liggr yfir eyju þeirri);
2) hiding, secrecy; drepa huldu á e-t, to hide, conceal a matter.
m. ‘hiding helmet’; bregða hulinshjálmi yfir e-n, to make one invisible.
m. ‘hiding helmet’; bregða huliðshjálmi yfir e-n, to make one invisible.
(gen. -s, pl. humrar), m. lobster; humra fjöll, waves (poet.).
(-s, -ar), m. dog, hound; vera ór hunda hljóði or hljóðum, to have made one’s escape.

(pl. hundruð), n. hundred; tírœtt h. = 100; tólfrœtt h. = 120; hundruðum, by (in) hundreds; as value, one hundred and twenty ells of the stuff wadmal; h. frítt, a hundred paid in cattle; tólf hundruð mórend, twelve hundred in dark-striped wadmal; ~ silfrs, ? the silver value of 120 ells (= 20 ounces).
n. broth made from a dog.
~ er aptr, the door is shut;
drepa á ~, to knock at the door.
n. the back of a door;
f. small hole in a door.
a cross-plank joining the boards of a door (þá boraði A. hurðarokann).
interj., to express shivering from cold.
f. whale pit (where blubber was kept).
(-s, -ar, and -ir), m. whale; skera hval, to flense a whale.
m. flensing (cutting up) of a whale.
(-s, -ar), m. grassy hollow or little vale (kaus hann sér bústað í hvammi einum).
1) where, in or at what place (h. vartu í nótt, eða h. er þitt heimili?); h. skulu vit á leita? where shall we search?;
2) where, to what place, whither (sé ek nú, h. sök horfir);
3) anywhere; hér framarr en h. annars staðar, here more than anywhere else;

4) in each place (urðu þrjú þing í hverjum fjórðungi ok skyldu þingnautar eiga hvar saksóknir saman); hér ok h., here and there, now here now there; víðast h., in most places, in most instances; h. sem, wherever (h. sem hann fór);

5) ever so, very; h. fjarri, ever so far, very far Off (ek ligg einn í húsi ok kerling mín, en h. fjarri öðrum mönnum); víðara h., ever so much farther (um allt Hálogaland ok þó víðara h.); h. meiri, ever more, much more (ek skal þó h. meiri stund á leggja).
n. disappearance (h. Iðunnar); rann hann þeim þar h., he ran out of their sight.
1) to be turned round; lét hann sér í hendi h. ker gullit, he rolled the gold cup round in his hand;
2) stroll about (fílamir ~ um skóginn); e-m ~r hugr, one’s mind wavers;
3) h. í milli, to stand between (in the way).
adv. in each (every) place, everywhere; h. er (or sem), wheresoever (h. er þú tekr land).
1) sharp, keen (h. knífr, hvössøxi, ~t vápn); pointed, tapering (h. hjálmr);
2) fig., of the intellect, keen (~t næmi); of the eyes or sight (hvöss augu, hvöss sjón);
3) sharp, acute; ~t hljód, a sharp sound;
4) of wind, sharp, fresh (h. byrr, ~t veðr, andviðri).
(old gen. hvess, dat. hví), neut. pron.

1) what (h. sýnist þér ráð?); h. er þér, Hjálmar? what is the matter with thee, H.?; expressing wonder, what sort of? (h. Øgmundr ertu?); with gen., h. er þat fira, flagða, drauma, fiska? what sort of men. witches, dreams, fishes? h. manna ertu? what sort of a man art thou?; with dat., hann spurði, h. mönnum þeir væri, what kind of men they were;
2) implying an answer in the negative, to what end? of what use? (h. skal rögum manni langt vápn?)
3) how, = hve, hversu; fréttir hann nú, h. liði bónorðs-málum, how the was going on;
1) each, every; h. at öðru, ‘each with the other’, everything; þat lið, er honum fylgdi, flýr sér hvat, scattered in all directions; h. bíðr sinnar stundar, there is a time for everything;
2) = hvatki, with the relat. part. ‘er (es)’ or ‘sem’; h. sem or h. es, whatsoever;
3) with compar., ever so much; hann var til hans h. betr en til sinna barna, he was ever so much kinder to him than to his own children.
1) to hasten, with dat., h. för sinni, h. ferðinni, to hasten one’s journey; h. göngunni, to quicken one’s pace; h. báli, to hurry on the bonfire;
2) absol., to hasten, speed (h. til skipa, h. heim).
acc. from hvatr, at a quick pace (ríða h.).
1) each thing, everything for itself (munu þér þá vita til hvers h. kemr);
2) with ‘er’; h. er (es), whatsoever (heill Atla, h. es þik dreymir).
a. quick, brisk; hvatligt lið, active troops.
a. active, brisk, vigorous (h. maðr, h. hugr); neut. ‘hvatt’ as adv. quickly (riða hvatt, sem hvatast).
(gen. hvers-, dat. hví-vetna), pron. n. anything whatever; vex þér ~ í augu, everything grows big in thy eyes; var Hrafn fyrir þeim í hvívetna, H. was superior in every respect.
a. rash, headlong, reckless (maðr hvatvíss ok óvitr).
1) whence; þóttist engi vita, h. veðr var á, whence (from what quarter) the wind blew, meðan ek veit eigi vist, h. G. hinn ríki stendr at, as long as I know not what side G. takes;

2) from wheresoever; h. sem, from what place or source soever; hann siglir h. sem á cr, he sails, whatever wind may blow; h. æfa, from every side (þustu þá borgarmenn h. æfa at þeim); on all sides; hann vann svá, at h. æfa vóru á honum hendrnar, he worked as if he had hands all over him.
dat. from the obsolete pron. ‘hvar’ = hverr;
1) to whom? (h. eru bekkir baugum sánir?);
2) to any (manni h., or manna h.) h. er (es), to whomsoever (orðstírr deyr aldregi ~, er sér góðan getr).
n. wheel; á hverfanda hveli, on it whirling wheel.
(-da, -dr), v. to upset, overturn, with dat. (hann hvelfdi nökkvanum undir sér); impers., skipinu hvelfdi, the ship capsized.
a. shrill, sharp in tone (h lúðr); hvell rödd, a clear voice; mæla. (tala) hátt ok hvellt, to speak loud and clearly.
1) to have a circular or rotatory motion, turn round (himinn hverfr);
with acc. of the place, himin ~ þau skulu hverjan dag, they shall wheel round the heaven every day, of the sun and moon;
2) to be lost to sight (~ at sýn); to disappear, vanish (~ af himni heiðar stjörnur);
e-m hverfr e-t, one loses a thing (Mávi hurfu sauðir nökkurir);
síðan hvarf hann þeim, he vanished out of their sight;
~ af at gera e-t, to leave off doing a thing;
aptr hverfr lygi, þá er sönnu mœtir, a lie recoils before the truth;
~ at e-m, to throng around one (þá hurfu þegar at honum allir ok fögnuðu honum);
~ at e-u, to turn to, to adopt (~ at e-u ráði);
~ frá e-u, to turn away from;
gørðu-t far festa, áðr þeir frá hyrfi, they did not moor the boat before they turned away; to leave off (nú skal þar til taka, sem fyrr var frá horfit);

~ til e-s, to turn (go) to one, or to a place (hlæjandi Guðrún hvarf til skemmu); esp. to go to one and take leave (Gunnar hverfr til allra manna, er hann er búinn); to fall to one’s lot, accrue to one (þótti stór heill til hans horfit hafa);
~ um e-t, to encircle, surround (~ um hodd goða);
~ undan e-m, to be withdrawn from, lost to one (hvarf ríki í Noregi undan Dana konungum);
1) to turn a thing (in a certain direction);
~ e-m hugi (acc. pl.), to change a person’s mind;
2) ~ e-u um e-t, to enclose with a thing;
vera hverfðr útan um e-t, to encircle a thing.
1) each, every one (hann lét sem hann eigi vissi, hvat h. talaði);
2) adding ‘er’ or ‘sem’, whosoever (h. er þá beiðir); hverngi veg sem (howsoever) hann vill svara.
1) nowhere (hann undi h.); h. annars staðar, nowhere else;

2) by no means, not at all; vil ek h. ara, I shall not go at all; vera h. fœrr, to be quite unable to go; h. nær, far from it (h. nær allir); with compar. (Bergr var þess h. fúsari); alls h., nowhere at all.
2) hot spring (~inn var bæði heitr ok djúpr); holtriða h., ‘rock-cauldron’, cave.

1) interrog., used both substantively and adjectively, who, which, what? hverjar ero þær meyjar? who are these maids? h. á hestinn? who owns the horse? h. er þessi maðr? who is this man? hvern enda? what end?

á ~, á hendr, against (lýsa vígi á ~ e-m);
snúa vanda á hendr e-m, to throw the responsibility on one;
fœrast e-t á hendr, to undertake;
ganga (drífa) á ~ e-m, to submit to one;
bjargast á sínar hendr, by one’s own handiwork;
selja, gefa, fá e-t í ~ (hendr) e-m, to give into one’s hands, hand over;
búa e-t í hendr e-m, to make it ready for one;
kalla til e-s í hendr e-m, to lay claim to a thing at the hands of another;
þá sömu nótt, er fór í ~, the following night;
veðr óx í ~, the wind rose higher and higher;
vera hœgt um ~, to be easy in hand;
til handa e-m, into one’s hands;
ganga til handa e-m, to put oneself in another’s hands, submit to him;
ef þat berr þér til handa, if it befalls thee;
þá skömrn kýs ek mér eigi til handa, I will not have that shame at my door;
biðja konu til handa e-m, on one’s behalf, for him;
2) the arm and hand, the arm (~in gekk af axlarliðnum; hann hefir á hœgri hendi hring fyrir ofan ölnboga);
var eigi djúpara en þeim tók undir hendr, the water just reached to their armpits;

1) to hit, with acc. (þeir hœfa aldri dýr); hann hœfði allt þat, er hann skaut til, he never missed his mark; h. til, to aim; svá hafði smiðrinn til hœft, so well had he aimed;

1) fitness; vera við e-s h., to fit one, be suitable, convenient (Hrútr fekk sér nú konu þá, er honum þótti við sitt h.);

(acc. -jan and -an), a. easy, convenient; ykkr er þat hœgst um hönd, it is most at hand for you; h. byrr, a gentle, fair wind; ekki var samlag þeirra hœgt, they were not on good terms; h. e-m or við e-n, gentle towards one.

2) hard, difficult, with gen.; illr viðr-eignar, ill to deal with;

temp. adv., pleonast. before a compar., hélt-a in lengr rúmi, he kept not his place longer, he ran away; mann in harðara = harðara mann, a hardier man; nema þú in snotrari sér, unless thou art wiser; né in heldr, neither; né hests in heldr, nor of his horse either; eigi in heldr ætla ek þat, neither do I think that.

1) in, into; ganga inn í búðina, to go into the booth; ganga inn, to go indoors (Njáll gekk ýmist út eða inn); kasta e-m (setja e-n) inn, to cast into prison; var þar glaumr mikill inn (in the house) at heyra; inn eptir firði, inwards along the firth;
2) denoting the situation of a place, = inni (varð Hálfdán bráðdauðr inn í þrándheimi);
3) innarr, more inward, farther in; innst, most inward, farthest in.
(in, it), def. art. the = hinn (hin, hit).
1) to perform (i. Íþrótt); hafði hann þá af hendi innt alla sætt sína, he had then fulfilled all the terms of his atonement;
2) to pay, discharge (i. gjald af hendi); hvat áttu mér illt at i., what evil hast thou to repay me?
3) to relate, tell (i. sín vandræði); innti orðstafi at eldi ljósum, she read out the letters by the light of the fire;
4) i. til e-s, to allude to, mention, speak of (þá skatta, sem nú mun ek til i.); i. upp, to sum up, expound (i. upp allan málavöxt);
5) refl., innast til um e-t, to discuss; inntust þeir til um kaupakosti, they discussed the bargain; innast orð við, to exchange words.
1) from within, from an inner part (reru þeir ~ í móti þeim); læsti hón loptinu i., she locked the door from the inside;

2) internally, within; gengu þeir um kirkjuna i., all around the inside of the church; rak þá síðan um haf i., all about the sea; fyrir i., prep. with acc. Inside of, within; fyrir i. stokk, in-doors;
3) prep. with gen. Within; i. lítils tíma, within a short time, presently; esp. in a great many adverbial compds.
a. n. accessible from within (~ var í fjósit).
adv. within the land, at home.
a. inward, interior; í ~i búðinni, in the inner (inmost) part of the booth.
a. wet within; hafa innanvátt, to have the sea washing over; þeir fengu mjök innanvátt, they had a wet passage.
adv. superl. farthest in, at thefurther end, = innst, see inn.
(-s, -ar), m. a man from the inner part of a fjord.
f. entrance; beiða e-n inngöngu, to ask one to be let in.
n. paying in, opp. to útgjald, outlay.
adv. in towards land; sigla innhallara, to stand nearer the shore.
adv. in-doors; úti ok i., out-doors and in-doors; brenna e-n i., to burn one to death in his house; hafa boð i., to hold a (wedding-) feast at one’s home.
n. abode, house, home; ná sínu i., to get home.
a. n., er engum manni ~, no one is allowed to enter.
1) coasting along, course along the shore;
a. compar. inner, inmost, interior, = iðri; fara hit innra (iðra), to go by the inner road.
m. pl. the inhabitants of the inner part of Thrandheim.
(að), v. to make one repent (eigi iðra mik mínar gørðir); impers. e-n iðrar e-s or eptir e-t, and refl., iðrast e-s, to repent of.
1) in, within; fela fé sitt í jörðu, to hide one’s money in the earth; fastir í vellinum, fast in the ground; vera í sveit, to live in a district; í öðrum löndum, in other lands;
2) with local names (í Orkneyjum, í Laxárdal, í Borgarfirði, etc.);
3) in a certain spot; í einum stað, í þeim (hverjum) stað, in one, that (every) place; standa í höggfœri, within sword’s reach;
4) in, among; í valnum, among the slain;
5) of clothes; vera í, to have on, wear (hann var í blám stakki, í litklæðum);
6) during, in; þenna vetr í jólum, during Yule; í sumri (hausti), this summer (autumn); í því bili, in that moment; í því er Gunnar stendr upp, at the very moment when G. rises;

7) denoting action, state, condition; vera í för með e-m, to travel in one’s company; vera í víkingu, to be engaged in freebooting; í trausti e-s, in his trust, under his protection; vera í góðu yfirlæti, to be in good quarters, live well; liggja í úviti, to lie in a swoon; vera í góðu (illu) skapi, to be in good (ill) humour;
8) in respect of, in regard to; roskinn í orðum, mature in words; léttr í máli, cheerful in speech; í öllum mannraunum, in all trials;

9) denoting form or content, in; at eigi hafi komit til Noregs meiri gørsemi í skikkju, such a jewel of a cloak; fé er í því there is value in it; Hallr kvað góðan kost í henni, H. said she was a good match; hvat er íþví? how is that? what is the matter?
10) by means of, through (opt kaupir sér í litlu lof);
11) equivalent to a gen. or poss. pron.; hann braut hrygg í henni, he broke her back; hann knýtir saman alla halana í nautunum, all the cows’ tails;

1) in, into (spjótit fló niðr í völlinn); leggja e-t í kistu, to put into a chest (coffin); steinninn kom í höfuð honum, the stone hit him in the head; sigla (láta) í haf, to stand out to sea; var þat sagt Gunnari inn í búðina, word was carried into the booth to Gunnar; giptast í önnur lönd, to marry into other countries, marry an alien; deyja Mælifell, to pass into M. after death; þórðr svaf ok horfði í lopt upp, with his face turned upwards;
2) of time; in, during; í þat mund, at that hour; í nótt, this night; í vetr, this winter; í (= um) fjórtán vetr, for fourteen winters;

3) denoting entrance into a state, condition, in, into; ganga íbönd ok eiða, to enter into bonds and oaths; falla í úvit, to fall into a swoom; taka e-n í frið, to pardon one; bjóða búum í setu, to call on the neighbours to take their seats;
4) denoting change into; skjöldrinn klofnaði í tvá hluti, split in two; brotna í spán, to be shivered to pieces; verja fé sínu í lausaeyri, to convert one’s property into movables;

5) denoting the object, purpose, etc.; gjalda í sonarbœtr, to pay as the son’s weregild; þiggja e-t vingjafir, to accept as a friend’s gift; kaupa e-t í skuld, to buy on credit; gøra e-t í hag (vil) e-m, to do something in one’s favour.
prep. with dat., against (í gegn vindi sem forvindis);
2) adv., allan dag í gegnum, all the day long.

f. = ívera; hús til ~ar, a house to dwell in.

2) equal, the same; þínar (viz. ferðir) verða flestar jafnastar, thy doings are mostly the same, all equally bad; hann var ellefu vetra ok sterkr at jöfnum aldri, and strong for his age; jafn e-m, equal to one; jafnt er sem þér sýnist, af er fótrinn, it is just as it appears to thee, the leg is off; komast til jafns við e-n, hafa e-t til jafns við e-n, to equal one, be one’s match in a thing; at jöfnu, equally, in equal shares.
in compds., such a, so… a, equally, as; er þat skömm j.-mörgum mönnum, it is a shame for so many men; j.-frægr drengr, so fine a fellow; j.-auðveldr, as easy.
1) to cut even, to trim (mörum sínum mön ~ði);
3) to divide in equal shares (j. ríki með sér);
4) j. e-u til e-s, við e-t, to compare (liken) one thing with (to) another; j. e-u saman, to compare, set of one thing against another (var þá ~t saman vígum);
5) refl., ~st við e-n, ~st e-m, to even oneself with, call oneself a match for, another; j. orðum við e-n, to bandy words with one.
f. level ground, plain (hann flýði af hálsinum ofan á jöfnu).
a. indecl. of the same age.
m. one of the same age (þeir váru mjök jafnaldrar).
m. fair judgement; leggja mál til jafnaðardóms, to put a case before an umpire.
m. a meeting on equal terms.
2) equal share (en þaðan af höfum vit jafnað báðir); at jafnaði, in equal proportions (skipta e-u at jafnaði); usually, as a rule (= með jafnaði);
(see bjóða), v. to be equal to, be a match for one (e-m).
pp. of equal birth; ~ til e-s having equal birthright to (~ til ríkis sem ek).
n. equal length of day and night, equinox.
1) equally forward, side by side, with (leggr fram skeiðina ~ skipi Hrúts); evenly, in a straight line (standa allir ~ fyrir konungsborðinu);
2) at the same time (þeir riðutil þings ~ Skeggja).
adv. equally, in the same degree, = jafnfram.
adv. on equal footing (standa ~ e-m, við e-n).
prep. with dat. just opposite to.
1) equalness; mæla til jafna (= til jafns) við e-n, to speak just as well as another;
pp. on even terms; with equal title (jafnkomnir til erfðar); neut., jafnkomit er á með ykkr, you are well matched.
a. as strait, as narrow; í jafnkrappan stað, in such a strait.
n. a level piece of ground.
f. the same time of the following day (til ~ar annars dags); the same day in the next year, anniversary (eigi síðarr en fyrir ~).
a. indecl. with an equal number of men.
a. as active in wielding arms.
adv. immediately, at once; ~ sem, as soon as.
adv. at the very same moment; allir ~, all at the same time.

1) just, precisely (þat var j. jólaaptan sjálfan, er þeir börðust);
pp. n. with an equal number slain on both sides.

(-ða, -t), v. to equal, match, with dat.
(-ða, -ðr), v. to bandy words with one (e-n).
1) to harp on one string; j. ávallt á enni sömu sök, to be always harping on the same case;

hafa e-t til ~a, to use as a token or evidence;
vera til ~a, to serve as a token;
n. strength of the earth (sá var aukinn jarðarmegni or jarðarmagni).

(-s, -ar), m. jaw-tooth, grinder, molar (tennrnar ok jaxlarnir).

(-dda, -ddr), v. to say yes to, with dat.

1) iron (hagr á j.); bera j., to carry hot iron (as an ordeal);
2) in pl. irons, fetters (setja e-n í j., sitja íjárnum); iron hinges (lék þar grind ájárnum); horse-shoes.
2) to shoe a horse (hestr ~ðr öllum fótum).

pp. mounted with iron (= járni varðr).
f. pl. iron withes, iron wire.
f. confession (j. heilagrar trúar, j. synda).
a. indecl. saying yes; verða e-m e-s j., to promise one a thing.
1) to say yes to, with dat. (þessu játar or játir hann);
2) to acknowledge, admit (erkibiskup hafði því játat, at);
3) to consent; mun ek þessu j. fyrir mik ok mína heimamenn, I will agree to this for myself and my household; j. e-u undan sér, j. e-u upp, to yield up;
4) to promise (konungr játaði þeim griðum ok sættum);

5) with acc. of the thing, to acknowledge (j. syndir); to grant, give (játtuðu allir þér konungdóm); with acc. of the person; fyr engan mun játum vér hann guð, by no means do we acknowledge him to be God; j. sik, to confess oneself; j. sik undir e-t, to engage oneself;
6) refl., játast undir e-t, játast til e-s, = játa sik undir e-t.
n. consent; leggja sitt ~ til, to give consent.
n. pl. Yule, a great midwinter feast in the heathen time, afterwards applied to Christmas.
m. pl. the Vikings of Jom (Wollin in Pomerania).
f. St. John Baptist’s day, the 24th of June.
(gen. jós; pl. jóar, acc. jóa and jói, dat. jóm), m. poet. stallion, steed.

(gen. -s, dat. jötni; pl. jötnar), m. giant; jötna synir, sons of giants.

fær hann annat ~ at öðru, he gets one plunge after another;

4) to bury, lead to the grave (Steinarr leiddi hann uppi í holtum).

1) levy, esp. by sea (including men, ships and money); bjóða út ~i, to levy men and ships for war (bjóða út ~i at mönnum ok vistum); hafa ~ úti, to make a sea expedition;

1) to land, with dat. (l. báti, skipi);

pp. sprung from the landed gentry.
1) landed; l. maðr, ‘landed-man’, holding land or emoluments from the king;
f. length (of space and time); til ~ar, long, for a long time; nú (or í bráð) ok ~ar, for now and hereafter.
(lengr, lengst), adv. long, for a long time; of l., too long; lengr en skemr, rather long than short, for a good while; with gen., l. vetrar, for a great part of the winter.
f. lengthening; lífs l., maintenance of life.

(-da, -dr), v. to lengthen (l. líf sitt); var lengt nafn hans, an addition was made to his name; hvat þarf þat l., what need to make a long story?; impers. to become longer (um vetrinn er daga lengdi).
adv. compar. to a greater length; farther, further.
adv. compar. longer, farther; for a longer time.
adv. superl. mostly, most of the time (hann var þó l. á Grjótá).

1) to pick up, gather (l. hnetr, ber, aldin); l. saman, to gather, glean (l. saman axhelmur); l. upp, to pick up;
2) to grasp, catch (eldrinn las skjótt tróðviðinn); l. sik upp, to haul oneself up (hann las sik skjótt upp eptir øxarskaptinu);
4) to read (l. á bók); l. fram, l. upp, to read aloud; l. um (of) e-n, to speak (evil) of one (l. fár um e-n).
(-sta, -str), v. to injure, damage (l. skip sitt);
refl., ~st, to be injured, damaged (féll hann af baki ok lestist fótr hans).
I) adv., only in the phrase, á ~, last, at last.
(let; latta, lóttum; lattr), v. to hold back, dissuade (one from something), l. e-n e-s (Björn latti ferðar; konungr fór eigi at síðr);
refl., ~st, to become loth, unwilling (þrællinn tók at l. mjök á starfanum).
1) to give leave to, allow, permit (leyfi þér honum at fara sem honum gegnir bezt);
1) to hide, conceal; l. e-n e-u, to hide, conceal a thing from one;
2) refl., ~st, to hide oneself, be concealed; l. at e-m, to steal upon a person, attack by stealth; l. í brott, to steal away.
f. secrecy, concealment, hiding; með l., af l., secretly.
1) to loose, loosen, untie, undo (tók Skrýmir ok leysti nest-bagga sinn); l. knút, to undo a knot;
2) impers. is dissolved, breaks up (skipit leysi undir þeim); snjó, ís leysir, the snow thaws, the ice breaks up; árnar (vötn) leysir or ísa leysir af vötnum, the ice breaks up on the rivers;
3) to absolve (biskup sagðist eigi mega leyas þá);
4) to free, set free, release (l. e-n ór ánauð, af þræildómi);
5) to discharge, pay (bœndr hetu jarli stórfé at l. þat gjald, er á var kveðit);
6) l. or l. af hendi, to perform, do (vel hefir þú leyst þitt erendi);
7) to redeem, purchase (vil ek l. landit til mín);
8) to solve (a difficulty); hann leysti hvers manns vandræði, he helped every man in distress;
9) to send away, dismiss (Oddr leysir menn þaðan með góðum gjöfum);
10) to get rid of, dispatch (seint sœkist várum félaga at l. þenna úkunna mann);

11) with preps. and advs., l. e-n brott, to dismiss (leysti Ásmundr hann brott með góðum gjöfum); l. e-n frá e-u, to rid one of a thing; l. ór e-u, to solve, explain, answer (K. leysti ór því öllu froðliga, sem hann spurði); l. e-t sundr, to dissolve; l. e-n undan e-u to release from, aquit of; l. e-n út to redeem (má vera, at þú náir at l. hann út héðan); to dismiss guests (leysti konungr þá út með sœmiligum gjöfum); to pay out (leysit Höskuldr út fé hans);

12) refl. ~st, to decompose (tók hold þeirra at þrútna ok l. af kulda); to absent oneself (leystist þú svá hédan næstum, at þér var engi ván lífs af mér); fig. to get oneself clear (megu vér eigi annat ætla, en ~st af nökkuru eptir slfk stórvirki).
1) to be left (er þriðjungr lifði nætr); meðan öld lifir, while the world stands;

2) to live; meðan hann lifði, while he lived; at sér lifanda, in his life-time; lifa eptir e-n, to survive one (verðr maðr eptir annan at l.); l. við e-t, to live on, feed on (þeir lifðu nú við reka ok smádýri);
3) to burn, of fire (lifði þar eldr í skála).
adv. alive; vera l. = vera lífs, á lífi.
2) to come to life, revive (konungr hugði, at hón mundi l.).
a. endowed with life, living; betra er lifðum en sé úlifðum, better to be living than lifeless.
1) to lie (ör liggr þar úti á vegginum);
~ sjúkr, to lie sick (hann liggr sjúkr heima);
þeir lágu í sárum, they lay ill of their wounds;
3) to lie at anchor (hann lagði til hafnar ok lá þþþþþþar um hríð);
4) to lie, be situated, of a place (þorp ok borgir, er lágu við ríki hans);
5) to lie, go, lead, of a road (liggr gata til bœjarins);
6) to be covered with ice, ice-bound (vetrar-ríki var á mikit ok lágu firðir allir);
7) to lie with, have sexual intercourse with, = ~ hjá konu;
~ á e-m, to lie heavy on, weigh upon, oppress (~ á mér hugir stórra manna);
~ á hálsi e-m, to hang on one’s neck, blame one;
~ á e-m, to be fated to one (þat lá á konungi, at hann skyldi eigi lifa um tíu vetr);
~ á e-u, to attend, be connected with (á þessum ráðum ~ stórmeinbugir);
to be urgent, of importance, pressing (A. kvað honum eigi á ~ þat at vita);
liggr honum ekki á, it does not matter to him;
~ á úknyttum, to pursue wicked courses;
~ eptir, to be left undone (skal ekki eptir ~ þat, sem vér megum þeim veita);
~ fyrir e-m, to lie in wait for;
~ fyrir, to be in store for, or open to, one;
þœtti mér þat ráð fyrir ~, at þú sendir menn, that the best thing would be to send men;
~ hjá e-rri, to lie with (lá ek hjá dóttur þinni);
~ í e-u, to stick or sink in (lágu hestarnir á kafi í snjónum);
~ í, to stick fast in mire or bog (liggr í hestrinn undir þeim);
~ í hernaði, víkingu, to be engaged in warfare;
~ niðri, to lie untold (nú skal þat eigi niðri ~, er honum er þó mest vegsemd í);
~ saman, to be adjacent (lágu saman skógar þeirra Lopts);
~ til e-s, to belong to (naut ok sauðir, lá þat til Atleyjar);
bœtr ~ til alls, there is atonement for every case;
to be due or proper (þótti þat til ~ at taka af honum tignina);
~ til byrjar, to lie by for a fair wind;
~ til hafs, to lie ready for sea (lá biskup til hafs sex vikur);
~ um e-n, to lie in wait for;
~ um e-t, to be bent upon (hann liggr um þat nótt ok dag at veita yðr líflát);
~ undir e-n or e-m, to be subject to, belong to (þessi lönd ~ undir Danakonung);
hlutr e-s liggr undir, one is worsted;
~ úti, to lie out, not in a house (sumir lágu úti á fjöllum með bú sín);
~ við, to lie at stake (líf mitt liggr við);
þá muntu bezt gefast, er mest liggr við, when the need is greatest;
e-m liggr við e-u, one is on the verge of;
mörgum lá við bana, many lay at death’s door;
lá við sjálft, at, ti was just on the point of.
f. pl. branches (þeir höfðu fest skjöldu sína í ~).
2) limbed; l. mjök, large-limbed; l. vel, having shapely limbs.
