4) refl., linast, to be softened, give way (þá linuðust hugir þeirra).
f. source, spring; lindar logi, gold (poet.).
(-ta, -t), v. to cease, stop (l. ferðinni); impers., e-u linnir, it ceases, abates (en er því linnti, greiða þeir atróðr sinn).

3) agreeable, pleasant; faðmast lint, to embrace softly.
1) art, craft (margar listir þær, sem áðr höfðu eigi fundnar verit);
2) skill, adroitness, dexterity (lék hann marga íþróttliga fimleika með mikilli l.).

1) colour, hue; bregða lit, to change colour; blár (grár, hvítr, rauðr) at lit, blue (grey, white, red) of colour;
2) the colour of the sky, at dawn or dusk; en er þeir kómu upp á heiðina, kenndu þeir, at lit brá, they saw the day break; þá tók at kenna annars litar, then it began to grow dusk;
þeir vóru allir eins liðs, they were all of one party;
vera einn sins liðs, to be alone;
2) family, household (lið mitt er heima bjarglaust);
koma e-m at liði, to come to one’s assistance.

1) joint of the body (lið kalla menn þat á manni, er leggir mætast); fótrinn stökk or liði, the foot went out of joint; fœra (fót) í lið, to set in joint again;
2) hann var fölleitr ok l. á nefi, he was pale-looking and hook-nosed;
2) to further, with acc. (hefir hón því heitit at ~ þetta mál).
a. requiring many people (vér höfum skip mikit ok liðskylft).
n. pl. reward for help rendered.
adv. willingly, readily (gerði Þ. þat vel ok ~).
2) free, unhindered (skal Grettir fara l. þangat, sem hann vill);
1) l. e-m e-s or e-m e-t, to lend one a thing (muntu mér, Freyja, fjaðrhams ljá?; bað hann ljá sér skip);
2) to grant, give (vil ek, at þú ljáir mér tómstundar til at finna Gizur); l. sik til e-s, to lend oneself to a thing (ef hann vill sik til þess l. at gera yðr mein);
3) impers., þat má vera, (at) þér ljái þess hugar at hverfa aptr, may be thou art minded to return; ef þér lér tveggja huga um þetta mál, if thou art in two minds in this matter.
f. new-mown grass (kona hans rakaði ljá eptir honum).
dat. and acc. from lé, scythe.

m. louver or opening in the roof (for the smoke to escape by, and also for admitting light).
1) a burning light (þeir þóttust sjá fjögur ljós í hauginum brenna); kveikja l., to make a light;
2) light of the sun, etc. (hefir þat ljós af sólu); fig., láta e-t í ljós, to bring to light, reveal; koma í l., to come to light, appear;
3) world; í þvísa ljósi ok öðru, in this life and the next.
1) light, bright; l. dagr, a bright day; verða ljóst, to grow light, dawn;
2) bright, shining (hann hafði exi ljósa um öxl);
3) light-coloured, fair; l. á hár, light-haired, = ljóshárr; ljós vara, ermine;
4) clear, evident, plain (hitt er ljóst, at þeir muni vilja vera úvinir mínir); vil ek ljósan gera mik, I will speak out plainly, make a clean breast.

1) to strike, smite (laust hann sveininn með sprota); l. e-n kinnhest, to give one a box on the ear; hann lýstr ofan í miðjan hvirfil honum, he dealt him a blow in the middle of the crown; laust hann selinn í svima, he stunned the seal (by a blow on the head);
2) to strike, hit, with a spear, arrow (þá var Knútr lostinn öru til bana); Þjóstólfr skaut broddi, ok laust undir kverkina, and hit him under the chin;

3) phrases, l. árum í sjó, to dash the oars into the sea; l. eldi í, to put fire to; l. e-u upp, to spread a rumour (skal ek þá l. upp þeim kvitt, at); l. upp herópi, to raise the war-cry; l. e-u við e-u, to put forth in defiance against (E. laust skildinum við kesjunni); G. lýstr við atgeirinum, G. parries the blow with the bill;

4) impers. illviðri lýstr á, bad weather comes on of a sudden; laust í bardaga með þeim mikinn, it came to a great battle between them; laust hræzlu í hug þeim, they were panic-stricken; e-m lýstr saman, to come to blows, begin to fight; ok er saman laust liðinu, when they came to close fighting; myrkri lýstr yfir, darkness comes on suddenly.
a. ugly (Þ. var manna ljótastr); fátt mun ljótt á Baldri, on Balder there are few blemishes.
n. verse or stanza of a song (ljóð þau, er kallat er gróttasöngr); a ditty, a charm in verse; usually pl., also in names of poems, as Hyndluljóð, Sólarljóð.
(að), v. to make verses, sing; l. á e-n, to address one in verse.
m. pl. the people’s abode, world.
2) mild, gentle (hann var l. ok lítillátr við alla);
3) ljúft ok leitt, pleasant and unpleasant, weal and woe.
(lýg; laug or ló, lugum; loginn), v.

1) to lie, tell a lie (lýgr þú nú, Atli!); mannfýla sú, er þetta hefir logit, the rascal who has told this lie; l. e-n e-u, to charge one falsely with a thing (ef hann er loginn þessu máli); l. e-u at e-m, to tell a lie to one (eigi er logit at þér); l. á e-n, to tell lies about one, belie; l. til e-s, to tell a lie about (l. til faðernis);
2) to treat falsely; Brandr mun eigi ~ stefnuna, B. will not fail to come; lýgr skjöldrinn nú at mér, now the shield proves false to me, fails me;
3) refl., ~st, to fail, prove false or untrue (hefir yðr þat sjaldan logizt, er ek sagða).
a. false to one’s word (cf. ú~).
1) praise, good report (opt kaupir sér í litlu lof);
2) leave, permission (ef konungr vill þeim lof til gefa);
3) in pl. license; þeir skulu ráða lögum ok lofum, the administration rests with them.
1) to praise (lofa konung þenna, en lasta eigi aðra konunga);
3) to promise (hann lofaði at koma aptr).
a. eager for praise or renown.
m. poet. prince, king (þar átti ~ land á milli).
1) flame (kerti mjök mikit ok log á);
2) esp. pl. lights, torches (þrjú vóru log í skálanum).
(að), v. to burn with a flame, to blaze; hyr sé ek brenna, en hauðr l., I see the fire burning and the earth ablaze.
m. flame, blaze; brenna loga (dat.), to burn strongly, be ablaze; þá var enn l. á eldinum, the fire was still aflame.
n. calm (l. var veðrs); veðrit datt (féll) í l., it fell dead calm.
f. drift of snow in calm weather.
f., liggja í lognrett, to be becalmed or drifting slowly on the sea.
1) bolt (of a door); láta l. frá hurðu, to unbolt a door;
2) lock (en lyklar vóru settir í lokin);
4) locker or bench in the stern of a boat, = stafnlok (gekk biskup fram í lokit);
5) in pl. lockers; gullhringr hvarf frá husfreyju ór lokum; out of the lockers;

6) fig. in pl. end, conclusion; þat fylgir ljóða lokum, this is the end of my lay; fœra e-t til loka, to put an end to; liða undir l., to die, perish; at lokum, at last, = loks; til loks, to an end; completely, altogether.
n. a kind of fern or weed; ganga sem l. yfir akr, to spread like weeds over a field.

f. bolt of a door (hurðarloka); láta loku fyrir hurð, to bolt a door; spretta frá lokunni, láta loku frá hurð, to unbolt a door; margr seilist um hurð til lokunnar, many a man reaches far to get what is near at hand.
n. wainscot or panelling of a bed-closet.
(að), v. to allure, entice (Æsir lokkuðu Fenrisúlf til þess at leggja fjöturinn á hann); l. e-t af e-m, to coax or wheedle out of one (ef menn sitja um at l. af mér fé mitt).
m. a man with thick locks of hair.
(að), v. refl. to fall in locks (hárit lokkaðist ofan í herðar).
(að), v. to come to an end, drop (láta l. niðr mál).
n. a hole for a latch.

1) air, atmosphere, sky (skein sól, ok var lítt a l. komin); l. var mikit til jarðar at falla, it was a great height to fall down; l. ok lögr, sky and sea; á l., aloft, into the air; bera (fœra) á l., to spread abroad; hlaupa í l. upp, to leap up into the air; liggja í l. upp, to lie face uppermost; á lopti, aloft, in the air, on high; taka spjót á lopti, to catch a spear as it flies;

1) hairy, shaggy, woolly; ær loðnar ok lembdar, ewes in fleece and with lamb; l. sem selr, shaggy as a seal;

vera mikillar ~ar, to be of a proud mind;
á þá ~, á þessa ~, in this way, thus.

(-di, -t), v. impers. to become calm (lygndi veðrit).

1) to shut in, enclose, close; l. e-n í myrkvastofu, to shut one up in a dungeon;
2) to put an end to (hvatki er lífi hans hefir lukt).
f. loop, coil of a rope, etc. (hann hafði ok dregr á hönd sér); gera ~ á leiðinni, to put an end to one’s journey, to stop; coil of a serpent (ormr með lykkju mikilli ok breiðum sporði).

f. end, conclusion (sú varð l. á viðrskiptum þeirra, sem nú má heyra); esp. in pl., gøra (vinna) lyktir á e-u, to do, perform; koma málum til lykta, to bring a case to a final issue; leiða e-t til lykta, to bring to an end, finish; at lyktum, at last, finally (þó flýði hann at lyktum); þat verðr at lyktum, at, the end of it was, that.
(að), v. to bring to an end, finish; impers., ~r e-u, it ends.
(að), v. refl. to steal quietly, to sneak (fœrist hann á fœtr ok ~ fram at durunum).
a. tempered; illa l., bad-tempered, opp. to góð~.

(-pta, -ptr), v. to lift, raise, with dat. (síðan lypti hón kápuhetti hans ok sá í andlit honum); l. e-u upp, to lift up; l. ferð sinni, to start on a journey; impers., lyptir e-u, it is lifted up, raised; lypti þá mjök brúnum manna, their faces brightened;
refl., ~st, to move, stir (lézt hann ekki mundu þaðan l. fyrr en á bak jólum); lyptist þeim þá lítt reiði, their anger was raised a little.
f. raised deck (in the after-part of war-ships).
m. forelock; taka e-m lyrg, to take one by the forelock.

(-sti), v. impers., e-n lystir, one desires, wishes; lifði hverr sem lysti, every one lived just as he pleased; hann lysti at sjá Ísland, he wished to see Iceland; mik lystir til e-s, í e-t, I have a fancy to, a desire for (mik lysti í hring þenna).
a. desirous of, eager for (l. e-s); lyst várumk þess lengi, I have long wished for this.
(pl. lár), f. the line of shoal water along the shore.
f. the ‘low chant’ (in the Roman Catholic Mass).
m. the ‘low chant’ (in the Roman Catholic Mass).
1) low, low down (þá er sól er lág um kveldit); bera lágt höfuðit, to carry the head low, be discomfited; fara lægra, to be lowered, humbled;
2) short (höggspjót á lágu skafti), short of stature (lágr sem dvergr ok digr);
3) low, humble (lágr at burðum); bera lægra hlut, to get the worst of it, be worsted;
4) low, of the voice (hann svarar ok heldr lágt).
pp. speaking in a low voice.
1) loan; at láni, as a loan; hafa at láni, to get on credit;
2) fief; hafa at láni = hafa at léni.
(að), v. to lend (þetta er lánsfé, er ymsir menn hafa lánat mér).
m. liege-lord, lord, master (hann þótti vel hafa fylgt sínum lánardróttni).
hurðin var í lási, the door was locked.
2) death, decease (ek segi þér ~ Eyvindar bróður þíns);
3) in pl. manners; skipta litum ok ~um, to change colour and manners.
1) to set, put, place (~ hest á stali);
~ e-n í myrkvastofu, to thrust in prison (dungeon);
~ e-t í ljós, to make it known;
~ e-t af e-u, to take off (vóru þá látnir fjötrar af Hallfreði);
2) to cede, give up (hann vildi eigi ~ þenna best);
~ hlut sinn, to let go one’s share, be worsted;
3) to leave, forsake (biðr hann, at þeir láti blótin);
hann ætlaði at ~ dróttningina eina, he intended to divorce the queen;
4) to lose (hann hafði látit flest allt lið ok herfang allt);
5) with infin. to let, make, cause;
látit mik vita, let me know;
ek lét drepa Þóri, I made Th. to be killed;
~ sér fátt um finnast, to disapprove;
hann lét fallast (= sik falla), he let himself fall;
hann lét verða farit, he went;
hann lét hana verða tekna, he seized her;
ellipt., omitting the infin., ~ um mælt, to let be said, to declare;
hann lét harðan Hunding veginn, he slew the stark H.;
7) to behave, comport oneself (forvitni er mér á hversu þeir ~);
hann lét illa í svefni, he was restless in his sleep;
~ hljótt yfir e-u, to keep silence about a thing;
~ mikit um sik, to puff oneself up;
8) ~ sem to make as if (hann lætr sem hann sjái ekki sveinana);
9) to estimate, value (fátt er betr látit en efni eru til);
10) to express, say (Þorfinnr bóndi lét heimilt skyldu pat);
hátt kveði þér, en þó lét hærra atgeirrinn, you speak loud, but yet the bill gave a louder sound;
~ af e-u, to leave off, desist from (sumir létu af blótum);
~ af hendi, to let out of one’s hands, deliver up;
~ at e-u, to yield to, comply with (allir þeir, er at mínum orðum ~);
~ at stjórn, to obey the helm (of a ship);
~ e-t eptir, to leave behind (þeir létu menu eptir at gæta skipa);
~ eptir e-m, to mimic, ape (mun Gísli hafa látit eptir fíflinu);
~ e-t eptir e-m, to grant, indulge one in a thing (lát þú þetta eptir mér);
~ fyrir e-u, to give way, yield (þeir munu verða fyrir at ~, ef vér leggjum sköruliga at);
~ í haf, to put out to sea;
~ e-t í mót e-m, not to indulge one;
~ e-t til, to grant (heimt mun brátt hit meira, ef þetta er til látit);
~ til við e-n, to yield (give way) to one (þeir báðu hann til ~ við konung);
~ undan e-m, to yield to one (ek skal hvergi undan þér ~);
to let one get up (eptir þat lét K. þenna mann upp);
~ e-t uppi, to grant (ertu saklauss, ef þúlætr uppi vistina);
~ út (skip sitt), to put to sea (síðan létu þeir út ok sigldu til Noregs);
~ vel (illa) yfir e-u, to express approval (disapproval) of a thing (hann lætr vel yfir því);
v. refl. to die, perish (hér hefir látist Njáll ok Bergþóra ok synir þeirra allir);
to declare of oneself, profess, pretend (allir létust honum fylgja vilja).
2) vel ~, highly esteemed, in good repute;
(að), v. refl. to go to rest.
blanda lopt lævi, to poison the air;
biðja e-m læs, to wish one evil;
löngr eru lýða læ, the woes of men are long.
2) opportunity, fair wind (gaf þeim ekki l. út ór firðinum).
2) fig. to humble, bring down (hann drap þá, eða lægði þá á annan veg);

3) impers., lægir e-t, it is lowered, sinks; þeir sigldu svá, at lönd (acc.) lægði, they sailed so far that the land sank out of sight; þegar er sólina lægði, when the sun sank; of a storm, it abates (þá tók at l. veðrit);
4) refl., ~st, to fall, sink abate (vindar lægðust; af hans tilkvámu lægðist harkit).
a., eiga lægt at kirkju, to have a right to be buried at a church.

(-ða, -ðr), v. to teach (hann lærði Ara prest); lærast at e-m, to get information from a person.
pp. learned (vel. l. þegar á unga aldri); lærðir menn, clerics.
1) to lock, with dat.; læsti hón loptinu innan, she locked the room from the inside; kirkjur vóru allar læstar, all the churches were locked;

1) noise, cries (slík l. þóttist konungrinn eigi heyrt hafa);

1) fief, fee (halda lönd ok lén af konungi);

f. pad or cushion which is placed under a pack-saddle.
f. a turf cut with a scythe.
2) with dat. to lift (þá létti köttrinn einum fœti);

3) l. e-u, to desist from, leave off; l. ferð sinni, to stop one’s journey, to halt; also absol., þeir léttu eigi (they stopped not, halted not) fyrr en þeir kómu í Skaptártungur; l. af e-u, l. af at gøra e-t, to leave off doing, give up (hann léttir aldregi af slíkt at vinna); l. af hernaði, to leave off freebooting; l. undan, to withdraw, retreat (svá kom því máli, at Sigvaldi létti undan);
4) to relieve, ease (hann létti hans meini með mikilli íþrótt);

5) impers., e-m léttir, one is relieved, eased (of pain, illness); sótt (dat.) léttir, léttir af sóttinni, the illness (fever) abates; with the person in dat., the illness in gen. honum létti brátt sóttarinnar, he soon recovered from the illness; l. upp, to clear up, abate, esp. of the weather; storminum (hríðinni) léttir upp, the storm (snowstorm) abates;
6) refl., ~st, to be lightened, cleared, of the sky (hinn syðri hlutr léttist); impers., e-m léttist = e-m léttir, one is relieved, eased (léttist honum heldr, ok var á fótum þrjá daga).
2) readiness; af létta, readily, without reserve (hann sagði allt af létta).
2) readily, with good will (dróttning tók kveðju hans ~).
a. living an easy life (e-m er léttlíft).
2) active, nimble (l. á sér); vera á léttasta skeiði, to be at one’s most active age; ek em nú af léttasta skeiði, I am past my best years;
3) unencumbered, free; verða léttari (at barni), to be delivered of a child; e-m verðr harms síns léttara, one is eased of one’s grief;
4) light, easy (mœddist hann fyrir þeim ok gekk þeim léttara); var veðr létt, the wind was light;
5) cheerful, gladsome (var konungr þá l. í öllum rœðum); e-m segir eigi létt hugr um e-t, one has apprehensions;
6) of small value; leggja e-t í léttan stað, to think lightly of.
a.; e-m er léttvígt, one finds it easy to fight.

1) life; týna lífinu, to lose one’s life; taka (ráða) e-n af lífi, to take or put and end to one’s life; sitja um l. e-s, to attempt or seek one’s life; vera á lífi, to be alive, living; vera lífi minnr, to be dead; fyrir l. sitt, even if it should cost one’s life (þeir vilja ekki fyrir l. sitt frá hverfa); lífs, alive; lífs eða látinn, alive or dead; hvárki lífs né liðinn, lífs né dauða, neither alive nor dead;
2) body; lífs ok sálar, body and soul; esp. the waist, middle (hafði hann vafit klæðum um lífit);
3) person; at svá fagrt l. skyldi þann veg kveljast, that so fine a man should be tortured in that way.
(að), v. to call to life, revive.
m. preserver of a person’s life, rescuer.
m. preserver of a person’s life, rescuer.
f. granting life or pardon to one.
m. danger of life, extreme danger.

f. hope of saving one’s life.
a. n. permitted to live (er-at l. vinum Ingimundar).
a. with hope of life, with hope of recovery.
1) the living body (við þat l. at lifa);
2) the dead body, corpse (jarða l. e-s).

(að), v. to please, satisfy, with dat. (líkaði yðr vel Finnskattrinn?); hvárt er honum líkar vel eðr illa, whether he likes it or not; e-m líkar vel (illa) til e-s or við e-n, one likes or dislikes a person (honum líkaði til Sighvats vel); líkaði við hana ekki illa, they liked her well enough.
a. bodily, affecting the body (líkamlig heilsa); fleshly.
f. the conveyance of a body to church.
2) form, shape (hann brá á sik l. graðungs eins).

1) likelihood, probability; l. eru á e-u or til e-s, it is probable; vera (fara) at líkindum, to be (go) as might be expected; ráða (sjá) e-t at líkindum, to guess at a thing; frá líkindum, beyond likelihood, extraordinary (þótti honum frá líkindum, hversu þungr hann var); til líkinda við, in comparison with;
2) semblance, trace (um morguninn eptir sá engi l. Danavirkis).
f. shape, form (hann lét gera járnkróka í l. akkerisfleina).
(-ta, -tr), v. to make like; l. eptir e-m, to imitate;
refl., ~st e-m, to be like, resemble (l. í ætt e-s).
adv. favourably; taka (svara) e-u ~, to give a favourable answer to.
1) likely, probable (gør af drauminum slíkt er þér sýþnist líkligast); Þorsteini var þar vel fagnat, sem líkligt var, as might be expected; gøra sik líkligan til e-s, to show oneself inclined to;
2) eligible, preferable, suitable (nú þykkir Eyjúlfi þetta et líkligasta).
m. one who assist at a funeral, a coffin-bearer.
f. mercy, relief, comfort; veita e-m l., to relieve, soothe; hvat er til líkna lagt Sigurði, what comfort is assigned for S.?.
(að), v. to show mercy to, with dat. (hann ~r hvers manns máli);
refl., ~st við e-n, to sue one for mercy (ef ek skal til blóta hverfa ok l. við goðin).
1) like, resembling (fríðr sýnum ok mjök l. föður sínum); Kári er øngum manni l., K. has no match; líkt ok ekki, like nothing (Steinólfi þótti þat líkt ok ekki); at líku, all the same, nevertheless;
2) likely, probable (þat er ok líkast, at);
3) likely, promising, fit (lituðust þeir um, hvar líkast væri út at komast).
n. lime, mortar (var þat mikit musteri ok gört sterkliga at lími).
2) to glue (l. skegg við höku sér).
m. broom or rod of twigs.
2) linen, linen garment; ganga und líni, to be wedded.
1) to look; ok í augu leit, and looked him in the eyes;
2) to see, behold (Sölvi gat at l., hvar þeir flýðu);

3) with preps.. l. á e-t, to look on or at; to consider, take into consideration (hann kvazt mundu l. á slík mál); þótti Þrándr brátt hafa á litit, Th. was thought to have been hasty; l. á með e-m, to keep an eye on, take care of; l. til e-s, to look towards one; konungr leit ástaraugum til hennar, the king cast love glances at her; hver spurning lítr jafnan til svara, a question looks for an answer; l. við e-m, to look at one (keisari leit við honum ok spurði, hverr hann væri); l. yfir e-t, to look over (Þ. hafði litit yfir verk húskarla sinna);

4) refl., lízt e-m, it seems (appears) to one; leizt honum mærin fögr, he thought the maiden beautiful; svá lízt mér, sem, it seems to me that; lízt þér eigi silfrit, dost thou not like the silver?; hversu lízt þér á mey þessa, what dost thou think of this maiden?; leizt mér vel á konunginn, I was pleased with the king; recipr., to look to one another (fellst hvárt öðru vel í geð, ok litust þau vel til ok blíðliga).
a. weak, small, of little account.
a. n., e-m er ~ um e-t, one is not much pleased with.
1) little, small in size (lét hann læsa þá í ~i stofu); at ek var ekki l. maðr vexti, that I was not small of stature;

2) small in amount, degree, etc. (lítil var gleði manna at boðinu); sumar þetta var l. grasvöxtr, a small (bad) crop; landit er skarpt ok lítit matland, bad for foraging; hann er l. blótmaðr, no great worshipper; þat er lítit mál, that is a small matter; var hans móðerni lítit, of low rank; jarl hafði hann lengi lítinn mann gört, treated him shabbily; l. fyrir sér, of little account (þér munut kalla mik lítinn mann fyrir mér);
3) of time, short, brief; litla stund, for a short while; litlu siðarr, a little while after.
adv. little, in a small degree.
(-tta, -ttr), v., ~ sik, to humble oneself, condescend.
1) smallness of estate, opp. to greatness;
2) degradation (henni þótti sér ~ í því at smá-konungar báðu hennar);
3) trifle (þér væri ~ í at skipta höggum við Vatsdœli).
a. of little worth, insignificant (sýnist þér þat lítilsvert?).
a. of little weight or moment.

1) to go, pass, glide (er skipit leið fram hjá flotanum);
~ e-m ór hug, to pass out of one’s memory;

impers., en er líðr Euphrates á (acc.), when one has passed the E.;
sem leið jóladaginn, as the Yule-day passed;
þá (or þegar) er e-n líðr, when a person is omitted, passed over;

3) to pass away, elapse, of time (eigi munu margir vetur ~ áðr en þér munuð þessa iðrast);
at liðnum vetri, when the winter had passed;
at liðinn fylki, after my lord’s death;
4) impers. with dat., nú líðr, svá dögum, at, the days draw on;

ok sér, hvat leið drykkinum, and sees, how it had gone with his drinking;

at áliðnum vetri, towards the end of the winter;

m. pl. wayfarers (ok býðrat líðöndum löð).

1) law, laws (með ~um skal land byggja, en með ólögum eyða);
leggja ~ á e-t, to establish by law;

taka e-t í ~, to accept as law (fyrr en kristni væri í ~ tekin á Íslandi);

dœma e-m ~, to adjudge one’s case according to law;

ræna e-n ~um, to deprive one of law, to treat one unfairly;
segja or segja upp ~, to recite the law, say what is the law;

n. the law-rock (the place at the Alþingi where the laws were recited).

(gen. laggar), f. groove in the staves of a cask.

f. the ark of the covenant.
pp. prescribed in the law (öll lögmælt skil).

(gen. lagnar), f. a net laid in the sea, opp. to dragnet.

f. legal challenge (of neighbours or judges).

1) the legislature in the Icelandic Commonwealth; also the place where the legislative sittings were held; ganga til lögréttu, to proceed to the ~;

(að), v. refl. to puff oneself up (m. af mikillæti ríkis síns).
a. full of pride or ambition.
1) esteem, value (þann metnað hefi ek á ráðagerðum mínum, at);
2) honour, repute (hann var þar í miklum metnaði);
3) pride, ambition (m. honum þróast, en mannvit aldregi).
2) esteem, consideration; þeir gørðu svá mikil ~ hans, at, they paid him so much regard that; sitja yfir ~um manna, to bear down others.
m. man of distinction (hann var ~ mestr).
n. pl. matters relating to marriage.
1) with, along with, together with (Unnr dóttir hans fór með honum; hón hafði á skipi m. sér sex tigi karla);
2) denoting help, assistance; leggja til m. e-m, to help one by word or deed; to give one advice; fá menn m. sér, to get followers;
3) by means of, with (verja sik með sverðum, skjöldum);
4) by, through, with, using (með harðfengi ok kappi); m. hlaupi, by running; m. einum bug, with one mind; m. sama hætti, in the same way;
5) including, inclusive of (hundrað manna m. nábúum); ok þat m., at, and besides (therewith) that; þann dag ok nóttina m., and the night too;
6) among, between (var fact um m. þeim brœðrum); þreyta e-t m. sér, to fight it out among themselves; koma m. e-m, to come among (maðr, er m. mörgum kemr);
7) denoting inward quality, in (hann hafði alla þá hluti m. sér, er konung prýða);

8) along (landit er viðast bygt með sjónum); esp. of direction, with an adv. denoting the direction (upp ~, ofan ~, fram ~, inn ~, út ~, etc.); m. stöfnum, from stem to stern, all along the ship; biðja matar með bœjum, from house to house;
9) adverbial usages; m. öllu, altogether, quite; m. öllu skjótt, all of a sudden; m. því at, in case that (m. því at ek falla); as, because (m. því at menn vóru hraustir, þá komast þeir yfir ána);
10) with verbs; ganga m. barni, to go with child, mæla m., to recommend;

1) with, with the notion of bearing, bringing, carrying (hann fór til Íslands m. konu sína ok börn); fara m. vápn, to carry a weapon; fig., fara með sök, mál, to conduct, manage a case; m. engi lögskil, in no lawful manner;
2) with, among; úsnotr m., es m. aldir kemr, a fool when he comes among men;
3) with an ordinal number; m. tólfta mann, with twelve men, including himself; with eleven others.

(á m., í m.), prep. with gen., among, between; m. vár or vár á m., among us; sat þar Þórhalla m. brúða, Th. sat between the brides; ellipt., ganga ~, í m., to intercede as peacemaker (gekk þá Njáll í m., svá at hvárir handsöluðu ödrum grið).
m. what is given into the bargain.
m. middling destroyer (þeir sögðu þat eigi meðalfarbauta vera).
m. middling fiend (ek ætla hann eigi meðalfjánda vera).
m. ‘middle-piece’, the haft of a sword between the two ‘hjölt’.

n. average; þat var með enu betra ~i, a good average; í ~i, ~i, not very, not over well (segir mér þó í ~i hugr um); ~i góðgjarn, not too benevolent; skipti vár hafa verið sum góð, en sum til ~s, our dealings have been, some good, some only middling.
m. average man; ~ á vöxt, a middle-sized man.
f. common honour (er eigi ~ at eiga slíkan mann at mág).
1) in the mean time, meanwhile (hann bað þá þar dveljast m.); m. at, m. er (es), as long as, while, whilst;
2) so long as = m. er (hélzt hann í vináttu við konung m. hann lifði).
1) management; vandhœfi mun þér þykkja á ~inni, you will find it difficult to manage;
2) hafa e-t ~ar, to have along with one, in one’s keeping;
3) behaviour, conduct; var konungi þá kunnigt hverja ~ ek hafða, how I behaved.
1) great, tall, of stature (m. vexti, maðr m. ok sterkr);
2) great, large, in bulk or size (mikil ey ok góð); áin var mikil, the river was swollen;
3) of quantity, great, much (m. viðr, mikil drykkjuföng);
4) great, prominent (skörungr m., málafylgjumaðr m.); m. drykkjumaðr, a great drunkard; vetr m., a severe winter; með ~i snild, with great skill;
5) acc. ‘mikinn’ used as adv.; ríða (fara) m., to ride (go) fast; róa m., to pull hard;

6) neut. as subst., much; skipta miklu, to be of great importance; dat., ‘miklu’ with compar., much, by far (m. betr; m. meiri maðr en áðr); with superl., m. mestr, by far the greatest, the very greatest; neut. as adv., mikit, greatly, much, = mjök (hón unni honum m.).
1) to make great, increase, magnify; m. sik, to pride oneself;
2) impers., e-m ~r e-t, one wonders at (konungi ~r þat með sjálfum sér, at);
3) refl., ~st, to acquire fame (ef konungr vill m. af þessu); to pride oneself (engi maðr miklist eða stœrist af sinni ætt).
(-s, -ar), m., poet. a liberal man (örr maðr heitir m.).
1) between (m. skógarins ok árinnar); sín á (or í) m., between (among) themselves; sigla m. landa, from one land to another;

2) special usages; var enn meirr vönduð veizla en þess í m., more than otherwise; um aðra hluti var skamt m. máls konunga, in other things there was no great difference between them; standa í m., to stand between, hinder; mátti þar ekki í ~m sjá, hvárr af öðrum myndi bera, it could not be seen which of the two would get the better of it;
3) ellipt. in ‘~ ok’; upp með ánni, m. (viz. árinnar or hennar) ok skógarins, up along the river, between (it) and the forest.
f. pl. memorial, souvenir, keepsake (hann tók hringinn Draupni ok sendi Óðni til minja; þessa gripi skaltu eiga at minjum).
1) to remind of (m. e-n e-s or e-n á e-t); hón hefir mik minnt þeirra hluta, or minnt mik á þá hluti, she has reminded me of those things;
2) impers., mik minnir e-s, I remember, think of (ávallt er ek sé fagrar konur, þá minnir mik þessarrar konu);

3) refl., ~st e-s, to remember, call to mind (H. minntist þess, at A. hafði rænta ok barða húskarla hans); eigi væri allfjarri at m. þín í nökkuru, to remember thee with some small pittance, give thee some trifle; m. á e-t, to bear in mind, remember; þá munu vér m. á hinn forna fjándskap, then we will bear in mind the old feud; to mention, talk of (hann minntist þá á marga luti þá, er fyrr höfðu verit).
(t), v. refl. to kiss (m. við e-n or til e-s); hann spratt upp í móti honum ok minntist til hans, he rose and kissed him.
1) memory (hann missti ~s ok þótti nær sem vitstolinn) leggja e-t í m., to lay up in the mind; reka m. til e-s, to call to mind;
2) esp. in pl. memorials (slík m. hafa Íslendingar Haralds konungs ok mörg önnur); settir eptir (viz. dauða) bautasteinar til ~s, as a memorial;
3) memory, of past time; þeir er vóru fyrir várt m., who lived before we can remember;
4) memorial cup, toast (at old sacrifices and banquets); mæla fyrir minnum, to propose a toast.
a. compar., answering to lítill, less, smaller; least, smallest (var minna karp þitt, meðan H. konungr lifði); er sá kallaðr ~ maðr (lower in rank), er öðrum fóstrar barn.
n. mouth (of a river, fjord, valley), = mynni.
1) having a good memory (Hallr var maðr stórvitr ok m);
2) m. e-s, mindful of, bearing in mind (m. þeirra meingørða, er).
adv. in memory (at þau frægðar verk skyldu ~ haldast).
1) memory, recollection, remembrance; í m. e-s, in memory of (í hverja m. heldr þú þenna dag?);
2) in pl. traces (engar ~ar vóru eptir hans meina);
4) requital, revenge (þótti sjá m. betri en eigi);
5) admonition, foreboding (þessi m. varð náliga hverja nótt);
6) mention, suggestion, proposal (gørði G. þá m., at).
a. memorable, worth remembering (þat sýnist mönnum minningarvert).
a. memorable, not to be forgotten (mun þér þat minnisamt); gøra e-m hríð minnisama, to make one remember an attack.
a. memorable, not to be forgotten (mun þér þat minnisamt); gøra e-m hríð minnisama, to make one remember an attack.
f. a banquet where there are minni (toasts).
f. a drink to restore remembrance.
1) to lessen, diminish; fig., m. sik, virðing sína, to lower oneself; impers., ~r e-t, it abates, decreases (biðu þeir þess, er ~ði ísana);
3) refl., ~st, to grow less, decrease (þótti mér mikit vaxa mín virðing, en m. ekki).

adv. compar. less (þeir sem vitrari vóru ok m. drukknir); with dat., vetri m. en hálf-sextugr, fifty-four years old; vera lífi m., to be minus one’s life, lifeless, dead; engu m., no less; ~ en, less than.
adv. superl. least; m. mánað, at least a month.
a. superl., answering to lítill, less, smaller; least, smallest (var minna karp þitt, meðan H. konungr lifði); er sá kallaðr minni maðr (lower in rank), er öðrum fóstrar barn.
(older form miss), adv. amiss; so as to miss;
farast þeir hjá á mis, they pass each other without meeting.
(see bjóða), v. to offend; e-m þykkir sér misboðit í e-u, one feels offended at, takes it ill.
m. death at different times; ef ~ þeirra yrði, if one of them should die before the other.
a. of unequal depth; now shallow, now deep.
n. disparity in age (~ þeirra brœðra var mikit).
(see fara), v. to treat amiss, outrage (~ e-u or með e-u); e-m misferst, it goes amiss with one.
(see gøra), v. to do amiss, transgress.
pp. wronged, not getting fair treatment.
a., vera ~ við e-n, to be at variance with.
pp. n., e-m verðr ~, one makes a mistake (in speaking).

a. uneven, unequal, of various qualities, indifferent, rather bad (samfarar þeirra vóru ~ar); mœta misjöfnu, to meet with hardships (sá verðr at mœta misjöfnu, er víða ferr); þessi ætlan þótti mönnum misjöfn, there were different opinions about this undertaking.
(að), v. to make unequal, share unequally; ~ frásögn um menn, to give a different account of, speak well of one and ill of another.
n. throwing away; farast at misköstum, to be wasted.
m. offence, harm; gøra e-m til miska, to offend, wrong a person.
f. forgiveness, mercy, grace (vill Þ. gefast upp í mitt vald til ~ar); í m. konungs, at the king’s mercy; gøra ~ á e-m, to show mercy to.
(að), v. to show mercy to, deal mercifully with, pardon (~ e-m, máli e-s).
líta ~m til e-s, to look in mercy on.
n. work of mercy or charity.
adv. without making any slip (‘miskviðr’) in the pleading (hann sótti málit ~).
m. a slip in the pleading (before a court).
(see leggja), v. to lay amiss; fig., e-m eru mislagðar hendr, one does the contrary of what one ought to do.
(að), v. to dislike, be displeased with (e-m ~r e-t).
(see líta), v. refl., e-m mislízt e-t, one is mistaken about a thing.
f. pl., leggja fœtrna mislögum, to lay the feet across.
(-ta, -tr), v. to make a slip of the tongue (Þórði varð mismælt).
n. slip of the tongue (mæla ~); e-m verðr ~ á munni, one makes a slip of the tongue.
pp. n., e-u er ~, it is ill-advised.
1) to miss, fail in hitting (Kolr sveiflaði til hans øxi ok missti hans);
2) to be without (þeir höfðu lengi matar misst); impers., missir e-s, it ceases; þar sem missti húsanna, where there were no longer any houses;
3) to miss, feel the want of (missum vér nú Hákonar, frænda míns); m. fótanna, to slip with the feet, miss one’s footing; impers., ef mín missir við, if I should die;
4) to lose, suffer loss of; ek hefi mikils misst, I have had a great loss;
5) with acc. to lose, esp. in later writers (vér höfum misst frændr vára).
f. loss (megu vér nú eigi þegja yfir missu okkarri).
(see segja), v. to relate wrongly or incorrectly.
1) season, a period of six months, half year (ár heitir tvau m.); sams ~s, in the same season;

2) in pl. twelvemonth, year (er þau höfðu ásamt verit ein m., áttu þau son); önnur m., the next twelvemonth; á tveim hinum fyrrum misserum, in the two preceding years; öllum misserum, all the year round.
n. pl., mistakes in a work (svá at eigi verði stór ~ á); sjá, finna ~ á e-u, to find, see faults in a thing.
a. of unequal length (of a garment).
(see sýna), v. refl., e-m missýnist, one sees wrong, is mistaken (allmjök missýnist slíkum manni sem Broddier).
2) e-m verðr-tekit til e-s, one does a thing wrongly;
(að), v. to make a slip with the tongue.
1) the middle (sá var mestr, er í miðit reið);
2) mark; sem ek munda hafa m. á mér, ef, which I should have experienced on myself, if;
3) fishing bank (indicated by landmarks on shore); bregða til miða, to seek for a fishing bank.

(að), v. to take note, mark (E. hafði glöggt miðat á um kveldit, hvar konungrinn hvíldi); m. við e-t, to mark a distance or place by another object (hlað hér vörðu, ok miða svá við þar sem eldrinn brennr).
n. the middle of a ship (skipit var breitt um ~t).
m. a farm lying in the midst (of three).
adv. in the middle of the fjord.
f. the middle of the line (in battle).
m. middle shelf on a hill-side.
(also á or í ~), prep. = meðal, milli (~ svefns ok vöku).

1) to share; m. e-m e-t or m. e-t við e-n, to share with another (Gunnar ~ði mörgum mönnum hey ok mat); skal ek eigi m. ríkit, I shall not share the realm; m. spor sín, to make a step, move (stöndum fast ok miðlum ekki spor vár);
2) to mediate; m. mál or málum, to make a compromise;
3) refl., ~st e-t við, to share with one another; m. mál við, to make a compromise.
1) midway, halfway (er þeir kómu ~ til Máfahlíðar);
2) in the middle (Ísraels synir gengu þurt ~ um hafit).
adv. middlingly, indifferently, poorly; þykkist hann þá vera m. staddr, in rather a hard plight.
n., the time when the sun is midway between midday (twelve o’clock) and nón (three o’clock), half past one (um ~ miðs dags ok nóns).
m. the middle point between two places or times (í miðmundastað vestrs ok útnorðrs).
1) the middle between two places; þá er Skoðborgará á miðmunda, the river S. is midway; with gen., þá er sól er miðmunda norðrs ok landnorðrs, when the sun is midway between north and north-east;
2) = miðmundaskeið (fyrir miðmunda hófst orrostan, en konungr féll fyrir nón);
3) moment, weight, importance; allir þeir, er þar höfðu verit ok nökkurr ~ var at, and were of any note.
m. the middle bench (of the lögrétta).

(mið, mitt), a. middle, lying in the middle; nær miðri veröldinni, near the middle of the world; G. leggr í móti atgeirinum ok kom á hann miðjan, and struck him in the middle; áin var opin um mitt, in the middle; mið nótt, midnight (þá var mið nótt); m. dagr, midday (þat var nær miðjum degi, er þeir fundust); m. aptann, six o’clock p. m.; m. morginn, six o’clock a. m.; at miðjum vetri, um miðjan vetr, at midwinter; mitt sumar, midsummer; miðrar brautar, in the middle of the road.
n. middle of a ship (= mitt skip).
adv. in the middle of the sound (cf. sund).
f. pl. milking (vóru þá konur at mjöltum).
n. the head of the thigh-bone.
(að), v. refl. to become narrow (sundin ~ til útsiglingar).
2) to give milk (geitr mjólkuðu sem kýr).
1) thin, slender, slim; mjótt band, a slender cord;
3) narrow, opp. to breiðr (þar var mjótt sund ok djúpt).
1) with verbs, much, greatly (hann skaut m. til ráða dóttur sinnar);
2) with adjs. and advs. very (harðlyndr m.);
3) almost, very nearly (hann var dauðr m. af kulda).
(gen. mjöls, dat. mjöli, mjölvi), n. meal, flour (skip hlaðit af malti ok mjölvi).
n. pl. purchase of meal (fara at ~um).
(gen. mjallar), fresh powdery snow (sá snjór, er hvítastr er, ok í logni fellr, ok m. er kallaðr).
f. rent to be paid in meal.
f. a weight (40 lbs.) of meal.
n. pl., poet. the right measure.
(gen. mjaðmar, pl. mjaðmir), f. hip; bregða e-m á m., to throw one’s antagonist by a hip-trick (mjaðmarbragð).
(gen. mjaðar, dat. miði), m. mead; blanda mjöð, to blend mead; grasaðr m., spiced mead.
1) soft to the touch, opp. to harðr (mjúkt skinn);
3) easy, comfortable (þótti þeim þat mjúkara at taka, er laust flaut);
4) meek, pliable, gentle (þér munu menninir mjúkari en mér).
1) with dat. to shovel (m. ösku, snjó, myki);
2) with acc. to cleanse by shovelling, to clear of dung, etc. (m. flór, kvíar, fjós).
(að), v. to crush, break into small pieces (hauss hans molaðist).
1) mould, earth (hlóðu síðan at grjóti ok jósu at moldu);
2) earth, the ground; fyrir m. ofan, above earth, alive; fyrir m. neðan, beneath the earth, underground; hníga til moldar, to die.
m. ‘mould’s eke’, dust; verða at moldarauka, to be turned into dust.
m. path of earth (lét hón mar fara moldveg sléttan).
m. small piece, crumb; also collect. bits, fragments (haussinn brotnaði í smán mola).
f. bridal gift (on the morning after the wedding).
at morni, next morning (konungr dvaldist þar um nótt, en at morni bjó hann ferð sína);
í morgin, this (past) morning (dauðan segir þú þann nú, er vér höfum hjalat við í morgin); tomorrow (í morgin, sem ljóst er, skulu vér rannsaka bœinn);
(að), v. to become morning, dawn (þar til er ~t var mjök).
1) to waste or pine away (m. ok þorna);
2) to cause to pine (þik morn morni!).
n. murder (kallið þér þat eigi m., at drepa menn um nætr?).
(gen. -rs), m. a lady’s headgear (m. snjóhvítr ok gullofinn).
f. a woman wearing a motr.

(man, munda, munaðr), v. to remember (mantu nökkut, hver orð ek hafða þar um? Þat man ek görla); m. langt fram, to remember far back; m. til e-s, to have recollection of (spyrr Sveinn konungr, hvárt þeir muni til heitstrengingar sinnar); m. e-m e-t, to remember a thing against one (skal ek nú, segir hón, muna þér kinn-hestinn).

1) to move, remove, with dat.; m. út garði, to shift the fence farther off, widen it; mér er ór minni munat, I have quite forgotten it; intrans., m. fram, to move forward, advance (miðlum ekki spor vár, nema vér munim fram);
2) to make a difference, with dat. of the amount (svá at muni hálfri stiku í tíu stikum).
(að), v. impers.; e-n munar, one longs, desires (rare).
n. time, high time (er þú hefir gört þetta, þá mun þér m. ór hauginum á braut);
(í) þat m., at (by, about) that time;
with gen., í þat m. dags, at that time of the day;
önnur misseri í þetta m., this time next year;
í þau m., in those days;
irregular pl. mundir, f., hann bað menn sína bíða til annars dags í þær mundir, wait till the same hour next day.
(að), v. to aim, point, with a weapon (Gunnarr mun eigi lengi m. atgeirinum, ef hann fœrir hann á lopt); recipr., ~st at or til, to point at one another (with weapons).

n. the tongue of the balance, the mean between two extremes, moderation; hærra nafn en m. væri, than was fit and proper; gen. sing. ‘~s’, and gen. pl. ‘~a’ used as adv., moderately, in a fair degree (~s mikit, ~a heitr).
n. the true middle, golden mean, due moderation; með-hófi, moderately, duly, fitly.
n. agreement about a woman’s mundr.
f. basin used in washing the hands (hann tók ~ar þrjár fáðar með gulli).
(gen. -ar), m. the sum which the bridegroom had to pay for his bride, and which after the wedding became her own property.
n.; með orðum ~s, with the words of his mouth.

1) mouth; mæla fyrir munni sér, to say in a low voice; e-m verðr e-t á munni, one happens to say (þat varð henni á munni, er hón sá þetta: ‘sjá ben markar spjóti spor’); mæla af munni fram, to extemporize;
2) the steel edge of an axe or hammer.
f. language; hafa góða ~, to use good language.
1) mind; e-m leikr í mun, one has a mind to, feels inclined to (= leikr e-m í skapi); munar stríð, heart’s grief;
2) mind, longing, delight; at mínum munum, to my mind; gráta at mun, to weep heartily; at mannskis munum, to please anybody; leita e-m munar, to comfort one;
3) love; sá inn máttki m., all-powerful love; vættak míns munar, I waited for my love; komast á muni við e-n, to insinuate oneself, become intimate, with one.
1) difference (hví gørir þú svá mikinn mun barnanna); er þess, mikill m., hvárt, it makes a great difference, whether;

2) moment, importance; e-m er m. undir e-u, it is of importance to one (at hann skyldi segja honum þá hluti, er honum væri m. undir at vita); e-m er m. at e-u, it is of some moment (ok mætti þér verða munr at, at þeir væri þér heldr sinnaðir en í móti); meta muninn, to hesitate (Hrólfr mat eigi munin eptir þeim at fara); Grímr gørði ok þann mun allan, er hann mátti, G. strained every nerve;

3) the dat. ‘muni’ or ‘mun’ before a compar., somewhat (= nökkuru), considerably, a good deal; ljóstu mun kyrrara, strike somewhat more gently; með muni minna liði, with consideralby less force; adding a pronoun, þeim mun (before a compar.) = því; þeim mun betr, so much the better; engum mun = engu; engum mun verr, no worse;

4) what is wanted, required; er mikilla muna vant or á vant, much is wanting (þótti honum mikilla muna á vant, at vel væri); E. hafði eigi skaplyndi til at biðja konung hér neinna muna um, E. was too proud to beg anything in this case;
5) adverbial phrases, fyrir hvern mun, by all means; fyrir engan mun, by no means;

6) means, things; at eigi munið ér alla yðra muni til leggja, that you will not contribute all your means, strain every nerve; biskup las fyrst smám ok smám munina fyrir þeim, expounded all the details for them.
n. dearest wish (hefk míns föður ~ brotit).
(man or mun, munda; pret. infin. mundu), v.

to be a hindrance to (ef þat nemr við förinni, at þú þykkist hafa fé of lítit);

(-ði, -t), v. to be enough, suffice; impers., e-m nœgir, it is sufficient for one;

1) with adjectives and adverbs; too; of gamall, ungr, langr, stuttr, too old, young, long, short; of mjök, too much; of lengi, too long;

taka ~ húsin, to pull down the house;

1) the upper, uppermost, opp. to neðanverðr;

ertu nökkurs ráðandi hér, have you any authority here?

~ fé ok fjörvi, to enjoy wealth and life;
~ e-t at líkindum, to judge from probabilities (engar munu fríðari en þínar dœtr, ef at líkindum skal ~);
12) to read and understand (~ rúnar, stafi, rit);
réð ek þær rúnar, er reist þín systir, I have read the runes thy sister engraved;
13) to punish, chastise, with dat. (fóstri hans var harðr við hann ok réð honum mjök);
ráða stórt, to aim high, undertake great things;
15) periphrastically with an infin., to do;
hón réð vakna (= hón vaknaði), she awoke;
þau lög, er hann réð upp at segja, the laws which he pronounced;
~ e-t af, to resolve, make up one’s mind (réð hann þat af at sigla súðr til Danmerkr);
to discontinue, put a stop to (ek hygg, at Þóroddr ætli nú at af ~ hingatkvámur þínar);
to do away with (þú verðr nú þetta vandræði af at ~);
~ e-n af e-u, to make one leave off (af hefir þú mik ráðit brekvísi við þik);
Þ. bað menn taka forka ok ~ af skipinu, to get the ship off, set her afloat;
~ e-n af = ~ e-n af lífi, af dögum, to put out of the way, put to death (hann kvazt mundu af ~ illmenni þessi);
~ at e-m, to attack (njósnarmenn hlupu upp ok réðu at þeim);
~ á e-t, to set about a thing (þeir réðu á íshöggit);
~ á e-n, to attack one (þorðu aldri úvinir hans á hann at ~);
~ bót (bœtr) á e-u, to remedy, make good (þóttust menn eigi kunna bœtr á þessu ~);
~ e-n frá e-u, to deprive one of, exclude one from (~ e-n frá landi, ríki);
~ fyrir e-u, to command, have authority over, be master of (~ fyrir skipi, hofi, fé, eldi);
~ í e-t, to guess at, find out (Gormr konungr réð ekki í þetta);
~ móti, í móti e-m, to attack one (í móti Kára réð Mörðr);
~ ór e-u, to find an expedient, solve a difficulty (er nú vant ór at ~);
~ til e-s, to rush in upon, attack (hann reiddi upp øxina ok réð til Þórvarðs); to take to (set about) a thing, try, make an attempt;
S. kom fótum undir sik, ok réð til í annat sinn, and tried again the second time;
ok er nú til at ~, ef þér vilit, now is the time for action, if you are willing;
skal ~ til árinnar eða eigi, shall we try to pass the river or not?;
~ til orrostu, to go to battle;
~ til uppgöngu, to make an ascent;
~ til ferðar, to start on a journey;
~ skipi til hlunns, to draw a ship on to land;
~ um e-t, to dispose of (megum vér eigi ~ um hennar gjaforð);
to deliberate on (konungr gaf jarli orlof at ~ um þetta við menn sina);
~ um at gøra e-t, to be about to do a thing (hann tók um strenginn ok réð um at fara upp í skipit);
~ um við e-n, to put an end to, finish off (var Alfr þá kominn ok ætlaði skjótt um at ~ við Finnboga);
~ e-t or e-u undan e-m, to deprive one of (hón vildi eigi giptast, því at hón vildi eigi ~ fé undan dóttur sinni);
~ e-t undir e-n, to put in the charge of (þá réðu þeir goðorð sitt undir Rafn);
~ e-t upp, to read up (þessi sömu bréf lét erkibiskup upp ~ í Danmörku);
~ við e-n, to be able to master one (muntu nú einn við mik ~);
~ e-t við sik, to make up one’s mind;
n. short stay (Asa tók við Þórði á ~).
f. change in one’s life or condition.
a. n. lacking counsel, at one’s wit’s ends (þeim varð ekki ~).
f. plan, design (töluðu þeir leyniliga ~ sína);
hafa áhyggjur ok ~ir, to make plans.
m. a man of many devices (mikill, lít ill, ~).
1) state of life, condition (eyðist fé fyrir þeim, ok gørist ~inn úhœgr); way of life (nú vil ek breyta ráðahag okkrum);
2) marriage (þér mun kostr ráðahags við Sigríði systur mína).
1) influential man (Birgir var hinn þriði mestr ~ ílandinu);
2) manager, steward (hann var húskarl Þóris ok ~ fyrir búi hans).
m. lack of shifts or expedients.
v. refl.to be resolved, settled (eigi mun þetta ~ þessu sinni);
réðst mikit mannfall, there was a great slaughter;
~ at hjóni, to hire oneself out, enter service (réðst hann þá þar at hjóni);
~ á, to come to blows (svá kom, at þeir ~ á);
~ í hernað, to go on warfare;
hann réðst í flokk með þeim, he joined him self to their company;
~ ór hernaði, give up, leave off freebooting;
~ til e-s, to remove to one (bið Una selja jörð sína ok ~ hingat til mín);
~ til ferðar með e-m, to undertake a journey with one;
~ til skips með e-m, to sail with one;
réðst til allgiptusamliga, it turned out very happily;
~ um við e-n, to consult with one (Pálnatóki réðst um við félaga sína);
vel hefir ór ráðizt, things have turned out well.
m. contriver of a person’s death.
v. refl. to consult (af e-m, við e-n).
1) resolved, determined (~ til e-s, í e-u);
2) certain (þat hygg ek at ~ sé úfriðrinn);
a. shiftless, having lost one’s head.
(see leggja), v. to give advice, advise (e-m e-t).
m. home, shelter; hann kvaðst sét hafa ráðstafa fyrir honum, he had provided for him.
a. open to advice, pliable (ráðþægir sínum ráðgjöfum).
n. pl. refuse, unclean matter (hann kvazt aldri etit hafa r.).
a. rejected, abhorred, abominable (r. ok rekinn frá guði).
(-ta, -tr), v. to rob, plunder, to deprive (one) of (a thing).
2) vera r. e-s, to be robbed or plundered by one (þú munt vilja vera r. Ljóts sem margir aðrir).
1) r. e-t á hendr e-m, to bring a charge against one (eigi var mér þess ván, at þú mundir þetta r. á hendr mér);
2) impers., ræsir draum, a dream proves true, comes to pass.
(-sta, -str), v. to clean, sweep (konur skulu ~ húsin ok tjalda);
~ (stífldan) lœk, to clear out a (dammed-up) brook.
m. knot (tók hann língarn ok reið á ræxna, sem net er síðan).
n. = rénan (var þá nökkut ~ á hans sótt).
(að), v. to dwindle, decrease, subside (orrostan rénaði).
1) public fold (þat var um haustit, er sauðir vóru í ~ reknir);
2) esp. pl. the general sheep-gathering in autumn (þann dag skulu vera réttir í Þórarinsdal).
1) to make straight, straighten, opp. to beygja, kreppa (~ krók, ~ á sér fingrna);
2) to stretch out, stretch (r. or r. fram höndina); r. e-t e-m, to reach, hand over, a thing to one (hann rétti sjóðinn at Sigmundi);
3) to raise, right a capsized boat (hvelfdi skipinu, en dvergarnir réttu skip sitt);
4) to rise (hann rétti ekki ór rekkju);
5) to put right, adjust; r. hluta e-s, to redress; knoungr vildi eigi r. þetta mál, the king refused justice;
6) to let the ship drift, = leggja í rétt (varð þá at hlaða seglum ok r.);
7) with preps., r. fram, to stretch out; r. e-t upp, to raise (Þórr rétti upp höndina); r. við, to come to oneself, recover (Narfi réttir við ór rotinu);
8) refl., ~st, to be put straight; réttust fingrnir, the fingers became straight; to stretch oneself (r. gørði raumrinn stirðr); r. upp, to rise (Hákon jarl réttist upp).
pp. legitimate; ~ til ríkis, a lawful heir to the throne.
a. in lawful possession of (at e-u).
1) setting right, amendment; vil ek eiga r. allra orða minna, I claim the right to amend all my words;
2) redress (varð þessa engi r. af Önundi).
pp. having proper right (~ til ríkis).
2) on the right path (snúa sér ~ ok trúa á sannan guð).
2) erect, upright (Óttar stóð r. ok brá sér ekki við);
3) right, just (telja þat rangt, er rétt er); hafa rétt at mæla, to be right, in the right; at réttu, með réttu, rightly.
1) right, law; lands r., the law of the land; kristinn r., guðs r., ecclesiastical law;
2) right, due, claim; konungs r., the king’s due (at konungr minnki nökkut af sínum rétti);
3) condition; hann gørði harðan rétt landsmanna, he tyrannized over them;
4) dish (hinn fyrsta rétt báru inn þessir lendir menn);
5) drifting before the wind; liggja í rétt, to lie drifting; leggja í rétt, to set a ship’s course for drifting;
6) storm, heavy sea (fengu þeir rétt mikinn; skipit var lekt ok þoldi illa réttinn).
a. ‘right-streamed’; hafa vel-streymt, to have the current fully with one.
a. fair, just (góðir menn ok réttsýnir).
adv. with the sun, opp. to rangsœlis.

1) to rive, tear (þeir létu dýr ok hrafna r. hræin); r. klæði af sér, to tear off one’s clothes; r. aptr, to rip up (Þ. vildi at aptr væri rifit sárit); r. ofan, r. niðr, to pull down; r. í sundr, to tear asunder;
2) impers. to be rent, give way (reif seglit).
(að), v. to mend, improve; er nauðsyn at r. ráð fyrir dóttur þinni, to mend her state.
a. good, acceptable (í gulli ok silfri eðr í rífum aurum).
1) power, might (ek hefi hafit þik til ríkis af litlum manni); veita e-m r., to grant one power;
2) rule, dominion (lagðist land allt undir r. Haralds konungs);
3) kingdom (fór konungr heim í r. sitt).
(-ta, -t), v. to reign (hann ríkti fjögur ár ok tuttugu).
1) mighty, powerful (r. höfðingi); r. ok auðigr, powerful and wealthy; ríkri (= ríkari) ráð sagði, the stronger had his way;
2) of things, strong (var þar ríkt varðhald); ganga ríkt, to prevail (lát þú eigi þá fæð svá ríkt ganga, at); leggja ríkt við, to lay a heavy penalty on;
a. magnificent (ríkulig veizla); ~ maðr, a fine man.
1) to rise, get up (ár skal r. sá er annars vill fé eða fjör hafa); r. ór rekkju, frá borði, to rise from the dead;
2) to come into existence, arise (vita þóttist hann, af hverjum rótum þetta hafði risit);

3) with preps. and advs., mikit orð ríss á e-u, it is much spoken of; r. í móti e-u, to rise against; r. upp, to rise, get up (hón reis ekki upp fyrir miðjan dag); to rise from the dead (dauðir rísa upp); r. upp fyrir e-m, to yield, give up, one’s place to another; r. við e-m, to rise against, withstand.
1) to cut, slash (Otkell rekr sporann við eyra Gunnari ok rístr mikla ristu); r. e-t í sundr, to cut int two (Þ. reist í sundr línbrók sína);
2) to cut open (hón reist á mér kviðinn);
3) to cut, carve, grave on something (r. rúnar á kefli, horni);
4) to carve, form by carving (Hrafn lá í bekk ok reist spán, því at hann var hagr).
2) to write (bókin var öll ritin gullstöfum).

1) to ride, go on horseback (þeir brœðr riðu til alþingis); with dat. of the animal (r. hesti, vargi); of ghosts, r. húsum, skála, to ‘ride’ on the ridge of a house; with acc. of the road or the place; r. leið sína, veg sinn, to ride through brush and forest; r. eyrendi, to ride on an errand;
2) to break in, train (þat var siðvenja þeirra at r. hesta, temja bæði við gang ok við hlaup);
3) to move through the air; øxin reið at honum, the axe cam at him; reið at honum brúnássinn, down on him came the wall-plate; er upp reið gálga-tréit, when the gallows-tree was raised;
4) to reel, stagger (hann reið á ymsar hliðar);
5) r. upp, to rise (þeir fengu tekit hann við klif, er upp ríðr ór fjörunni);
6) miklu (litlu) ríðr um e-t, it is of great (small) importance; eigi þarf nú meira við, at fullu num þetta r., this will be quite enough.

1) to twist, knit, wind; r. knút, to knit a knot; r. net, to work a net; r. knapp á e-t, to finish, wind a thing up; vera við e-t riðinn, to be concerned in, have to do with (verðr hann lítt við söguna riðinn);
2) to rub, smear (r. blóði á e-n or e-n blóði); ríða í, to rub into (r. kolum ok leiri í andlit sér);
3) fig., with dat., to thrash, flog; r. e-m um kinn, to buffet one;
4) to wring, press (mjólk sú, er riðin er ór seljubörk).

f. rest, calm, tranquility; gefa ró reiði, to give rest to one’s wrath; í ró, at rest, in peace; mega sér hvergi ró eiga í landi, to feel restless, feel no rest anywhere; bíða ró, to be easy, at rest (Gunnhildr lét þat seiða, at Egill skyldi aldri ró bíða á Íslandi).
(pl. rœr), f. small clinch-plate, burr (on which a nail is clinched).
1) to row, pull; hann rœr út í Bjarneyjar, he rows out to the Bearisles; with the boat in dat. (reru þeir skipinu upp í ána);
2) to row out to sea, go fishing, = r. út (þenna morgin bjóst Þ. á sjó at r.); er hann kom þar, vóru allir menn rónir nema Þ., all the men had rowed out fishing except Th.;
3) to rock oneself backwards and forwards;
4) recipr., róast at, to pull so as to encounter one another, of two ships in battle.
f. the vertebral part of a tail.
1) slander, calumny (sögðu þat mundu vera r. illra manna); bera e-n í r. við e-n, to slander (calumniate) one to a person (sá maðr var borinn í r. við Magnús konung);
2) strife, quarrel; verða e-m at rógi, to be the cause of discord; leiða e-n nær rógi, to lead into feud.
(að), v. to give assent to by shouting, approve of (þetta ráð var af öllum vel rómat).
m. the road leading to Rome.
f. journey (pilgrimage) to Rome (hann bjóst til ~ar).
1) voice (Gizurr var blíðmæltr ok mikill rómrinn); tala með litlum rómi, to speak in a low voice;
2) applause; gøra góðan (mikinn) róm at e-u, to applaud.
1) root (var þess ván, at illr ávöxtr mundi koma af illri r.);
2) fig. cause, origin (vera e-s r. or r. undir e-u).
f. the inner part of the roof of a house, where stores are hung up.
(að), v. to stir, throw into disorder, with dat.; þeir rótuðu um koll taflinu, they upset the chessboard; þá rótar karl saman fénu, he sweeps the money into one heap.
n. a tree with the root.
m. poet. wind, tempest; láta (leggja) e-n fyrir róða, to cast to the winds, forsake one.
(gen. róðrar), m. rowing, pulling (hafa búnar árar til róðrar).
n. rowing-wind; taka ~, to take to rowing.
(gen. raddar, pl. raddir), f. voice; með skjálfandi ~u, with a trembling (faltering) voice.
(gen. röggvar, pl. röggvar), f. tuft, shagginess (of the fur of a cloak).
1) reason, ground, origin (nú skal segja, af hverjum rökum heiðnir menn héldu jól);

2) wonder, marvel; forn r., great things of yore; firrist (imperat.) æ forn r. firar, let bygones be bygones; stór r., mighty things, great marvels; tíva r., the life and doings of the gods; þjóða r., origin, creation of mankind; í aldar r., at the end of the world; ragna r., see ragnarök.
2) poet. shield; leggja randir saman, to lay shield against shield; reisa r. við e-m, to raise the shield against one, resist, withstand;
I) (gen. rangar, pl. rengr), f. rib in a ship.
a. doughty (var hann allra manna röskligastr).
(acc. röskvan), a. vigorous, doughty, brave (~ maðr).
(að), v. refl. to ripen, of fruit; to grow up, of man (ok er hann röskvaðist, fekk konungr honum skip).
(gen. rastar, pl. rastir), f. a strong current in the sea, race.
(gen. rastar, pl. rastir), f. a distance of four or five miles.
(gen. raðar, pl. raðar, raðir), f. row, series.
n. twilight; ragna r., the twilight of the gods, the end of the world = ragna rök.
(røkkr, -, røkkvit), v. to grow dark (hann þorði hvergi at fara, þegar er r. tók); er røkkvit var, after nightfall.
n. twilight; ragna r., the twilight of the gods, the end of the world = ragna rök.
1) room, space (hvergi nær hafði þar r. lið þeirra); fá rúms, to get space; e-m liggr e-t í miklu rúmi, it is of great concern, importance to one;
2) place, seat (Egill gekk til rúms þess, er dóttir jarlsins hafði setit um daginn);
3) bed, = rekkja (síðan rannsakaði hann rúmit, er hón hafði hvílt í);
4) ‘room’ in a ship, one for each pair of rowers (mikit skip, þar vóru sex rúm ok tuttugu);
5) space of time; þriggja daga r., a space of three days.
n. number of ‘rooms’ in a ship (skip þrítugt at ~i).
m. way to Rome (konungr var á Rúmavegi), = Rómavegr.
adv. roomily (í þeirri höll máttu ~ sitja fjögur hundruð manna).
1) roomy, ample, spacious, broad (gatan var eigi rýmri en einn maðr mátti ríða senn);
2) roomy, loose (fjöturrinn var r.); neut., rúmt, roomily (skipin lágu rúmt í höfninni).
of ~ heyrða ek dœma, I heard them talk of mysteries;
jötna ~, the mysteries of the giants;
rísta ~, to engrave runes (réð ek þær ~, er reist þín systir);
rísta ~ á kefli, to cut runes on a stick;
3) magical characters or signs (hann tók við horninu ok reist á ~ ok reið á blóðinu).
(rý, rúða, rúinn), v. to pluck the wool off sheep (r. gemlinga).
1) to make more roomy (r. garð sinn); r. varðhaldit, to make the confinement less severe; r. fyri (viz. öllu fólki) veginn, to clear the way; with dat., r. á honum fjötrinum, to loosen his fetter;
2) r. e-u brott, to drive away, sweep off = ryðja e-u brott (rýmit brott þongum harmi af yðru brjósti); r. til e-s, to clear, prepare the way for = ryðja til e-s;
3) to clear away, break up (þú skalt r. fjalir ór gólfinu);

4) to quit, leave; r. land, to leave the country, go into exile; r. e-t fyrir e-m, to leave (a place, seat) that it may be occupied by another (kallar Skapti, at Þ. skyldi r. höfnina fyrir honum ok leggja ór læginu);
5) to withdraw, absent oneself (skulu þér allir eta hér inni, en ek mun r.); r. fyrir e-m, to cede, give up one’s place to one (hann rýmdi fyrir herra Ásgrími); r. brott, to go away;

6) refl., rýmast, to become roomy, widen; r. tekr dalrinn, the dale widens; impers., rýmist, there is more room (ef rýmdist í kirkjunni); rýmdi Grettir þá fram á gólfit, then G. stepped forth on the floor.
1) to talk, converse (þau rœddu ok rýndu);
2) r. eptir e-u, to pry into.
(-tti, -tt), v. to grunt, squeal, of swine (rýtandi ok emjandi).
(-ða, -ðr), v. to slander, defame; r. menn saman, to set them by the ears by slander.
adv. earnestly, carefully; biðjast fyrir ~, to pray fervently; halda ~, to observe strictly.
(-ta, -tr), v. to reck, heed, take care of; skulu vér r. húðföt vár, let us keep to our hammocks.
(að), v. to take care of, regard, keep (r. vel trú sína).
(-da, -dr), v. to approve of, = róma (allir rœmdu vel mál konungs); r. e-t lítt, to take it coldly (konungr spyrr, ef þeir vildi skírn taka; þeir rœma þat lítt).
1) r. e-t upp, to root up (r. upp illgresi ór guðs akri);
2) refl., rœtast, to take root, strike root, = rótfestast.

1) to speak; r. um e-t, to speak about (konungr rœddi fátt um þessi tíðendi fyrir mönnum); r. við e-n, to speak, talk with one (þá rœddi Höskuldr við Hrút); r. e-t, talk about, discuss (ef þú rœðir þetta mál fyrir konungi);
2) refl., rœðast við, to converse about (hann sagði henni allt þat, er þeir höfðu við rœðst).
f. speech, talk (konungr reiddist mjök við rœður þessar).
vera ~ á e-u, to have got enough of.
m. sap of trees (börkr af viði ok safi; ber ok safi).
(að), v. to saw, cut with a saw (krossinn var sagaðr í sundr).
1) what is said, statement (má vera, at sönn sé s. þín);

2) tale, story, history; segja, ríta sögu, to tell, write a story; hann kemr eigi við þessa sögu, he is not connected with this ‘saga’; vera ór sögunni, to be out of the story; vera í sögu, to be mentioned in a story; svá sem sögu, to be mentioned in a story; svá sem sögur eru til, as the story goes;
3) the events which gave rise to the story; hann var þá mjök hniginn á efra aldr, er sjá saga gørðist, when this came to pass;
4) tale, report (eigi veit ek um sögur slíkar, hvárt satt er).
f. story-telling (at public meetings, feasts, etc.).

(að), v. to do harm, scathe (jarl kvað þat ekki s. mundu); impers., hvat sem at var gört, sakaði hann (acc.) ekki, no matter what they did, no harm came to him; recipr., at vér skylim sjálfir um sakast, that we should injure one another.

(að), v. to blame, find fault with; s. sik um e-t, to blame oneself for (ekki mun tjá at s. sik um orðinn hlut); recipr., sakast um e-t, to blame one another for a thing; s. sáryrðum, to bandy cutting words.
adv. without prosecution, dropping the prosecution.
m. a man disposed to litigate; ~ mikill, a great ligitant.
m. the chief party in a case.
n. mispleading, by which a suit may be lost.
m. ground which one has for suing another; offence (gefa upp sakarstaðinn).
m. a witness to the handing over of a suit.
n. witness of the handing over of a suit.
1) scathed, damaged (var eitt borð sakat í skipi þeirra);
2) guilty (hann er því meirr s. en aðrir menn, at hann vann á jarli dauðum).
f. pl. damages, fine (to be paid to the kinsmen of the slain).
m. fine, penalty esp. a fine due to the king.
prep. with gen. on account of, for the sake of, = fyrir ~ e-s (s. orða konungs).

adv. together, = saman; allir s., all together; einn s., alone; í s., continuously, uninterruptedly (cf. samr); kemr þat á samt með þeim, at, they come to an agreement that.

1) to assert, affirm (~ði annarr, en annarr synjaði);

1) truth, verity (ef hann vill heldr trúa lygi en sannindum); e-t er með sannindum, it is true (biskup trúði, at þat mundi með sannindum, er sagt var frá); fara með sannindum, to tell the truth; reynast með sannindum, to prove true; með sannindum at segja, to tell the truth; unna e-m sanninda um e-t, to give one his due;
2) evidence, proof (engi önnur s. hafa menn till þess, nema þau); til sanninda e-s, um e-t, as a proof of.
1) to call a thing by its right name;

1) true (sónn saga); hón sagði þór satt frá Geirróði, she told Thor the truth about G.; nú skal ek segja þér it sanna, now I will tell thee the truth; hafa e-t fyrir satt, to be sure (convinced) of; hafa sannara, to be in the right (skal konungr um segja, hvárir sannara hafi); gøra e-t satt, to make good, prove (hvern veg gørir þú þat satt); s. sem dagr, true as day, clear as noonday (= dag~); sönnu sagðr, justly charged; með sönnu, at sönnu, in truth, truly; til sanns, certainly, for certain (vita e-t til sanns);
2) meet, proper (væri þat sannara, at þú værir drepinn);
3) s. at e-u, convicted of, (proved) guilty of (s. at sökinni).
1) truth (vita sann á e-u); fœra e-m heim sanninn, to tell one the bitter truth;
2) fairness; e-t er nær sanni, is fair or reasonable; ástir þeirra vóru at góðum sanni, they loved each other fittingly;
3) estimation; bœtta e-t við góðra manna sann, according to the estimate of good men.

(að), v. to sew (sátu þær þar ok saumuðu); to make by sewing (s. e-m klæði); s. e-t at e-u, to sew tight round; kyrtill svá þröngr, sem ~ðr væri at honum, a tunic as tight as though it were sewn on him.
f. a row of nails in a ship’s planking.
2) pl., saumar, needle-work, sewing (sitja at saumum).
(að), v. to dirty, defile, pollute (~ völlinn í blóði).
(acc. saurgan), a. filthy, dirty (hafa hendr mjök saurgar).
n. lewdness, fornication, lechery, opp. to hreinlífi.
1) mud (at engi s. støkkvi af hestum yðrum ok á konunginn);
2) dirt, excrements; ausast sauri á, to throw dirt at one another.
n. pl. foul words, filthy language; cf. saurmæli.

m. flock of sheep (sem vargr í sauðadun).
n. shreds of sheep torn by a beast of prey.

3) the gunwale near the prow (Gunnarr hleypr þegar á saxit á skip Vandils); esp. in pl., söx, the forepart of a ship (sær féll inn um söxin).
(að), v. to cut with a sax, to chop, hack (s. e-t í sundr).
m. the point of a sax.
a. sated, having got one’s fill (~ em ek enn þess).
(að), v. to soothe, appease, calm (ef hann fær eigi sefat hana);
refl., sefast, to be soothed, appeased, of anger (gekk af honum móðrinn ok sefaðist hann).
m. slice, strip, shred (skera e-t í sega).
1) to say, tell (seg þú mér þat, er ek spyr þik);
þeir sögðu, at þeir skyldu aldri upp gefast, they said they would never yield;
~ e-m leið, to tell the way, esp. on the sea, to pilot;
impers. it is told (hér segir frá Birni bunu);
sem áðr sagði, as was told before;
~nda er allt vin sínum, all can be told to a friend;
2) to say, declare, in an oath;
ek segi þat guði (Æsi), I declare to God (to the ‘Áss’);
~ sik í þing, lög, to declare oneself member of a community;
~ sik ór þingi, lögum, to declare oneself out of, withdraw from, a community;
~ skilit við konu, to declare oneself separated from, divorce, one’s wife;
~ fram sök, to declare one’s case;
~ lög, to recite the law, of the lögsögumaðr;
5) with preps., ~ e-n af e-u, to declare one off a thing, take it from him;
~ e-t á e-n, to impose on (bœta at þeim hluta, sem lög segði á hann); to announce (~ á reiði, úsátt sína);
~ eptir e-m, to tell tales of one;
Unnr, er ek sagða þér frá, U. of whom I told thee;
~ fyrir e-u, to prescribe (svá var með öllu farit, sem hann hafði fyrir sagt);
~ fyrir skipi, to bid God-speed to a ship;
~ e-t fyrir, to predict, foretell (~ fyrir úorðna hluti);
~ e-u sundr, í sundr, to break up, dissolve (~ sundr friði, frændsemi, hjúskap);
~ til e-s, to tell, inform of (segit honum ekki til, hvat þér hafit gört við hrossit);
~ til nafns síns, ~ til sín, to tell (give) one’s name;
~ upp e-t, to pronounce (~ upp dóm, gørð);
~ upp lög, to proclaim the law (from the law-hill);
~ e-n upp, to give one up;
~ upp e-u, to declare at an end (~ upp friði, griðum);
~ upp þjónustu við e-n, to leave one’s service;
hann sagðist þá vaka, he said that he was awake;
kristnir menn ok heiðnir sögðust hvárir ór lögum annarra, they declared themselves each out of the other’s laws;
láta (sér) ~st, to let oneself be spoken to, listen to reason;
impers., e-m segist svá, one’s tale runs so.
a. sail; draga, vinda (upp) ~, to hoist sail; leggja (ofan) s., to take in sail; hlaða seglum, to furl the sails.
n. pl. return (payment) for a sail.
3) difficult (seigt mun veita at kristna Ísland).
f. string, line; koma á s. e-m, to be carried along by one.

(d), v. refl. to stretch out one’s hand (Þórr seildist svá langt upp, sem hann mátti lengst); s. eptir e-u, til e-s, to try to get hold of a thing; fig. to seek far for a thing (s. tíl sœmdar í hendr e-m); s. á e-t, to encroach on (s. á guðs, krúnunnar, rétt).
2) poet. gold, riches (rautt gull er s.).
n.?, delay; láta eigi s. at sér, to make haste.

a. slow to advance oneself, slow-growing.

refl., ~st, to be delayed (mjök þótti s. atlagan).
adv. slowly, indifferently, reluctantly (taka e-u ~, taka ~ undir e-t).

2) late (förum til skipa ok verðum eigi of seinir); Sveinn var seinst búinn, S. was the last to get ready.
pp. slow to be moved; ~ til vandræða, slow to be drawn into quarrels.
(-dda, -ddr), v. to enchant by a spell; s. seið, to work a spell.

f. spells to counteract witchcraft (rísta seiðvillur).
1) to sentence to a fine, = gøra e-n ~n; esp. to sentence one to outlawry;
2) refl., ~st, to be liable to a penalty.
2) package, truss, in a merchant ship.
láta þann undan setja, er ~ er, to let him escape who is guilty;
~ e-s or um e-t, guilty of;
2) convicted, outlawed, condemned to outlawry (gøra e-n sekjan, verða ~ um e-t);
3) sentenced to pay, mulcted in (verðr hann ~ um þat þrem mörkum);
tel ek sekt fé hans allt, I say that all his goods are forfeited.
2) penalty; full ~, the highest penalty of the law, forfeiture of goods and outlawry (lýsa til sektar fullrar á hönd e-m);
n. goods, property of an outlaw (skógarmaðr, fjörbaugsmaðr), which was confiscated, one half to the community (fjórðungsmenn), the other half to the prosecutor.
2) pl. the marks by which to know the person of an outlaw.
m. the destitute dependant of an outlaw.
(gen. pl. selja), n. shed on a mountain pasture (where the milk-cows are kept in the summer months).
m. a boat for seal-catching, seal-boat.
f. pl. door of a sel.
f. the keeping of cattle at a sel.
~ e-t í hendr e-m, to make over to one (hann seldi búit í hendr Þorsteini);
~ vápn ór hendi sér, to give up (deliver) one’s weapons;
~ e-m e-t til varðveizlu, to commit to another’s keeping (þér skulut nú ~ mér til varðveizlu vápn yður);
hann kvazt hvárki vildu ~ grið né taka, he said that he would neither give nor receive pardon;
~ e-m laun, to give reward, pay;
~ fé at láni, to lend money;
~ á leigu, to put out at interest;
~ á frest, to give on credit;
2) to sell, part with (hann seldi land sitt);
~ e-t við litlu (miklu) verði, to sell for a small (great) sum;
þótti þeim konungr út seldr, a done man (= fram seldr);
3) refl., ~st, to give oneself up (~st arfsali);
aldri mun þat vel út ~st, it will never go well.
(pl. -endr), m. one who hands over; seller, vendor.

f. pl. door of a sel.
n. a place where seals are caught.
svá ~, so as (svá ~ fyrr vat ritit);
slíkr ~, such as (slíkr maðr ~ Ljótr er);
2) ellipt. = svá ~ (svæla e-n inni ~ melrakka greni);
hann kom, ~ hann hafði heitit, as he had promised;
dugði hverr, ~ mátti, every did as he could, did his best;
3) with superl., ~ skjótast, ~ fyrst, as soon as possible;
þeir hleyptu út á Skaptá ~ mest máttu þeir, as fast as they could;
4) with subj., as if (þeir vóru allir með vápnum ~ til bardaga væri búnir);
5) temp. as, when (~ hringdi til aptansöngs, vildi konungr ganga);
6) as a relat. part., who, which, that, = er, es (eptir þetta, ~ nú var getit);
þaðan ~, whence (muntu þar þykkja sómamaðr ~ þú kemr);
hvar ~ hann kom, wheresoever he came;
8) þar ~, whereas (þú gørir þik góðan þar ~ þú bæði verit þjófr ok ræningi).
to bring or put into, order;
~ sætt, to make peace (fyrr en sættin væri samið);
2) to agree on, settle (engir hlutir skyldi þeir til verða, at eigi þeir sjálfir);
~ við e-n, to treat with one (Hrútr kvazt at vísu vilja ~ við Höskuld);
3) impers., e-m semr e-t, one agrees to a thing;
hvárt sem þeim semdi eða whether they came to terms or not;
konungr bœtti þeirra ok samdi siðu, the king mended, reformed their faith and manners;
hefir þú heldr samit þik ór því sem var, thou hast rather improved thyself;
setja ok ~ dramb to compose and set down one’s pride;
~ sik eptir e-u, to adapt oneself to, conform oneself to (hefir þú samit þik mjök eptir siðvenju útlendra manna);
at þeir semdi sína frændsemi eptir því sem vera ætti, that they should restore their relationship to a proper footing;
5) reflex., ~st, to be settled, agreed on (þat mál samdist á þá leið, at);
e-t semst með e-m, it is agreed on between them (samdist þetta með þeim);
impers. (selja man ek yngra sveininn, sem okkr semst);
~st e-u, to take to (samdist hón skildi ok sverði en við sauma ok borða).
m. pl. ‘Finnish’ messengers (so called by themselves).
1) to send, dispatxh (ek vil ~ þik til Víkrinnar);
maðr var sendr Gizuri hvíta, a man was sent to G. the white;
2) to send, throw, cast (~ spjót, ~ skeytin aptr);
3) recipr., ~st e-t á, ~st e-t í milli, to interchange, send to one another (áðr höfðu þeir senzt orð í milli).
senda konungi vingjafar, hauka, hesta, tjöld, segl, eða aðra þá hluti, er ~ar eru, which are fit for presents;
3) dish, course (eptir þat bjuggust menn til borða; því næst kómu inn ~ar, í fyrstu heitt kjöt).
adv. at the same time, at a time (létu þeir einn jarl s. vera í landinu); allir s., all at once; also, í s. (einn, margir, allir í s.).
(gen. Serkja), m. pl. the Saracens; Assyrians, Persians, etc.
n. the land of the Saracens, esp. used of northern Africa.

1) sark, shirt (þú skalt fara í serk minn); hafa dreng í serk, to have a man inside one’s shirt, to be bold and courageous; hamarrinn var svá lítill, at hafa mátti í serk sér, that one could conceal it in one’s bosom;
(serð, sarð, sorðinn), v. to have intercourse with (esp. a male).
(pl. -ar), m. seat; hann var hár í sessi, he was tall when seated; vera kominn í vandan ~, to be in a difficult situation.
n. a raised deal-floor or platform along the side-walls of an ancient hall (eldaskáli), used as a sitting- and sleeping-place by the household.
1) sitting (nú varð setan löng); hvat merkir s. sjá, what means this sitting still?;
2) seat = sess (hann var hár í setunni); bjóða búum í setu, to call on the neighbours to take their seats;
3) body of men (assembled for defence); eptir þat höfðu hvárirtveggja setu, after that both kept men assembled.
f. pl. breeches with gores in the seat.
m. seat-gore (in a pair of man’s breeches).
1) to seat, set, place, put (hann setti sveininn í kné konungi; hón var í haug sett);
~ e-n inn, to put in prison;
~ inn fénað, svín, hross, to pen up, take in;
~ tjöld, herbúðir, to set up tents;
~ grundvöll til kirkju, to lay the foundation of;
~ e-m gisla, to give one hostages;
2) to drive (hann setti øxina í höfuð honum);
3) to make, establish (~ lög, frið, grið);
~ ráð, ráðagørð, to set on foot (contrive) a plan, plot (báðu þeir hann ~ aðra ráðagørð);
~ e-m torg, markað, to set up a market;
~ e-m dag, stefnu, to fix a day for one to appear;
5) with dat., ~ e-u, to settle (~ máli);
6) to appoint (hann setti Guthorm son sinn til landvarnar);
7) to allay (sá dauði mun ~ mína sút);
8) ~ e-t e-u or með e-u, to set, inlay (hann lét gøra gullkaleik ok ~ gimsteinum);
to embroider (seglit var sett með fögrum skriptum);
9) intrans., to set off (hann lagði halann á bak sér ok setti í burtu);
þegar er niðt setti moldrykit (acc.), when the dust settled;
jarl (acc.) setti svá rauðan sem blóð (dreyrrauðan), the earl turned red as blood;
þá setti at honum hósta, a fit of coughing seized him;
þá setr at henni grát mikinn, she bursts into tears;
~ e-n af kirkju, to put out of the church, excommunicate;

3) adverbially, skömmu, skemmstu, lately, very lately, recently, very recently, = fyrir skömmu, skemmstu; skömmum, not long (sat hann skömmum við drykk); skemmrum, for a shorter time (at landit mundi verða skemmrum biskupslaust, ef tveir væri biskuparnir); sem skemmst, as short a while as possible.
