(skil, skilda; skiliðr, later skildr, skilinn), v.
1) to part, divide, separate (sú er nú kölluð Jökulsá ok skirl landsfjórðunga);
skilr hann flokk sinn, he divides his band;
2) to break off, break up (þessi sótt mun ~ samvistu okkra);
síðan skildu þau talit, they broke off their talk;
3) to part company, take leave (skildu þeir með mikilli vináttu);
4) impers.; þar er leidir (acc.) skildi, þá skildi ok slóðina, where the roads parted, there the tracks too parted;
mundi ~ vegu þeirra, their ways would diverge;
með þessu skilr skipti þeirra, thus ended their dealings;
it differs, mikit (acc.) skilr hamingju okkra, there is a wide difference between our fortunes;
þá skilr á um e-t, they disagree about a thing;
ef skrár skilr á, if the scrolls differ;
5) to distinluish, discern, with the eyes (nú má ek þann eigi sjá eða biða mér fulltings, er ek má harm eigi ~);
with the ears, to hear (eru þeir hér svá, at þeir megi ~ mál mitt);
6) to understand, find out (þá þóttist Þórr ~ hvat látum verity hafði of nóttina);
7) to decide, settle (skildi konungr erendi Sighvats svá, at honum líkaði vel);
8) to set apart, reserve for one (þó at konungr hafi mér skilit eignir minar eða landsvist í Orkneyjum);
eiga e-t skilit, to have reserved, stipulated (þat átta ek skilit við þik, at);
~ sér e-t, to reserve to oneself (jarðir hafði hann hygt ok skilit sér allar landskyldir);
~ e-t í sætt, to lay down, stipulate, in an agreement (þat var skilit í sæt- várri, at);
~ e-t á við e-n, to stipulate (þó vil ek ~ á við þik einn hlut);
~ e-t frá e-u, to separate from (hann skildi sik sjálfr frá ríki ok fór í klaustr);
to exeinpt from (hverr maðr skyldi gjalda konungi fimm aura, sá er eigi væri frá því skiliðr);
~ fyrir e-u, to formulate, dictate (~ fyrir eiðstafinum);
~ fyrir heiti, to formulate, pronounce a vow;
~ með mönnum, to part, separate (nótt skildi þá með þeim);
impers., skilr með þeim, they part (eptir þetta skildi með þeim);
~ e-t í sundr, to part asunder (hinir skildu í sundr skipin ok gerðu hlið í millum skipanna);
~ e-t til, to stipulate (vil ek ok til ~, at);
~ e-t undan, to except, to make a reservation for (at undan skildum, heraðssektum);
~ e-t undan e-m, to deprive one of;
~ e-t undir e-n, to leave it to one (Njáll kvaðst þat vilja ~ undir Höskuld);
~ e-n undir sætt, to include one in an agreement (hversu marga menn viltu ~ undir sættir okkar);
~ undir eið, to make an oath with reservation;
~ við e-n, to part with, put away;
~ við konu, bónda, to divorce one’s wife, one’s husband;
segja skilit við konu, to declare oneself separated from;
v. refl. to separate, break up (skildist þá ok riðlaðist fylkingin);
~ við e-n, e-t, to part from, forsake (hann kveðst aldri við Kára skyldu ~);
recipr. to part company (skildust þeir með blíðskap, feðgar);
impers., e-m skilst e-t, one perceives, understands (nú skaltu vita, hvárt mér hafi skilizt);
láta sér e-t ~, to let oneself be convinced of (Björn lét sér þat eigi ~).
1) pl. money (hón skell um hlaut fyr skillinga);
m. agreement, condition, stipulation (með þeim. skilmála, at).
m. separation, parting, divorce; at skilnaði, at parting.
vera má, at svá sé, en ek heti hina ~, but I am of the opposite opinion.
a. senseless, without understanding; skilningarlaus skepna, a brute.
n. pl. garments, hose, cap made of skin.
f. garments, hose, cap made of skin.
f. garments, hose, cap made of skin.
m. colour of the skin, complexion (døkkr, hvítr á skinnslit).

1) to arrange, place in order, draw up, with dat. (Egill ~ði svá mönnum þeim, er merkit báru); s. e-m fyrir e-t or yfir e-t, to put one in charge of; s. e-m hjá e-m, to assign a seat to one beside another (jarlinn ~ði þeim hjá Gunnlaugi); fig. to explain; s. draumi, to interpret a dream;

2) with acc. to take up, occupy; skipuðu konur pall, the women were seated on the pallr; hann ~ði öndvegi, he had his place in the high-seat; to arrange, array, s. fylking sína, to draw up one’s line of battle; var skjöldum ~t allt húsit um veggina, the walls were all hung with shields;
3) s. e-m e-t, to assign a thing to one (~ði hann nú allt land sínum sýslumönnum); also without dat. (Geirmundr ~r jarðir sínar á laun);
4) to man (skipuðu þeir skipin sem bezt); ek skal s. húskörlum mínum annat skipit, I will man one of them with my house-carles;
5) s. til e-s, to arrange, make ready for (s. til atlögu); s. til búa sinna, to put one’s household in order; þó mun eigi of ~t til ánna, there will not be too many rams for the ewes;
6) to change; bið hann, at þit skipit máldaga, ask him to change the bargain;

7) reflex., ~st, to draw up (gengu þeir þá inn allir ok skipuðust í dyrrin); skipuðust menn þar í sæti, the men took their seats; to undergo a change (mart hefir ~zt í Haukadal, ok vertu varr um þik); s. á betri leið, to change for the better; s. við e-t, to yield to, he moved by (s. við orð, fortölur e-s); s. við orðsending e-s, to answer to one’s call; þenna kost gerðum, vér Hákoni, ~ðist hann vel við, he took it in good part; impers., var heitit fyrir henni mörgu, ok ~ðist henni ekki viðr, it had no effect.
(að), v., s. e-t upp, to unload (þeir tóku land ok skipuðu þar upp).
m. the fitting out of ships, making ready for sea.
m. the fitting out of ships, making ready for sea.
n. trading with a ship in harbour.
1) order, arrangement; A. sagði, hver s. vera skyldi fyrir liði hans, how his troops should be drawn up; þessi var s. á göngu konungs til kirkju, this was the order of the royal procession;
2) manning of a ship, crew; sex skip skipuð fullri s., fully manned:
3) place, berth, as one of the crew (hann tók, sér s. með þeim manni, er Þórólfr hét);
4) due order, due course, disposition, arrangement (lét hann upp lesa bréf um s. ríkisins);
6) change; mun honum, þykkja góð a. á komin, he will think that good change has taken place.
1) shipwreck; vera í ~i, to be shipwrecked;
2) pl. pieces of a wrecked ship (ætluðu þeir at gera sér skip ór ~unum).
m. a shipwrecked person (sýna skipbrotsmanni, hvar höfn var).
f. a ship’s plank; stíga á ~, to go on board.
a. navigable for a ship (veðr hvasst ok eigi skipfœrt).
m. the ship’s share of a catch.
v. to bury in a ship.
f. the hire of a ship.
f. the camp of the Varangians at Constantinople.
s. e-u í tvá staði, to divide into two parts;
s. e-u með sér, to divide between themselves (sumum mönnum skiptu þeir með sér til ánauðar);
enda skipti guð með oss, and so may God judge between us;
3) to shift, change (s. litum, nafni, skapi);
4) þat skiptir engu (litlu, miklu), it is of no (little, great) importance, it makes no (little, great) difference;
mik skiptir engu, it is of no moment to me, does not concern me;
s. máli, to be of importance (þótti henni allmiklu máli s., at þér tœkist stórmannliga);
eiga máli at s. um e-t, to have a right to deal with, be concerned about, a thing;
þat mun tveimr s., it will turn out in one of two ways;
sér Pálnatoki, at mun tveimr um s., that it will turn out one way or the other;
þat skipti mörgum hundruðum, it was a matter of (it amounted to) many hundreds;
sitr Ólafr nú at búi sínu, svá at vetrum skipti, for several years;
ef því er at s., if it comes to that;
því er at s. þó, it will however turn out so;
6) with preps., s. sér af e-u, to take part in, concern oneself with a thing (Glúmr skipti sér ekki af um búsýslu);
s. e-u fyrir e-t, to exchange a thing for another;
undarliga skiptit ér til, ye do strangely with things;
impers., skiptir e-n veg til, it turns out, comes to pass (þannig skipti til sem úlíkligra mundi þykkja);
s. um trúnaði sínum, to go over to the other side;
s. um e-t, to change (s. um bústað, lánardróttna, nafn);
s. um, to come to a crisis, turn one way or other (skjótt mun um s.);
s. e-u við e-n, to exchange with one another (s. höggum við e-n);
s. orðum við e-n, to bandy words with one;
s. ríki við e-n, to share the kingdom with (sá hann engan annan sinn kost en s. ríki við Harald);
7) refl., ~st, to divide themselves, disperse (skiptust þeir, snøru sumir norðr); to change (þá skiptust tungur á Englandi, er Vilhjálmr bastarðr vann England);
recipr., ~st e-u við, to make an exchange;
s. gjöfum (höggum) við, to exchange presents (blows);
s. við um róðr, to row by turns.
f. the seizing of a ship.
m. loss of a ship (at sea).
1) division, distribution sharing (þér hafit land lítit, en erut margir til ~s);
2) change (mörgum þótti þetta s. mjök í móti skapi);
3) shift (þat munu Danir kalla betra s. at drepa heldr víking norrœnan en bróðurson sinn danskan);
4) pl. dealings, transactions, disputes, fights (þau ein s. munu vit eiga, at þér mun eigi betr gegna).
f. tithe to be divided into four parts.
m. one of the crew; pl., skipverjar, the crew.
f. the being one of the crew.
2) to prevent, avert, with dat. (s. vandræðum);
3) refl., ~st e-t, við e-t, to shrink from, shun.
(að), v. to cover (furnish) with a shield or shields.
m. the lower pointed end of a shield.
n. pl. old worn-out shields (~ ok baugabrot).
f. wall (rampart) of shields, an old battle-array (skipa mönnum í ~).

(skell; skall, skullum; skollinn), v. to clash, clatter (á hælum hringar skullu).
2) hann kvað sér vera ekki einkar skjallt, he said he did not feel well.
m. the side of the head.
a. shy, timid (s. sauðr); s. við e-t, shy (afraid) of (s. við skot).
2) an ill-flavoured or poisonous element (s. í mungáti).
(skelf; skalf, skulfum; skolfit), v. to shiver, shake, quiver (honum þótti s. bæði jörð ok himinn); þeygi henni hendr skulfu, her hands faltered not at all.
m., in the phrase, skjóta í skjálg augunum, to look askance.
(pl. skjáir), m. a window-frame with a transparent membrane over it, fitting to the opening (ljóri) in the roof, or to the window in the sidewall (cf. hlið~).
n. shelter, cover; skjóta ~i yfir e-n, to give shelter to.
1) to shoot with a weapon, with dat. (~ öru, spjóti, kólfi);
vera skotinn spjóti í gegnum, to be shot through with a spear;
~ af boga, to shoot with a bow;
with the object shot at in acc. (~ dýr, mann, sel, fugl);
~ at e-m, til e-s, to shoot at one;
~ til hœfis, to shoot at a mark;
2) to shoot push or shove quickly;
~ brú af, to draw the bridge off or away;
~ skildi fyrir sik, to put a shield before one;
~ loku fyrir, to shoot the bolt, lock the door;
~ skipum á vatn, to launch ships;
~ báti, to launch a boat from the shore;
~ útan báti, to shove out a boat;
~ hesti uridir e-n, to put a horse under one, to mount him;
var mér hér skotit á land, I was put ashore here;
~ e-u niðr, to thrust it down (hann skaut svá fast niðr skildinum, at);
~ e-m brott or undan, to let one escape;
~ undan peningum, to abstract, embezzle money;
~ e-u í hug e-m to suggest to one (þá skaut guð því ráði í hug þeim);
~ upp hvítum skildi, to hoist a white shield;
~ upp vita, ~ eldi í vita, to light up a beacon;
~ á fylking, to draw up in battle array;
~ á husþingi, to call a meeting together;
~ á eyrendi, to make a speech;
~ fótum undir sik, to take to one’s heels, to run;
barnit skaut öndu upp, the child began to breathe;
~ e-u of öxl, to throw off one’s shoulder;
3) to transfer a case to another;
vér tólf dómendr, er málum þessum er t il skotit, to whom these suits are handed over;
skýt ek því til gúðs ok góðra manna, at, I call God and all good men to witness, that;
4) to pay (hann skaut einn fyrir sveitunga sína alla);
5) impers., e-u skýtr upp, it shoots up, emerges, comes forth;
upp skýtr jörðunni þá ór sænum, then the earth rises from the sea;
skaut upp jörðu dag frá degi, the earth appeared day by day (as the snow melted);
þó at þér skyti því í hug, though it shot into thy mind, occurred to thee;
þeim skaut skelk í bringu, they were panic-stricken;
sem kólfi skyti, swift as a dart;
v. refl. to shoot, start, move quickly;
hann skauzt á fœtr, he started to his feet;
Björn skauzt aptr at baki Kára, B. sprang back again behind K.;
at menn hans skytist eigi frá honum, lest his men should slip away, desert;
hann vildi ljósta Gretti, en hann skauzt undan, he avoided the blow;
margir skutust honum, many forsook him;
skutust þá margir við þórð í trúnaðinum, many proved false to Thord;
hann var nökkut við aldr, ok skauzt á fótum, and tottered on his legs;
e-m skýzt yfir um e-t, one over-looks, fails to notice a thing (þeim hafði yfir skotizt um þetta);
recipr., skótast á, to exchange shots.
pp. n., gera ~ e-t mál, to hurry, be rash in a thing.
a. swift fleet (~ hestr); quick, short (skjót svör); neut., skjótt, as adv. speedily (hón bjó sik skjótt).
(gen. skjaldar, dat. skildi; pl. skildir, acc. skjöldu), m. shield;
hafa e-n at skildi fyrir sér, to have another as a shield before one;
bera efra (hærra) skjöld, to have the best of it, to gain the day;
þjóna undir þann skjöld, to serve under that standard;
leika tveim skjöldum, to play a double game;
koma í opna skjöldu, to attack in flank (from the left);
skjóta skildi yfir e-n, to protect one.
(að), v. refl. to jail (kvað Sigmundr harm skjöplazt hafa í ferðinni) to give way.
(að), v. to wash; also impers. (~ði til hafs öllu ór skipinu).

m. skulking, deceit (nökkurr s. var í skapi búand-karla).

1) to chafe, rub, gall (jarnin skoruðu mjök at beini);

3) to challenge; s. e-m (or e-n) á hólm (til hólmgöngu, til hólms, til einvígis), to challenge to a duel;

4) s. á e-n, to call upon, request strongly (þeir skoruðu á hann fast); s. á e-n til e-s, to call upon one for a thing (s. á. e-n til liðveizlu, fulltings); s. á e-n til hólmgöngu, to challenge one to fight;
5) to urge insist upon (fast ~r þú þat); s. e-t mál við e-n, to broach a matter to one (konungr ~r þá þetta mál við hana sjálfa);
6) s. e-t í, to stipulate (Þ. ~ði þat í, at);
7) to score, count by tallies (hann lét þá s. liðit).
(að), v. to shrivel up (~r skór at fœti mér); fig. ~r at, it presses hard (þér mun þykkja mjök at s.).
pp. n., used as adv., short of; var hann þar litit s. viku, he was there little short of a week.

(-rti, -rt), v. to be lacking to one (eigi mun þik karlmenska s.); mostly impers., e-n skortir e-t, one is in want of, is short of; ekki skortir ykkr áhuga, ye do not lack heart; e-n skortir við e-n, to be one’s inferior, fall short of one; honum þótti sik s. við oss, he thought he fell short of us; skortir á e-t, it is lacking; þat er á skorti, what was lacking.
f. stay, prop (setja skorður undir skip); fig., reisa (setja) skorður við e-u, to put a stop to, take precautions against.
(að), v. to prop, support by shores (þeir skorðuðu skipit).
1) shooting, shot (þóttist Þ. eigi hafa skotit betra ~);
2) the thing shot missile, = skeyti (ef fleiri ~ eru í hvalnum);
3) appeal; er til hans miklu minna ~ en margir láta yfir, there is less appeal to (less worth in) him than folks say;
4) a narrow dark passage, running along the wall of the ancient hall (gekk hann inn ok í ~, er var um eldahúsit).
m. ‘shooting-bank’, butts (fóru þeir í skotbakka ok vöndust við skot).
koma í ~, to come within shot;
liggja í skotfœrum við, to be within bow-shot.
a. composed in the metre skothenda.
m. a dead whale with a harpoon in it.
koma í ~, to come within range.

m. target; hafa e-n at skotspæni, to make a butt of one.

m. a wand to he shot.
(að), v. to look after, view, review (konungr halði ~t lið sitt);
(að), v. to prate, chat; recipr., ~st við, to talk together.
2) dried fish, = skörp ~ (skorti bæði mjöl ok ~).
m. a cargo, pile of dried fish.
m. a cargo, pile of dried fish.

1) to slip; skruppu honum fœtr, his feet slipped;
2) to slip away, absent oneself, margir bœjarmenn skruppu inn í garða sína, skulked away into their homesteads.
m. the contents of a scrip (skreppa ok allr ~).
(-tta, -ttr), v. to ornament, adorn, dress fine (skreyttr inum beztum klæðum).
1) to draw, paint (sögur þær, er ~ðar váru á eldhúsinu);
2) to write (eptir því sem fróðir menn hafa ~t).
n. monster (s. þau, er þar vafra í höfum umhverfis).
1) picture, drawing (seglit var sett með fögrum ~um);
3) confession (to a priest); veita e-m s., to confess one; ganga til ~ar, ~a, to go to confession;
5) punishment (tröll kváðu Kaldrana hata fengit makliga s. fyrir sinn tilverknað).
1) to shrive, confess, hear the confession of, with dat. (biskup fór at s. þeim);
2) to enjoin penance (s. e-m at vatnfasta);
3) to punish (váru sumir hálshöggnir, en sumum annan veg ~t);
4) with acc. to confess (s. sinar syndir);
5) refl., ~st við e-n, to confess to (~ðist S. við Þormóð prest); láta s., to go to confession.
m. a man under penance, penitent.
f. landslip, avalanche (hljóp s. á bœinn).
(að), v. to slip, slide; ~ði hann öðrum fœti, he slipped with one foot; skriðnuðu honum fœtr, his feet slipped; s. or s. í sundr, to come to an end (mest ván, at við þetta skriðni várt félag).
(gen. -ar), m. a creeping or gliding motion, of a reptile (beina þeir sinn skrið); of a ship, forward movement, course, speed; tók skriðinn af skipinu, the ship stopped.
(~ða), v. to sneak about (Narfi ~ði um it ytra).
1) piece of dry skin or parchment;
2) a scroll for writing on, a written scroll;
setja á ~, to commit to writing;
1) to put on a scroll, enter (at ~ nöfn þeira allra);
2) to enrol (E. lét lesa upp, hverir skráðir váru á konungsskipit).
(see setja), v. to put on a scroll, enter, enroll, = skrá.
(-ð), v. refl. to act like a coward, be a poltroon.
(-kta, -kt), v. to screech, shriek (hrafn skrækti hátt).
masc.pl. the native inhabitants of Vínland in America.

1) to creep, crawl, of reptiles; hann brást í orms líki ok skreið í nafars-raufina, he transformed himself to a serpent and crept into the auger-hole; of persons (hann skreið upp í fjöruna); s. undir skegg e-m, to creep under another’s beard, to humble oneself; saman níðingar ~, ‘birds of a feather flock together’;
2) of a ship, to glide, sail (þú skynjar eigi, hvárt skipit skríðr undir þér eða eigi);

(dat. ~vi), n. false story, falsehood, invention (hvárt þat væri s. eða sannindi).
4) costly stuff (sem af ~i einu væri gör seglin).

2) with dat. to make stiff and bristly (hann skrýfði sem mest hárinu).
refl., ~st e-u, to put on, dress in (s. hárklæðum, sorgarbúnaði).
1) shadow; berr skugga á e-t, a shadow falls upon (þar bar skuggann á sæinn af fjöllunum); bar hvergi skugga á, there was no shadow anywhere;
2) shade of a hat (undan skugga hattarins);
3) shadow, spectre (henni sýndist þa kirkjan full af hræði- ligum skuggum);

4) fig., ganga ór skugga um e-t, to show one’s mind as to a thing; hann bað Halldór ganga ór skugga, hvárt, he asked H. to say plainly, whether; hann sagði sér vera mikinn skugga á, hvat Magnús mundi ætlast fyrir, he said he felt much mis-giving as to what M. had in mind.
1) debt; gjalda s., to pay a debt; kaupa í s., to buy on trust; ganga í s. fyrir e-n, to be bail for another; ganga í s. við e-n, to become one’s debtor;
2) tax, due (ek vissi, at þer áttuð at réttu s. ok skatt af at taka).
f. = skyld; fyrir þann (= þá) s., at, because that.

(pres. skal, ~m; pret. skyldu; pret. infin. skyldu), v. shall (denoting fate, law, bidding, necessity, duty, obligation, purpose); þat skal Eyjólfr gøra, E. shall do that; hvat skal ek honum, what shall I do with him? vega skaltu hann, thou shalt kill him; hvat skal tjald þat, what is that tent for?; hón spurði, hvat þat skyldi, she asked what was the meaning of that.
1) to speed, = skynda, with dat. (s. ferð sinni); s. fé saman, to make a collection;
m. speed, haste (með skunda, með miklum skunda).
f. a woman’s hood hiding the face.
a. covered with scurf, scurfy (af skurfóttum manni).
4) ditch, channel (s. svá breiðr ok djúpr, at þar mátti vel skipum halda); grafa skurð, to dig a ditch;
5) carving, of art (silfri var rennt í skurðina).
m. pl. ‘stern-mates’, the men stationed in the stern of a ship.
f. cable from the stern, stern moorings.
2) dish, trencher, small table (hón gaf Sveini konungi ágætan skutil).
(-ar, -ir), m. the stern of a ship; in pl. stem and stern (skip minna til skutanna en um mitt).

(að), v. to make a gurgling sound (sökk øxin ok ~ði við).

3) to polish, with acc. (s. sverð þau, er áðr eru forn).
pp. bright, polished (hjálmr s. sem gler).
1) seeing (hann hafði fengit sýn sína ok var þá s. maðr);
2) sharp-sighted (E. var einsýnn ok þó manna ~astr).
(-da), v. to pry, spy; s. um e-t, at e-u, to spy after, look for;
refl., ~st um, to look about (skygndist hann nú um fast).
m. eyesight, power of vision (augun með björtum skygnleik).
f. pl. wide open eyes (H. rak þá s. á landit).
dat. pl. as adv., ganga s., to go rocking; gekk jörðin undir þeim s., the earth went rocking, under them, of an earthquake.
3) reason, sake; fyrir mína s., for my sake.
1) to bind in duty, oblige (konungrum ~ði þá til at flytja líkin til graptar);
2) s. til e-s, to deserve, merit.
1) due, tax, tribute (fekk hann þaðan engar skyldur né skatta);
2) duty (er þat yðvarr réttr ok s. at verja ríki várt);
3) relationship (eigi veit ek, at með okkr sé nein s.).
pp. bound, obliged (ek em s. til at reka konungs eyrendi).
adv. duly, dutifully; þurfa ~, to stand in pressing need of.
a., e-m er e-t skyldligtt, it is one’s duty.
1) bound, obliged (ef þér veitit mér þat, þá verð ek s. til at gøra yðvarn vilja);
3) urgent, pressing (skylt erendi); mér er skylt, it’s my bounden duty (þat mun konungi skylt þykkja, at ek fara);
4) related; s. at frændsemi, related by kinship; mér er maðrinn s., the man is near akin to me; skyld frændsemi, near kinship.
3) vera s. e-m, to owe to one.
(d), v. refl., to fence with a weapon (s. með skjöld ok sverð).

(pl. -jar), f. sense, knowledge, understanding; vita, kunna, hafa s. (or skynjar) á e-u, to have knowledge of, understand (Flosi kvazt eigi vita s. á, hverir lögmenn væri mestir); hann kunni allra s. í borginni, he knew all the people in the town; bera s. yfir e-t, to have knowledge of a thing, understand it; gjalda s. fyrir e-t, to give account of, account for; Loki sagði s. á öllum gripum, explained all the objects.
1) to hasten, with dat. (s. ferð sinni); s. sér, to hasten, make haste;
2) to hasten, = s. sér (hann skyndi til skipa).
f. speed, haste; af ~u, in haste, speedily.
m. haste; bera skyndi at um e-t, to make haste with.
1) to perceive, make out, understand (þeir ~ skjótt, hverir höfðingjar vóru vinir Magnúss konungs);
2) to search into, inquire (Þ. bað menn sína s., ef hann þyrfti liðs við); s. vörð or um vörð, to inspect the guard.
a. senseless; skynlaus skepna, skynlaust kvikendi, an irrational being, brute.

f. reason; vera með fullri ~, to be in one’s right senses (þá er vér erum údrukknir ok með fullri ~); kunna litla ~, to have little understanding (kunnum vér litla ~ til at skipa svá stórum málum); hafa ~ af e-u, to have knowledge of; þá muntu synja þess með ~, then thou must deny it, giving reasons for it; gjalda ~ e-s, af e-u, to give account of; krefja e-n ~ar fyrir e-t, af e-u, to call one to account for a thing.
n., vera með ~i, to be in one’s right senses.
f. = skynsemd; mikil ~ er at rifja vandliga þat, much knowledge is wanted to explain all that.
n. a kind of curdled milk.
f. shirt, a kind of kirtle.
f. the making of a shirt.
I) m. marksman, shooter, harpooner (~ allra manna beztr).
m. inn or club, where each guest paid or contributed his own scot (hann veitti allri hirð sinni mat ok mungát, svá at engi maðr þurfti í skytning at ganga).
m. relief, improvement (varð engi ~ á hans meini).
2) scale, esp. pl., scales (bað hann taka skálir ok vega gullit).
f. pl. the doorway of a skáli.
n. the constellation Libra (gengr sól fyr ~).
f. the site of a (former) skáli.
1) hut, shed (put up for temporary use);
2) hall, room (cf. drykkju~, elda~, for~, kvenna~), esp. sleeping-hall.
1) prong (tók hann birkirapt ok reiddi um öxl, svá at hann hélt um ~irnar);
a. compar., better; þat mun þér ráð skást, it will be most advisable for thee.
a. superl., best; þat mun þér ráð skást, it will be most advisable for thee.
a. skilled or versed in poetry (lítt em ek s.).
m. a case for holding a pair of shears.
n. pl. a pair of shears.
2) clear, bright, serene (s. himinn, skært veðr);
(-ða, -ðr), v. to slice, cut into slices (mátti þar sjá hjálma skífða).
(skín; skein, skinum; skininn), v. to shine (veðr var fagrt, skein sól í heiði); impers., mun s. af í dag, it will clear up today.
1) to cleanse, purify (s. silfr); skira sik, to clear (pure) oneself by an oath or ordeal;
2) to baptize, christen (skírði prestr barnit); láta ~st, to be baptized.
a. bright; ~ í yfirbragði, at yfirlitum, bright of countenance.
f. baptism, christening; halda barni undir s., to stand godfather; taka s., to be baptized.
1) clear, bright, pure, of glass, metal, water, sky, etc. (s. mjöðr, skírt vatn, s. málmr, skírt silfr);
2) cleansed from guilt (hón skal øruggliga bera mega þetta járn ok skír verða);
(að), v. to refer or submit to judgement (E. ~ði þessum órskurði undir þá menn alla, er við vóru), or to testimony (~ e-u undir e-n, e-u fyrir e-m, e-u við vitni e-s); ~ til e-s, to appeal to.
f. = skírsl; fig. gera skírslu til e-s, to put to the test.
n. = skírsl; fig. gera skírslu til e-s, to put to the test.
þeir fuglar, er í sitt hreiðr ~, that foul their own nest.
2) esp. pl., long snowshoes, ‘ski’ (fara, renna, skriða, kunna á skíðum).
n. lintel; hurð vár á skíði, the door was shut.
f. piece of split wood, billet, stick, = skíð 1 (klauf hann þar Þór í skíður einar ok lagði síðan í eld).
n. going or travelling on snow-shoes.
f. going or travelling on snow-shoes.
a. good at travelling on snow-shoes.
m. wooden palings, wooden fence (Þ. hleypr yfir skíðgarð nökkurn).
m. snow-sledge shaped like a snow-shoe.
m. snow-sledge shaped like a snow-shoe.
m. a dweller near a wood.
n. damage done to a wood.
f. a case or suit involving outlawry.

(-ar, -ar), m. wood, forest (var þá s. milli fjalls ok fjöru); fara í skóg; to go foresting; stefna e-m til skógar, to summon a person with intent to outlaw him; leysa e-n ór skógi, to free one from outlawry.
m. school (þeir váru báðir saman í skóla).
(gen. skós, pl. skúar, later skór), m.
1) shoe; kippa skóm á fœtr sér, to pull on one’s shoes; leysa skúa af e-m, to untie a person’s shoes;
2) horse-shoe (þótt skúarnir hryti undan hestum þeira).
a. wet on the shoes, wet-footed.
(-s, -ar), m. the shin, shin-bone (skeinast á sköfnungunum).
f. loud, scornful laughter, mockery (gøra mikla s. at e-m).
I) (gen. skammar, pl. skammir), f. shame;
lifa við ~, to live in shame;
er þat ~ at sitja hjá, it is a shame to sit idly by;
fœra ~ at e-m, gøra e-m ~, to bring dishonour on one;
veiða at ~, to be put to shame.
1) what is fated, one’s fate, doom (eigi má við sköpunum sporna); ef at sköpum ferr, if it goes according to the natural course of things;
2) curse (þá er konunga-börn urðu fyrir stjúpmœðra sköpum);
3) with the article, sköpin, the genitals.

1) rim, edge; allt út at skörinni, to the rim of the ice; fig., skríða til skarar, to slide to the very edge, come to a crisis (skal nú til skarar skríða með okkr Knúti bróður mínum); tjaldskör, edge of a tent; spretta skörum, to lift the edges of the tent;
2) the joints in a ship’s planking (skipit hafði bilat at skörunum, þá er fram var sett);
3) step (þeir skyldu sitja í hásæti skör hærra en jarlar, en skör lægra en sjálfr hann);
4) hair; ~ nam at dýja, he tossed his locks; ~ var fyrir enni, the hair was cut across the forehead; rautt mun sjá í skörina, there will be bloody locks;
1) bold, manly, imposing in appearance (manna sköruligastr at sjá);
2) magnificent, fine (skörulig veizla, rœða); með sköruligum flutningi, with manly pleading.
1) foreman, leader (nema hann gerðist ~ fyrir þessu máli);
2) a prominent or outstanding person, a notable man or woman (var Þorkell vitr maðr ok ~ mikill).
m. nobleness, manliness (með miklum ríkdóm ok skörungskap).
(að), v. to shoe; s. hest sinn gullskóm, to shoe his horse with golden shoes; of persons (vel hosaðr ok skúaðr).
(gen. pl. skúatna), f. a small craft, skiff (hrundu þeir fram skútu).
f. taunt; drepa e-m skútu um e-t, to taunt one with.
(-tti, -tt), v. to jut out (bjargit skútti yfir fram).
1) a cave formed by jutting rocks;
2) taunt; stinga e-m skúta, to taunt one.
(gen. pl. skýja), n. cloud; skýjum efri, above the clouds.
(-ða, -ðr), v. to shove, push, with dat. (látit mik vera kyrra ok skýfit mér hvergi); with acc. (þeir skýfðu skurðgoðin af stöllum).
(að), v. to cloud, cover with clouds; impers., en nú ~r á heldr, but now it clouds over.
(-da, -dr), v. to screen, shelter, protect, with dat. (hvalr skýldi skipinu við veðrinu).
n. damaging cut, with an axe (þar lá tréstobbi mikill ok í ~ mikil).
(-ða, -ðr), v. to explain, expound, set forth, interpret (kveðst s. mundu fyrir honum, ef hann vildi vita); s. spurdaga, to solve or answer a question.
1) clear, evident, manifest (með skýrum sannindum); neut. skýrt, as adv. clearly, distinctly (Arnórr kveðr skýrt á þetta);
2) clever, intelligent (s. maðr ok skáld gott).
f. scoff, taunt (svara e-m ~u or af ~u).
(-dda, -ddr), v.; skœðir hann sik, he puts on his shoes.
n. pl. a piece of skin cut square for making a pair of shoes (var þá skorin yxnis-húðin til skœða).
a. scatheful, noxious (skœðar tungur); skœðir vargar, wild beasts.
1) blow, stroke (~ undir kinnnina); eigast slög við, to come to blows;
2) fig. blow, defeat; veita, gefa e-m ~, to defeat;
3) skirmish, opp. to a pitched battle (jarl átti tvær fólk-orrustur, en mörg slög ok manndráp);
4) nick of time (í þessu slagi koma þeir af sér akkerinu).
(að), v. to flow over, be spilt (féll ofan ketillinn ok ~ði á sveininn ór katlinum).
2) tune, air, played on a stringed instrument (konungr spurði, hvárt hann kynni eigi fleiri slagi).
f. a ewe to be slaughtered.
(að), v. to make a bubbling noise (~ði í sárinu).
f. slaver (úlfrinn grenjar, ok ~ renn ór munni hans).
verða milli steins ok sleggju, to come between the hammer and the anvil.
(-ta, -tr), v. to lick (kýrin gekk opt ofan í fjöruna ok sleikti steinana).
f. shuffle, subterfuge, esp. pl., drekka við sleitur, to drink unfairly.
1) to slip, glide (sleggjan slapp ór hendi honum); sluppu honum fœtr, his feet slipped;
2) to slip away, escape (ef Þórólfr skal s.);
3) to slip, fail; ef yðr sleppr at festa hendr á Birni, if you fail to get hold of Bjorn.
(-ta, -t), v. to make slip out of one’s hands, let slip; Þorgils hafði sleppt øxinni, Th. had let go of the axe.
adv. feebly; með því at þeim hafði svá s. til tekizt, as they had had such poor success.
1) to slap; hann sletti flötu sverðinu um herðar honum, he slapped him with the flat of the sword;
2) to dash, splash (A. þreif upp skyrkyllinn ok sletti framan í fang Grettis).
2) tear and wear; kápa komin at sliti, a worn-out cloak;
1) to break, snap, of a cord, rope, string (festr mun s.);
2) to end, break up (þú vilt, at okkarr kaupmáli slitni).
refl., ~st, to grow blunt or dull (sýn, minni ~st).
a. extinguished (þegar at ljós váru slokin).
(að), v. to expire, go out (eldr, ljós, log ~r).
pp. extinguished, = slokinn (þá er s. var eldrinn).
(-s, -ar), m. loose gown; esp. of a priest’s white gown (skrýddr sloppum ok kantarakápum).
(að), v. to hang down (lið hans lét s. hendr niðr með síðu ok höfðust ekki at); s. við, to be idle, slink away.
(að), v. to drag or trail oneself along (sloðruðu þeir þá vestr af heiðinni).
a. dextrous, clever (hann var s. við allar íþróttir).

(slyng; slöng, slungum; slunginn), v. with dat. to sling, throw, fling (því næst slyngr Surtr eldi yfir jörðina); sungu ok slungu snúðga steini, they sang and swung the swift millstone; var þessu kaupi slungit, this bargain was struck; í vandkvæði er slungit, we are in difficulties; döggu slunginn, bedewed; slunginn vafrloga, encircled by a flickering flame; horna-tog ver slungit af silfri, twisted of silver.
a. unarmed, weaponless (nú kalla ek, at Hrafn sé sigraðr, er hann er ~).
1) mishap, mischance, accident (s. mun þat þykkja, er hann hjó hönd af konu sinni);
2) wrong-doing, mischief (erfitt mun þér verða at bœta öll s. Hallgerðar).
a. n. e-m verðr ~, one has bad luck.
adv. unfortunately; vildi mér svá ~ til, at ek braut spjót mitt, I had the ill-luck to break my spear; takast s., to come off badly.
(slæ; sló, slógum; sleginn; pret. also sleri), v.
1) to smite, strike (~ e-n högg, kinnhest);
2) ~ hörpu, fiðlu, to strike the harp, fiddle;
~ slag, to strike up a tune;
~ leik, to strike up, begin, a game;
~ vef, to strike the web, to weave;
3) to hammer, forge (~ gull, silfr, sverð);
~ e-t e-u, to mount with (járnum sleginn);
4) to cut grass, mow (~ hey, töðu, tún, eng);
5) to slay, kill (síns bróður sló hann handbana);
6) fig., ~ kaupi, to strike a bargain;
~ máli í sátt, to refer a matter to arbitration;
~ fylking, to draw up a line of battle;
~ manngarð, mannhring, to form a ring of men round;
~ eldi í e-t, to set fire to;
~ landtjöldum, to pitch a tent, or also, to strike a tent, take it down;
~ netjum, to put out the nets;
~ hundum lausum, to slip the hounds;
~ á e-t, to take to a thing;
~ á glens ok glúmur, to take to play and sport;
~ á heit, to take to making a vow;
~ e-u á sik, to take upon one-self;
~ á sik sótt, to feign illness;
~ á sik úlfúð, to show anger or ill-will;
ekki skaltu slíku á þik ~, do not betake thyself to that;
impers., sló á hann hlátri, he was taken with a fit of laughter;
sló ótta á marga, many were seized with fear;
því slær á, at, it so happens that;
ljóssi sleri (= sló) fyrir hann, a light flashed upon him;
~ í deilu, to begin quarrelling (eitt kveld, er þeir drukku, slógu þeir í deilu mikla);
impers., slær í e-t, it arises;
slær þegar í bardaga, it came to a fight;
~ niðr e-u, to put an end to;
nú er niðr slegit allri vináttu, now there is an end to all friendship;
~ sér niðr, to lie down, take to one’s bed;
~ e-u saman, to join (þeir ~ þá saman öllu liðinu í eina fylking);
~ til e-s, to aim a blow at one, strike at one;
~ undan höfuð-bendunum, to slacken the stays;
~ e-u upp, to spread a report;
~ upp herópi, to raise the war-cry;
impers., loganum sló upp ór keröldunum, the flame burst out of the vessels;
~ út e-u, to pour out (þá er full er mundlaugin, gengr hón ok slær út eitrinu);
~ e-u við, to take into use (þá var slegit við öllum búnaði);
~ við segli, to spread the sail;
ek hefi þó náliga öllu við slegit, því er ek hefi í minni fest, I have put forth almost all that I recollected;
~ beizli við hest, to put a bridle on a horse;
e-u slær yfir, it comes over, arises (slær yfir þoku svá myrkri, at engi þeirra sá annan);
(pl. ~r), f. bar, bolt, cross-beam (~ ein var um þvert skipit).
~ aptr, to draw back (gæta þess, at eigi slœgist aptr liðit);
~ á e-t, to take to a thing (~ á svikræði við e-n);
~ á tal við e-n, to enter into conversation with;
~ á bak e-m, to go behind another;
slóst hón fram at eldinum, she rushed to the fireside;
~ í för með e-m, to join one in a journey;
~ í sveit með e-m, to join one’s party;
slógust í Suðreyjar víkingar, vikings invaded the Hebrides;
~ til ferðar með e-m = ~ í för með e-m.
n. flesh-meat (hafði þá Loki etit ~ allt af beinum).
(að), v. to slaughter, with dat. (þar hafði ~t verit uxa einum).
m. a head of cattle for slaughter.
2) mowing season (þat var um öndverðar sláttur);
Haralds ~, the bad coin of King Harold.
refl., ~ðist skap jarlsins, his wrath abated.
adv. without energy, = sljóliga (róa, sœkja at ~).
(-tta, -ttr), v. to make plain, level; fig., s. yfir e-t, to smooth over a thing, amend, remedy (hafit ér vel yfir slétt vanhyggju mína).

a. plain, flat, even, smooth; s. völlr, level field; s. sjór, smooth sea; segja sínar farar eigi sléttar, to tell of one’s journey not having been smooth, to report a failure; neut. slétt, as adv. straight, quite (gengu þeir slétt út af borðunum); smoothly, well (tala slétt); eigi mundi ferðin takast slétt, the journey would not go smoothly.
1) such; s. maðr, such a man; s. sem (or er), such as; s. svá, such like, similar (slíkir svá menn); annarr s., another of the same kind;
3) neut., slíkt, as adv. in such wise, so; slíkt er þér líkar, as it pleases thee; slíkan, similarly, in a like manner (hygg ek, at slíkan mun hafa farit um annat).
n. slime (þegar eptir þat heit dró af slímit auganu).
1) to snap, break, a string, cord, rope (Æsirnir sýndu honum silkibandit ok báðu hann s.); s. í sundr, to break asunder (s. í sundr svá mjótt band);

2) to tear, pull; Loki sleit upp mistiltein, L. pulled up the mistletoe; ~ ná, hræ, to tear a corpse; s. e-n af sér, to throw one off (S. vildi s. hann af sér); sleit hann undan veðr, the gale drove him out of his course;
3) fig. to break, break off, with acc.; s. þing, to break off, dissolve a meeting; with dat. (s. þingi, flokki, veizlunni); áðr þinginu sé slitit, before the meeting be dissolved;
4) to rend, tear (brynja hans var slitin til únýts); klæði sundr slitin, torn asunder;
5) to wear-out; hann mun eigi mörgum skyrtunum s., he will not wear out many shirts, not live long; slitnir skór, worn-out shoes;
6) s. ór e-u, to decide, settle (hann kvað lögmann ór þessu s. skyldu);

7) impers. to be torn away (sleit af honum mann á báti); with dat., slítr þar tali þeirra, there the talk ended; sleit Fróða frið fjánda á milli, Frodi’s peace was broken between the foes; borgir ok kastalar ok þorp, svá at hvergi slítr, in an unbroken line; þar til er ór slítr með þeim, till it comes to an end;
8) refl., ~st, to tear oneself loose (s. ór höndum e-m).
a. fierce, cruel, fearful (hefndir ~ar ok sárar).
(að), v. to sheathe, put in the scabbard (s. kníf, sverð).
f. pl. sheath, scabbard (stinga sverð í ~; draga, bregða sverði ór slíðrum).
a. sharp as a a razor.
f. pl. sheath, scabbard (stinga sverð í ~; draga, bregða sverði ór slíðrum).
f. track, trail (sáu menn s. liggja frá skipunum, því at dögg hafði fallit); cf. döggslóð.
m. a truss of branches trailed along; draga slóða, to drag a slot or trail; fig., meira slóða mun draga, it will be attended with more serious consequences.
1) to extinguish, put out (heimamenn sløktu eldinn);
(-ða), v. to throw with a sling, fling, hurl; with dat. (sløngvir hann þá stokkinum út af þekjunni).
f. sling (tók D. sér sløngu í hönd); cf. ‘val~’.
1) to cheat, entice, ensnare (s. hug e-s ok hjarta);
2) impers., e-n slœgir til e-s, one has a mind to, desires; eigi slœgir mik hér til langvista í Norvegi, I am not tempted to linger here in Norway;

3) refl., ~st til e-s, to seek for a thing, of gain; hér er til lítils at s., but little profit to be had; Þórðr unni henni lítit, hafði hann mjök slœgzt til fjár, Th. loved her but little, and had married her for her money’s sake.
m. a purse to hold one’s gain.
m. gain, profit; vil ek sjá hann ok virða fyrir mér, hverr s. mér þykkir í vera, and consider what I think he is worth; þykki mér þó meiri s. til hans, I think there is more good in him.
(acc. -jan), a. sly, cunning, crafty (s. í skaplyndi).
(-da, -dr), v. to make a side blow at one (hann slœmir til hans øxinni); with acc., s. undan e-m fœtrna, to cut off one’s feet.
m. the third and last division of a poem (drápa).
1) to trail; fax svá sítt, at slœddi jörð, that it trailed on the ground;
2) to spread manure, by means of slóðahrís.
f. pl. a gown that trails along the ground (s. af silki, pelli).
f. tending sheep in the pastures.
f. tending sheep in the pastures.
f. shepherd’s mound; sitja á smalaþúfu, to tend sheep.
(-ða, -t), v. to slip, with dat.; smeygði hann lykkjunni af hálsi sér, he slipped the loop off is neck; hann smeygði á sik brókunum, he pulled the trousers on;
refl., ~st, to free oneself (smeygðist Egill af stafnum); s. undan af sannindunum, to slip away from the truth.
f. a booth used as a smity.
f. pl. door of a smithy.
(-s; pl. -ar and -ir), m. smith, wright, worker in metal or wood.
f. the rim running along the back of a scythe-blade to give it strength (ljár máðr upp í ~).
(smýg; smaug or smó, smugum; smoginn), v.

1) to creep through an opening; smugu þeir milli spalanna, they crept between the bars; smýgr hann þá niðr undir hjá henni, he creeps under the bed-clothes; to put on a garment with only a round hole to put the head through (gullbrynju smó);
2) to pierce (kom lásör í brúnina ok smó þegar í gegnum).
f. narrow cleft to creep through, small hole (hvergi fannst s. á).
f. anointing; hin síðasta s., extreme unction.
n. pl. the dress in which one receives extreme unction.
(smyr, smurða, smurðr), v. to anoint (s. konung til veldis); to rub with ointment (hann smurði hörund hennar með góðum smyrslum).
(smáða, smáðr), v. to scorn, slight, revile (s. e-n í orðum).
m. pl. small cups, slight hollows.
f. shame, disgrace (þessi s. ok svívirðing, er þú gørir mér).

2) neut., hann seldi smátt varninginn, he sold by retail; höggva smátt, to strike small blows; hann kvaðst eigi mundu smátt á sjá, he said he would deal liberally in the matter; smátt ok smátt, bit by bit, by degrees;
3) smám, bit by bit, slowly (fara smám).
m. pl. plains of fine sand.
a. creeping through the smallest hole; fig. minute, subtle.

2) work of skill or art, structure (Bifröst er gör með list ok kunnáttu meiri en aðrar smíðir).

1) to turn quickly, twist, wring; K. ~r skjöldinn svá fast, at spjótit brotnaði, K. twists the shield so smartly that the spear broke; hann ~r af honum höfuðit, he wrings off his head;
2) to translate (s. bók upp í norrœnu);

6) refl., ~st, to turn oneself (pass) quickly (hann ~st fram hjá þeim); S. ~st þá út ór stofunni, then S. hastens out of the room; s. við e-m, to turn quickly towards one (M. ~ðist við honum ok mæIti); s. í karlföt, to dress in man’s clothes.
1) snare; leggja snörur fyrir e-n, to lay or spread snares for one;

1) roughness; ~ næfra, the roughness of the bark;

a. sharp, dashing (með fylktu liði ok snarpligu).

5) neut., snart, as adv. soon, quickly (rann hann at sem snarast).

hverr á þessa s., who is meant by this slight?
stinga e-m ~, to cut with sarcasm.
2) to taunt, make game of, with dat. (slíkt er illa mælt at s. honum afgömlum);

f. a swift-sailing ship (A. átti langskip, þat var s. tvítugsessa).

1) short (gøra stutt skegg ok snøggvan kamp); þeir bitu allt gras at snøggu, they bit it close;
3) sudden, brief (orrosta hörð ok snøgg); neut., snøggt, as adv. soon, quickly (þá dró snøggt undan).
snýr jarl þangat herinum, the earl turns his host thither;

~ aptr ferð sinni, to turn back;

~ brott, to go away (maðrinn sneri þá brott);
3) to change, alter (hann sneri síðan nafni sínu);
~ skapi sínu, to change one’s mind;
4) to turn, twist, twine (~ vönd í hárit);
6) impers., snýr e-u, it is turned (snøri þá mannfalli í lið Kirjala); it changes (brátt sneri fjáærhaginum fyrir Teiti, er G. var í brottu);
~ at e-m, to turn on one;
snúm vér nú at þeim, let us turn upon them;
halt svá hendi yfir honum, at øngri hefnd sé til hans snúit, protect him so that no vengeance may befall him;
~ e-u til leiðar, to bring about;
skiptir mik miklu, hversu þú vilt til ~, what turn thou wilt take;
~ e-u um, to turn upside down, upset (um snýr þú öllum, sætunum); to change completely (hón kvaðst hafa ætlat at ~ þar um lands-lagi öllu);

v. refl. to turn oneself (hafði Gunnarr snúizt í hauginum);
~ at e-m, í móti e-m, við e-m, to turn upon one, face about, to meet an attack;
svá snerist, at þeir kómust í engan lífs-háska, it turned out so, that they got into no danger of life;
~ til leiðar, to turn to the right way;
~ til e-s um e-t, to turn to one for a thing (er þat líkast, at hann snúist til várrar ættar um vinfengit);
~ undan, to draw back (síðan vildi A. undan ~).

a. swift (sungu ok slungu snúðga steini); neut., snúðigt, as adv. swiftly; fara, ganga snúðigt, to march, walk at a swinging pace.

1) to blow the nose (s. sér); s. rauðu, to get a bloody nose;

1) to spare (hann sparir eigi peninga Þórólfs); s. e-m e-t, to leave it to another (spörum þetta verk öðrum); s. e-n til e-s, to spare one from (þeir spörðu hana eigi til erfiðis ok skaprauna); skal ek eigi mitt til s., I, for my part, shall not be sparing in the matter; s. e-t við e-n, to withhold from one (eigi spari ek mat við þik); s. e-t við sik, to shrink from; hverr sá er, at eigi sparir þat úhapp við sik, who does not shrink from that crime;

2) refl., ~st til e-s, to shrink from, forbear (hefi ek lengi til þessa ~zk); to spare oneself, spare one’s strength; þat orð flyzt af, at þú sparist við, that thou sparest thyself, dost not use all thy strength.
(að), v. to kick; also fig. (at ölmusur sparki í andlit mér).
a. lively, brisk (sparkar áttu vér konur).
n. leniency; reka ~ við e-n, to spare, deal leniently with.

f. wisdom (sú s., er hann sagði fyrir úorðna hluti).

(spakta, spaktr), v. to calm, soothe (s. menn sína);

1) to span, clasp (s. sverð báðum höndum); hon spennti hringinn á hönd honum, she clasped the ring round his wrist; s. e-u um sik, s. sik e-u, to gird oneself with, buckle on (hann spennti sik megingjörðum); s. af sér beltinu, to unclasp the belt;
2) to clasp the hands round one’s neck, = s. höndum um háls e-m (þykki þér betra at s. karlsdóttur);
3) to clasp, catch, capture (prestr nökkurr gekk á land; Birkibeinar spenntu hann); harðliga spenntr, in hard straits;
4) to spend (eptir ár liðit skal ek segja þér, hvat þú spennir);

2) to destroy, kill (s. ætla ek báðum);

n. track, footprint (þeir rekja s. sem hundar); ganga (stíga) í s. e-m, to walk in one’s footsteps, follow one’s example (víst hefir þú vel fram gengit, en þó hefir þú eigi gengit mér í s.); ekki spor, not a step.
f. backing, assistance (veita e-m fylgd ok sporgöngu).

a. n., hafði fallit lítil snæfölva svá at ~ var, so that it was possible to trace the footprints.

(-s, -ar), m. tail of a fish, serpent, etc. (s. sem á fiski); standa e-m á sporði, to be a match for, be one’s superior (vitr maðr ertu, Eyólfr, svá at fáir munu standa á sporði þér); s. skjaldar, the lower pointed end of a shield (þreif B. sporð skjaldarins hinni hendinni ok rak í höfuð Þórði).
n. mockery, scoff (þú ferr með s. ok háð); gøra (draga) s. at e-u, hafa e-t at ~i, to scoff at, turn into ridicule.
(að), v. to mock, make sport of (eigi þarf at s. þetta svá mjök); s. at e-u, to jeer about a thing; s. e-t af e-m, to cheat one of a thing.

a. mocking, given to jibes (spottrsamr ok údœll).
(-da, -dr), v. to make burst (H. kvezt eigi mundu s. sik á grauti); s. hest, to break the wind of a horse.
m. bursting; honum hélt við spreng, he was near bursting from exhaustion; vinna til sprengs, to work oneself to death.
1) to spring up, issue forth (þar sprettr einn mikill brunnr);
spratt honum sveiti í enni, sweat burst out on his forehead;
also s. upp (spratt þar vatn upp);
s. af baki, to spring off horseback;
s. á fœtr, s. upp, to start to one’s feet, jump up;
spratt upp lássinn, up sprang the lock;
spratt henni fótr ok féll hón, she slipped and fell;
spratt þat upp af heimamönnum, at, it was rumoured that;
3) to sprout, grow, of hair, grass, crops (piltar tveir léku á gólfi; þeim var sprottit hár ór kolli).
1) to make spring up, unfasten, loosen;
2) to rip open or up (s. saum);
ek lét s. berkinum, I had the bark peeled off;
Þjálfi spretti á knífi sínum, Th. split the bone with his knife.
2) to spirt out, issue forth (sprakk blóð bæði af nösum hennar ok munni);
3) to burst, split, break (hornit sprakk í sundr í miðju); sprotinn kom í andlitit ok sprakk fyrir, the switch came on his face, and the skin was broken;
4) to die from over-exertion, grief, etc.; s. af harmi, to break one’s heart; ef þú hefðir eigi mat, nema á hræum spryngir, if thou couldst get no food save by overgorging upon corpses.
2) the end-piece or clasp of a belt (fetlar sprotum settir).
a. sprightly, lively, active (sveinninn var s.).
(að), v. to sprawl, kick with the feet (Skotar létu smábörn s. á spjótaoddum).
a. asking many questions, inquiring, inquisitive (hverr er sá maðr, er svá er s.).

2) news, report, tidings (mun þegar s. koma til Höskulds); hafa s. af e-u or til e-s, to have news of.
1) to track, trace steps or footprints (hundar þeir, er vóru vanir at ~ þá upp, er undan hljópust);
2) to investigate, find out (þeir fengu hann eigi upp spurðan);
G. spurði, hvat hann vildi þá láta at gera, G. asked what he wished them to do;
with gen., ~ e-n tíðenda, to ask tidings of one;
~ e-n ráðs, to ask advice of, consult one;
H. spurði margs ór brennunni, H. asked much about the burning;
with preps., ~ e-n af e-u, at e-u, at um e-t, um e-t, to ask one about a thing;
~ at e-m, to inquire after one;
~ e-n at nafni, to ask one his name;
~ eptir, to ask, inquire (spurði hón eptir, hvat íslenzkra manna væri á skipi);
spurði Höskuldr dóttur sína ekki eprit, H. did not ask his daughter’s consent;
4) to hear, be informed of (~ sönn tíðendi);
Snorri spyrr nú, hvar komit málunum, now S. hears how the causes stood;
~ til e-s, to get inelligence as to, hear of (síðan hefi ek aldri til hans spurt);
5) refl., ~st, to be heard of or reported, to get abroad;
til Þórveigar spurðist þat, at hon lá hætt, it was told of Th. that she was very ill;
impers., mér spyrst á þann veg, I am told;
hefir til þessa skips aldregi spurzt, nothing has since been heard of this ship;
~st fyrir um e-t, to inquire about (þeir spurðust þá fyrir um ferðir Ólafs konungs);
recipr. to ask one another (~st tíðenda).

~ fœti á e-n or á e-m, s. fœti til e-s, to push one with the foot, to kick (Þórr spyrndi fœti sínum á hann); s. fœti (fótum) í e-t, to put or press one’s foot (feet) against; s. við, to struggle against with the feet (it fyrsta sinn, er úlfrinn spyrndi við, brotnaði sá fjöturr); s. e-u af sér, to kick off (gat hann spyrnt af sér fjötrinum); frá spyrndr allri eign, spurned from, bereft of; recipr., ~st í iljar, to touch one another with the soles (of two stretched on their backs).
(-rða, -rðr), v. to tie up (fish) by the tail.
(-tta, -ttr), v. to cheat (e-n af e-u) one out of a thing.
(spá, spát, spáð), v. to prophesy, foretell (s. em e-t or e-s).
(pl. spár), f. prophecy (sjaldan hafa spár mínar átt langan aldr).
v. to break into splinters (í Grindavík spánbraut buzuna).
(gen. spánar, pl. spænir or spœnir, acc. spánu or spónu), m.

1) chip, shaving (alla spánu báru þeir at skálanum, slógu síðan eld í allt saman); brjóta skip í spán, to have one’s ship broken to pieces (þeir brutu skipit í spán); brotna í spán, to be dashed to pieces (skipit brotnaði í spán);
3) ornament on a warship (only in pl.; cf. ennispænir);
4) divining chip, used at sacrifices (féll honum þá svá s. sem hann mundi eigi lengi lifa);
a. span-new, bran-new (mér er þessi atburðr ~); quite fresh, not exhausted (látum nú sem vér sém spánnýir).

a. prophetic (í hjarta spás manns); cf. forspár, veðrspár.

f. prophecy (góðar þykkja mér spásögur þínar).

3) ornament on a warship (only in pl.; cf. ennispænir);

(gen. spalar, pl. spelir, acc. spölu), m.
1) rail, bar; smugu þeir milli spalanna, they crept between the bars;
2) bit, short piece (hefja upp sögu ok segja af spöl nökkurn).
(gen. spangar, pl. spengr), f. spangle (varú lagðar yfir spengr af gulli); floe, flake of ice (Markarfljót féll í millum höfuðísa, ok váru spengr á hér ok hvar).

ertu Íslenzkr maðr? — hann sagði, at ~ var, he said it was so;
~ er sagt, at, it is told that;
2) joined with another particle, ~ … ok, both … and;
~ starf ok torveldi, both toil and trouble;
~ ráns-maðrinn ok okrkarlinn, the robber as well as the usurer;
sumarit ok ~ um vetrinn, the summer, as also the winter;
fögr augu ok ~ snarlig, fair eyes and also sharp;
3) so, denoting degree (œrit mun hann stórvirkr, en eigi veit ek, hvárt hann er ~ góðvirkr);
Gunnarr spyrr, hví Njáli þœtti þetta ~ úráðligt, why he thought this so unwise;
ekki meirr en ~, not more than so, so and no more;
4) followed by an adjective and ‘at’, ~ ríkr, góðr, mikill, margir, fáir … at, so mighty, good, great, many, few … that;
contracted ‘~t’, ~t ek muna, that (so far as) I remember;
with a gen., Hallfreðr er ~ manna, at ek skil sízt, H. is such a man as I never can make out;
hón er ~ kvenna (= hón er ~ af konum), at mér er mest um at eiga, she is just such a woman as I most want;
hárit var ~ fagrt sem silki, as fair (soft) as silk;
~ vel sem þér ferr, well as thou behavest;
6) so, then (gengu þeir norðr yfir hálsinn ok ~ fram á Rastarkálf);
7) joined to an a. or adv., about, pretty much;
þat mun þó ~ nær fara, yet it will be just on the verge of that;
mjök ~, almost, very nearly, all but (mjök ~ kominn at bana).
adv. not so, nor yet (vildi eigi, at þeir léti eignir sínar, ~ konur eða börn); svágort, svágurt, see sogörr; svana, adv. thus.

1) for oneself, separately, singly (fór Eyjólfr einn ~);
eitt er þat ~, that is a thing by itself;
2) in a distributive sense, ~ hverr, ~ hvárr, each by himself, each separately;
ef ~ ferr hverr várr, if each of us goes by himself;
stundum báðir samt, stundum ~ hvárr þeirra, sometimes each of them singly;
þat lið, er honum fylgði, flýr ~ hvat, in all directions.
2) exactly (Einarr kvað Þorstein eigi dauðan hafa verit ~).
láta grön ~, to sip through the beard.
f. sieve or strainer, for liquids.
f. glowing spark, esp. from metal (síur flugu ór afli).

(-rða, -rðr), v. to lay (a ship) alongside, in a sea-fight; with dat. (jarl síbyrði Barðanum enn við Orminn); without the dat. (síbyrði hann þar við Járnbarðann).
adv. broadside to broadside (leggja, liggja síbyrðis, síbyrt).
adv. every day, day by day.
(síg; seig or sé, sigum; siginn), v.

1) to sink gently down; seig á hann svefn, sleep came over him; sé sorti mikill fyrir augu þeim, a great darkness fell over their eyes; láta s., to let sink (Þórr lét s. brýnnar ofan fyrir augun); létu þeir s. festi ofan í gröfina, they lowered a rope down into the pit; fig., get ek, at héðan af fari þeim heldr síganda, I imagine it will go downwards with them henceforth;

2) to glide, move slowly (er þat mitt ráð at láta s. út skipin frá bryggjum); láta undan s., to retreat (Danir létu þá enn undan s.); láta s. aptr til sömu hafnar, to retreat to the same port; augun síga saman, the eyes close (in death); láta s. saman til samþykkis, to let things draw towards an agreement; létum s. sáttmál okkur, we came to terms;

3) refl., láta sígast, to let oneself sink; lætr hann s. ór trénu, he lets himself drop from the tree; hann lét s. fast á stólinn, he pressed himself down against the seat; nökkurir menn létu s. sárir, dropped down wounded; láta undan s., to retreat (jarl sótti hart fram þar til, er Álfgeirr lét undan s.).
m. cord, rope (þær ór sandi síma undu).
a. always talking, long-winded (~ í þinni rœðu).
gen. from the refl. pron., hefna s., to revenge oneself.
m. indecl. sir, master (esp. used of priests, sometimes of knights).
n. winding round; vefja e-u ~i, to wind it round and round.
1) since, = síðan er; engi er eira maki, s. Gunnarr lézt, since Gunnar died;
2) as prep. with acc. since, after; sofna ek minst s. mína sonu dauða, since the death of my sons.
adv. superl. least, opp. to helzt; þér vilda ek s. illt gera, thee least of all would I harm.
1) since, = síðan er; engi er eira maki, s. Gunnarr lézt, since Gunnar died;
2) as prep. with acc. since, after; sofna ek minst s. mína sonu dauða, since the death of my sons.
with gen., ~ aptans, sumars, vetrar, late in the evening, summer, winter;
~ um haustit, kveldit, late in the autumn, evening;
f., only in the phrase, um ~, at last (þó varð hann um ~ ofrliði borinn);
more commonly in pl., um (of) síðir (þó vaknaði hann um síðir).
2) flank, side of meat (síður af nauti allfeitar);
3) coast (hann braut skip sitt við Jótlands síðu).
(síð; seið, siðum; siðinn), v. to work charms through seiðr (þat er vá lítil, at vér síðim).
1) since, after that (~ gekk hón í brott); hefir sú kapella þar staðit ~, ever since; hvárki áðr né ~, neither before nor since;
2) afterwards, later on (koma þeir allir við þessa sögu s.);
3) as prep. with acc., þeir höfðu ekki etið s. laugardaginn, since Saturday;
4) with the relat. part., at, er, as conj., from the time when, since (s. er tengdir várar tókust);
5) since = s. er (E. hafði verit með Ólafi konungi s. Sveinn jarl andaðist); seeing that, in as much as (viltu, at ek gæta vitans, s. ek geri ekki annat).
adv. late (eitt kveld síðarla gengu til gestir nökkurir).
adv. late (eitt kveld síðarla gengu til gestir nökkurir).
adv. compar. (see síð), later (þau svik, er ~ komu fram);
fám vetrum ~, a few years later.
a. compar. later, latter, opp. to fyrri (it síðarra sumar).
f.; at síðustu, at síðastunni, at last.
a. latest, last (sá skal fyrstr út ganga er s. gengr inn); it síðarsta, at the latest (þá skal stefnt it síðarsta viku fyrir þing).
orð þau er hann mælti ~, his last words;
sá er ~ gengr inn, he who enters last.
f.; at síðustu, at síðastunni, at last.
a. latest, last (sá skal fyrstr út ganga er s. gengr inn); it síðarsta, at the latest (þá skal stefnt it síðarsta viku fyrir þing).
pp. wearing a hood low over the face (fyrsta aptan hafa brúðirnar síðfaldit).
pp. n., varð honum ~, he walked slowly.
a. late abroad, out late in the evening.
n., um or á ~um, late in the evening.
adv. late; s. kvelds, s. of aptaninn, late in the evening.

(síð, sítt), a. long, hanging down (sítt hár, skegg; síð klæði; síðar brynjur); hann hafði síðan hatt yfir hjálmi, a hood coming far down over the face; falda sítt, to wear a hood coming low over the face (brúðirnar falda sítt, svá at úgörla má sjá þeira yfirlit).

1) less (þat er mér enn s. hent); miklu s., much less; engu s., no less; eigi s., not less, as much (hann var kærr konungi, ok eigi s. dróttningu); eigi s. en, no less than, as well as (átti hann eigi síðr England en Danmörk); at s. vóru menn sjálfráðir fyrir konungi, at engi réð, á hvern guð trúa skyldi, so far were they from being independent, that, etc.;
2) as conj., lest, s. oss Loki kveði lastastöfum, that L. may not abuse us.
n. a wound in the side.
2) ~ út, to squander; sem fé þetta var út ~t, when this money was spent.
2) prosecution; urðu þá allir á þat sáttir, at þá væri framarr vörn en s., that the defence was better than the prosecution; sœkja með lands-laga sókn, to raise a lawful action;
3) concourse, resort of people (nú er s. mikil í Skálholt um allt Ísland.), company;
n. pl. the proofs for a prosecution.
n. a parliament with courts and pleading (aðrir menn vóru at dómum, því at ~ var).
(gen. sólar, dat. sól and sólu), f.

1) sun (hann fal sik á hendi þeim guði, er sólina hafði skapat); á morgin fyrir s., before sunrise; einn morgin við s., about sunrise; þá var dagr all-ljóss, ok s. farin, the sun had risen; sól var lítt farin, lítt á lopt komin, not high above the horizon; s. rennr upp, the sun rises; þegar er sólina lægði, when the sun got low; s. gengr í ægi, til viðar, undir, s. sezt, the sun sets; ganga at sólu, to go prosperously, succeed to one’s wishes (honum gengu náliga allir hlutir at sólu);
2) day; fyrir ina þriðju s., before the third sun, within three days; áðr sjau sólir eru af himni, before seven days have passed.
m. the burning heat of the sun.
m. the sun’s course, between sunrise and sunset (en er váraði ok ~ var sem mestr).
n. sun-reddening, sunrise; um morgininn í ~, at peep of dawn.
adv. sunwise, from east to west.
n. solstice (nú líðr fram at sólhvörfum).
n. pl. sunrise and sunset; með ~um, milli ~a, from sunrise till sunset.
f. solstice, usually in pl. (nú líðr fram at sólstöðum).
(-da), v. to beseem, become, befit (sómir þér konungum at þjóna); at hón sœmdi þér, that she were a fit match for thee; láta sér e-t s., to be pleased with.
m. honour (vil ek eigi drepa hendi við sóma minum).
n. a special sacrifice (of a boar).
1) to sweep, with dat. (griðkonan ~r saman léreptunum);
láta greipr ~ um e-t, ~ höndum um e-t, to make a clean sweep, carry off all;
2) to sweep a house, floor, with acc. (A. lét ~ húsin ok tjalda);
3) refl., ~st e-u, ~st at um e-t, ~st um, to scrape together, gather, = ~ e-u at sér (~st mönnum, ~st at um menn).
a. sooty; hann kom eigi undir sótkan rapt, he never came under a sooty rafter.
taka (or fá) s., to fall ill, be taken ill;
kasta á sik s., to feign illness;
kenna (or kenna sér) sóttar, to feel the symptoms of illness;
pl. pains of labour (at sú mær hafði miklar sóttir).
n. condition of one’s illness; sickness.
n. condition of one’s illness; sickness.
a. having died from sickness (hann lifði skemmst ok varð ~).
a. apt to be taken ill.
1) speech, opp. to þögn (s. eða þögn haf þér sjálfr í hug);
2) tale, report, news (konungr varð allreiðr, þá er hann heyrði þessa s.); þat er s. manna, at, people say, the story goes, that; nauðga e-m, pína e-n, til sagna, to force one to confess, by torture;
(gen. sakar, pl. sakar or sakir), f.
gera sakar á hendr sér, to incur charges;
gera sakir við e-n, to do offence or harm to one;
gefa e-m (upp) sakir, to remit a charge;
gefa e-m ~ (sakar) á e-u, gefa e-m e-t at ~, to make a charge against one;
fœrast undan ~um, to plead not guilty;
vera (bundinn) í ~um við e-n, to have done offence to one (konungr tók stór gjöld af bóndum þeim, er honum þóttu í ~um við sik);
eiga ~ á e-u, to have a ground for complaint;
ek á sjálfr ~ á því, that is my own affair;
svæfa allar sakar, to settle all causes;
fara með ~ina, to conduct the suit;
segja fram ~ sína, to declare ones suit;
hafa ekki at ~, to effect nothing;
tók Þóroddr þá at vanda um kvámur hans, ok hafði ekki at ~, but to no effect;
4) cause, reason (þótti konungi sakir til, þótt hann hefði eigi komit);
fyrir hverja ~, for the sake of what, why?
fyrir þá (þessa) ~, for that reason, therefore;
af þeim ~um, from that cause (svá lauk þessu, at húsfreyja lézt af þeim ~um);
fyrir e-s sakir or ~um, for the sake of, because of;
fyrir ástar sakir, for love’s sake;
with respect to (skyldi boðit verða sem vegligast, bæði fyrir tilfanga sakir ok fjölmennis);
fyrir mínum ~um, for my sake, for my part;
um sakar þínar, for thy sake;
of time, um nokkurra nátta sakir, for a few nights;
of (um) stundar sakir, for a while;
um sinns sakir, for this once;
um nætr sakir, for one night;
sakir e-s, ~um e-s = fyrir sakir e-s, fyrir ~um e-s.
m. a person with whom one is at variance, enemy, adversary.
m. a person with whom one is at variance, enemy, adversary.
a. n., in the phrase, eiga ~ við e-n, to have many quarrels with (á ek ~ við fólkit).
(gen. sölva), n. pl. an edible seaweed, dulse.
f. a piece of common stuff, wadmal.
f. pl. breeks made of ordinary stuff (söluváð).
m. cowl made of ordinary stuff (söluváð).
m. kirtle made of ordinary stuff (söluváð).
f. beach where dulse is gathered, dulse-gathering (vera í sölvafjöru).
(að), v. to make a jingling or ringing sound (spratt járnit á gólfit, svá at ~ði við).
(að), v. to saddle (ok bað hann ~ hesta þeira); fig., ~ e-u á e-t or á ofan, to add one (affront) to another (Björn ~r því á ofan, at hann kvað vísu þessa).
leggja söðul á hest, to saddle a horse.
(søkk; sökk, sukkum; sokkinn), v. to sink (skútan sökk niðr með öllum farminum).
(-ta, -t), v. to sink, make to sink, with dat. (reru þeir menn út á fjörð ok søktu þar niðr kistunni);
refl., ~st, to sink down (ormrinn søktist í sæinn).
(sýg; saug or só, sugum; soginn), v. to suck (sveinninn saug hana dauða).
(sýp; saup, supum; sopinn), v. to sip, drink (~ skyr);
s. á, to take a sip; to sip (hann saup á þrjá sopa).
(að), v. to become sour; ~r í augum, the eyes smart (from smoke).
1) sickness (eptir þat fær hann s. mikla ok liggr í rekkju um hríð);
2) grief, sorrow, affliction (snýst þessi hátíð í s. ok grát); ala s., to pine, feel care.
f. overlapping edge of a board (in clinker-built boats or ships).
pp. covered with over-lapping boards, of a house.
f. line of hoards in a ship (komnar voru níu sýjur á hvárt borð).
(only pret. pl. séðu, pp. séðr, sœðr), v. to fasten together (the outer planking in a ship or boat).
a., s. dagr, a day on sýknwhich lawsuits and actions are permitted.
(-da, -dr), v. to make stiff with ice (kuflinn var sýldr allr); impers., to turn into ice (sýldi hvern dropa, er inn kom); benjarnar sýldi, the wounds became stiff with cold.

1) the faculty of vision, sight (þau hafa ekki mál, enga s. né heyrn); þá er Hákon konungr kom í s. við bœinn, when king H. came within sight of the farm; hverfa at s., to be lost to sight, disappear (sól hvarf at s. ok gerði myrkt); er mér þat at s. orðit, er ek hefi opt heyrt frá sagt, I have seen with my eyes what I have often heard of;
2) vision (bar fyrir hann í svefni mikla s. ok merkiliga);
3) appearance, look (líkari eru þeir þursum at vexti ok at s. en menskum mönnum); fríðr sýnum, fair of face; at s., apparently (var þeim þar vel fagnat at s.).
1) to show (hón bað hann s. sér sverðit); þú skalt enga fáleika á þér s., thou must show no signs of coldness;

2) refl., sýnast, to appear, seem (sýndist vitrum mönnum hann afbragð); s. e-m, to appear to one in a dream (honum sýndist þá hinn helgi Ólafr konungr); e-m sýnist e-t, one thinks fit; veitið mér gröpt slíkan sem yðr sýnist, give me such burial as you please.
1) having eyesight, able to see (gamall ok s. lítt); (t) of weather, clear (í björtu veðri ok vel sýndu).
n. sight; til sýnis, for the sight’s sake; var hann sendr konungi til sýnis, as a curiosity; til sýnis e-s or um e-t, in proof of, as a sample of (til sýnis um mikilleika hestsins).
2) sightly (Þ. var mikill maðr ok sterkr ok hinn sýniligsti);
3) advisable (nú þykki mér þat sýniligast at fara aptr í ríki mitt).

1) clear, evident, certain (þér skal sýn búhlífð í því vera); þótti öllum at sýnu ganga, at, all thought that it was clear, beyond doubt, that; dat. sing. ‘sýnu’ with a compar. a great deal, much (sýnu meiri, minni, betri, verri); with a superl., E. gekk upp sýnu fyrstr, far ahead; neut. ‘synt’ as adv. evidently, clearly (þik skortir sýnt við hann);
2) fit, likely; ef yðr þykkir eigi annat sýnna fyrir liggja en vera hér, if you have nothing better to do.
(gen. sýr, acc. and dat. sú, pl. sýr), f. sow; also as a nickname.
n. a tub with sour whey.

1) to do, effect (E. konungr hafði mart sýst í landinu, þat er nytsemd var í); with dat., þá er hann hefir sýst eyrendum sínum, when he had done his errand; s. e-t at, to effect (þeir sýstu þat eitt at, at þeir sættust á víg Snorra); var svá til sýst, at, it was so arranged that; s. um e-t, to busy oneself with (hón sýsti um þörf gesta);
2) to procure, get (voru honum skjótt ~ðir hestar).
1) business, work; hjón sátu þar, héldu á sýslu, busy at their work; ganga um sýslur manna, to go about as an overseer;
a. fit for work (vel ~ at flestu verki).
2) bailiff, the king’s steward (at the same time justice and tax-gatherer).
(-tta, -ttr), v. to lament or mourn for one (þeir sýttu hann sem dauðan); s. við e-u, to grumble at, grudge (sýtir æ gløggr við gjöfum).
1) to put to death, kill, esp. a sacrificial beast (sœfð vóru þau kvikendi, er goðunum var fórnat);
2) refl., sœfast, to be killed; s. á sverðinu, spjótinu, to be killed by a sword or spear thrust through the body (sœfist hón á sverðinu ok deyr).
2) tumult, uproar (~ mikill er í bœnum ok lið allt ölótt);

1) to seek (hann ætlar at s. sér kirkjuvið ok siglir þegar á haf); þangat sœkir þik engi, no one will seek thee thither; s. heilræði ok traust at e-m, to seek good counsel and help from one; s. um liðveizlu við e-n, to call on one for support;
2) to go to fetch (B. átti erendi yfir fjörð at s. skjöldu sína ok vápn); s. e-t í e-n stað or til e-s staðar, to go to a place to fetch a thing (s. grös upp í hlíð, vatn til lœkjar);

3) to visit, come to (enn aldna jötun ek sótta); s. e-n heim, to come to see one, visit one in his home; s. þing, to attend or frequent á þing; s. e-n at liðveizlu, um liðveizlu, to call on one for support;
4) to attack, assail (s. e-n með vápnum; þessir munu s. oss með eldi); s. e-n heim, to fall upon one in his house (Gunnar sóttu heim þeir höfðingjar, er …);
5) to catch, overtake (nú fiðr hann geldingaflokk ok fær eigi sótt);
6) to overcome, master (munu þeir mik aldri fá sótt, meðan ek kem boganum við); to carry, take (eigi mun eyin sótt verða);
7) to pursue; þeir sækja ferðina knáliga, they push on doughtily; s. fast róðrinn (sundit), to pull (swim) hard;

8) to prosecute, in a lawsuit (s. e-n sökum, s. e-n til fullra laga); sótti K. til lands at Móeiðarhváli, K. laid claim to the land at M.; s. sök, mál, to carry on a suit; skalt þú s. þær sakir báðar, both these suits thou shall take up; s. mál til laga, to follow up a suit at law;
9) to pass over (býðr þeim at s. fjallit norðr í bygð); var áin all-ill at s., the river was very bad to cross;

10) absol. to proceed, go, advance (þeir stíga af hestunum ok ~ upp á hólinn); er hann sótti langt austr, when he had advanced far eastward; s. á fund e-s, to go to see one; s. at, s. á, to attack (s. á borg); to urge the matter, insist (Þ. sótti á því meirr, en G. fór undan); s. eptir e-m, to pursue (Egill sótti þá eptir þeim); s. fram, to advance, go forward, in battle (E. sótti þá fram ok hjó til beggja handa); s. til e-s staðar, to frequent a place (til Túnsbergs sóttu mjök kaupmenn);

11) refl., ~st, to advance, of a work in hand (en er á leið vetrinn, sóttist mjök borgargørðin); to be passed, of a road or distance; nú er meir en hálf-sótt, more than half-way; sóttist þeim seint skip þeira Hrúts, they were slow in boarding Hrut’s ship; þeir ætla, at þeim muni illa s. at vinna oss, they think it will be a hard struggle to master us; recipr., to seek one another ~st sér um líkir, birds of a feather flock together; to attack one another, fight (þeir nafnar sóttust lengi).
1) to honour; ef hann vildi s. hann í nökkuru léni, if he would honour him with (the grant of) a fief;
2) s. við e-t, to put up with, bear with (hann þóttist eigi mega s. við skap hennar); s. við heiminn, to conform to the world; s. við e-n, to attend, wait on (þú, kerling, skalt s. við gestinn).
1) honour; fá, hafa s. af e-u, to get, have honour from a matter; gera, veita e-m s., to do, show honour to one;
2) redress for loss or injury (þóttist Þórarinn enga s. hafa fyrir víg Þorvalds bróður síns).
m. (share of) honour (hafa sœmdarhlut af e-u).
m. honourable man, man of distinction (munt þú þar þykkja ~, sem þú ert); verða e-m at sœmdarmanni, to do honour to one.
a. becoming, befitting (þér er ~a sverð at rjóða).
1) to conjure, adjure (ek særi þik við alla krapta Krists);
2) to exorcize (~ djöfla frá óðum mönnum).
a. to be sworn, of an oath (hann sór þeim eiðinn ok sagði þó, at eigi mundi vel s. vera).
a. sweet (s. ilmr); þótti mér sløkkt it sœtasta ljós augna minna, the sweetest light of my eyes.
1) a board-game, ‘tables’, chess, draughts; sitja at tafli, leika t., at tafli, to play at chess; nú eru brögð í tafli, there is a trick in the game, there is foul play;
2) the board with the pieces (taflit svarfaðist);
f. piece in a game of tables.
n. the money played for, the stakes.
m. a bag for the pieces.
n. horse’s tail (skera t. ór hrossum); rarely, cow’s tail.
1) to take, catch, seize (tóku þeir laxinn ok otrinn ok báru með sér);
G. tók inni vinstri hendi spjótit á lopti, G. caught the spear with his left hand;
man hón ~ fé okkart allt með ráni, she will take all our goods by force;
~ e-n höndum, to seize one, take captive;
tökum vápn vár, let us take to our weapons;
2) fig., ~ trú, to take the faith, become a Christian;
~ rœðu, umrœðu, to begin a parley;
~ ráð, to take a counsel (= ~ til ráðs);
~ sættir or sættum, to accept terms;
~ þenna kost, to take this choice;
~ úgleði, to get out of spirits;
~ andviðri, to meet with contrary winds;
~ konung, to take, elect a king;
~ úkunna stigu, to take to unknown ways;
~ e-n or e-m vel, to receive one well;
~ e-t þvert, to take a thing crossly, deny flatly;
~ upp höndum, to raise the hands;
fremri hyrnan tók viðbeinit, the upper horn caught the collar bone;
því at ek tek eigi heim í kveld, for I shall not reach home to-night;
hárit tók ofan á belti, the hair came down to her waist;
4) to reach and take harbour (þeir tóku land á Melrakka-sléttu);
5) to take, hold, of a vessel (ketill, er tók tvær tunnur);

2) to entertain (t. e-n vel ok herliga).
1) help, protection, support (hingat em ek kominn at sœkja heilræði at þér ok t.); ek hefi lítil t. undir mér, small power, authority;

a. safe, to be relied on.

f., in the phrase, við t. ok nauð, with great difficulty.
a. unwilling, loath, reluctant (t. mun ek af hendi at láta sveit þessa); neut., trautt, scarcely, = trauðla (til þess munu menn trautt vita dœmi).
(pres. tregr, pret. tregði), irreg. v. to grieve; fjöld er þat, er fira tregr, many are the woes of man; hví tregr-at ykkr teiti at mæla, how can ye bear to speak words of cheer?.
(að), v. to grieve (marga menn ~ði mjök andlát porláks biskups); to bring grief upon (munaðar-ríki hefir margan ~t).
1) difficulty, reluctance; hafa enga trega í málum þessum, to raise no difficulties in these suits;
2) grief, woe (með tárum ok trega); svá fellr mér þetta nær um trega, at, this grieves me so much that.
2) reluctantly, unwillingly (Brúsi gekk ~ at öllu sáttmáli);
a. slow, reluctant (Þ. var heldr ~ í fyrstu);
it tregligasta, with the greatest difficulty.
a. unwilling, reluctant (Hrafn var inn tregasti at bregða flokkinum); tardy, slow (t. til sætta); neut., tregt = tregliga; mun honum þat tregt veita, it will go hard with him.
f. reluctance, unwillingness; hafa tregður í at gera e-t, to be unwilling to do a thing.
2) war-jacket (hann hafði góða brynju ok styrkja treyju).
1) to make trusty, make strong and safe (Höskuldr treysti mundriða í skildi);
2) to make firm (t. vináttu e-s); t. herinn ok eggja, encourage and exhort the troops;
3) to try the strength of a thing with the hand (hann treysti ‘silkibandit’ með handa-afli ok slitnaði eigi);
4) to trust to, rely on (t. e-m or t. á e-n);
5) to dare, venture (nú er sú öld í Noregi, at ek treysti eigi at halda ykkr hér heima með mér);
6) refl., ~st = ~ 4 (treystust Numidiumenn betr fótum en vápnum); = ~ 5 (hann mun eigi t. öðru en gøra sem ek vil).
(treð, tradda, traddr), v. to tread down, trample.

1) a monstrous, evil-disposed being, not belonging to the human race (hann var mikill sem t.); t. hafi þik, or þína vini, the ~s take thee, or thy friends;

a. indecl. ridden by a troll, witch-ridden.

1) to tread; t. skó, to wear out shoes; t. e-n undir fótum, to tread one under foot; t. stafkarlsstíg, to wander as a beggar;

3) to slop, cram with, t. e-t e-u (hann treðr belginn lyngvi ok mosa);
4) refl., ~st, to throng, crowd upon each other (troðist eigi svá ákaft).
1) pipe; hvann-njóla t., the stalk of the angelica;

a. safe, to be relied on.

(-ða, -ðr), v. to make firm and trusty (trygðu þeir Þórir þá sættir með sér).

f. pl. plighted faith, sworn truce (svíkja e-n í trygðum).
1) to turn into troll, enchant (þeir trylldu hann svá at hann var engum mennskum manni líkr);
3) refl., ~st, to be turned into a troll, to be enchanted.
(pl. tré, gen. trjá, dat. trjám), n.
1) tree (höggva t. í skógi); eigi felir t. við it fyrsta högg, the tree falls not at the first stroke;
2) the mast of a ship, = siglutré (á skipi Munans brotnaði ~it);
m. wooden leg (ganga við tréfót); also as a nickname.
(að), v. to become hard and woody, of a tree or plant-stem.
n. the carving on a post of a person’s likeness in an obscene posture.

1) faith, word of honour (segir Ólafr þat upp á t. sína, at hann skal þessa menn út leysa);
2) religious faith, belief (Helgi var blandinn mjök í t.); taka við t., to receive the Christian faith.
(gen. trú), f. = trú; svá njóta ek trú minnar, þat veit trúa mín, in good sooth, upon my word.
1) to believe, with dat. (mundir þú t. fyrirburð þessum, ef Njáll segði þér?);
2) in a religious sense, to believe; t. á e-n, to believe in (t. á einn guð);
3) to believe in, trust (meyjar orðum skýli manngi t.).
a. credible (þótti mönnum sú sögn trúanlig).
pp. believing; rétt t., orthodox; trúaðir menn, believers.
2) safe, to be relied on; veðr er trúligt, the trúweather bids fair;
m. a true believer, good Christian.
1) trust, good faith (var þetta sáttmáí bundit með fullum trúnaði); ganga í trúnað fyrir e-n, to become bound for another, go security for one;
2) faithfulness (halda man ek við þik fullum trúnaði);
3) trust, confidence; festa, leggja trúnað á e-t, to give credence to; eiga trúnað undir e-m, to have confidence (faith) in one; hafa trúnað á e-m, to place confidence in one;

4) confidence, secret; til hvers reiðt þú til þings, ef þú vill eigi segja mér trúnað þinn, if thou wilt not tell me thy secret; segja e-m e-t af trúnaði, in confidence, secretly; mæla trúnað fyrir e-m, to speak in confidence to one.
1) true, faithful (t. skal ek þér í ráðum);
2) safe; er eigi trútt, at, it is not quite safe that, quite free from it (er eigi trútt, at mér hafi eigi í skap runnit sonar-dauð-inn);
n. snout (of a dog or bear).
m. a cloak filled with straps.
m. a cloak filled with straps.
m. = tigr; hafði hann þrjá vetr hins fjórða tugar, he was thirty-three years old.
ord. numb. twentieth, = tuttugti (við tugtugta mann).

1) tongue; skœðar tungur, evil tongues; hafa tungu fyrir e-m, to have a tongue for a person, be the spokesman; gæti hann, að honum vefist eigi ~n um höfuð, let him take heed that his tongue do not twist a noose for his own neck;

n. the moon (t. óð í skýjum).

f. pl. the roots of the tongue.

(að), v. to turn; t. e-u um, to turn upside down.

a. consisting of two different things or kinds, twofold (tvenn frásögn); í tvennu lagi, in two parts; tvennir, two (á skóginum voru tvennar leiðir); nú ferr tvennum sögunum fram, two tales now run parallel; tvennir skór, two pair of shoes; neut. tvennt, two things (sides, parts); hefir mér tvennt um sýnzt, there has seemed to be two sides to the matter.

pp. mounted with a double ring.
pp. having two wives at once, bigamous.

spjótin tóku ~ til hans, the spears scarcely reached him;

n. pl. tidings, news, events; þú skalt eigi kunna frá tíðindum at segja, thou shall not be left alive to tell the tale; gerast (verða) til tíðinda, to happen, occur (verðr ekki til tíðinda); mun þetta vita tíðinda, this forebodes great tidings; er þetta var tíðinda, when this happened.
adv., in the phrase, vita, hvat ~ var, to know what was the news.
